Title: Gujarat: Cumin acreage up 44%, output may rise by 25% in 2020
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Adequate rainfall coupled with decent prices have brightened the prospects of cumin (jeera) farmers in Gujarat. The acreage sown with cumin in the state has increased by 44% and output is likely to rise by 25% in 2020.

Data compiled by the Gujarat government’s director of agriculture shows that cumin acreage has increased by 1.41 lakh hectares (ha) to 4.87 lakh hectares by the end of the January 13, against 3.45 lakh hectares at the point of 2019. The total cumin acreage for the entire rabi season last year was 3.82 lakh ha.

Greater availability of water following a good monsoon and farmers getting good price for their produce last year are the factors responsible for the increase in cumin cultivation.

“Gujarat saw less cumin production last year, which helped farmers get good prices for their produce. This year the monsoon was good. As a result, the area under cumin cultivation has increased,” said Ashwin Nayak, chairman, Federation of Indian Spice Stakeholders (FISS).

Lower production projections had kept cumin prices between Rs 2,700 to Rs 3,400 per 20kg throughout 2019. Prices are still firm between Rs 2,700 and Rs 3,200 per 20kg depending on quality.

“With the higher acreage, Gujarat is expected to produce 25% more cumin than last year. A lot depends on the weather over the next couple of months. If weather changes unexpectedly, it could hurt the crop,” Nayak added.

The new crop is expected to begin arriving at market yards from March end or early April, as sowing was delayed this year, market players say.

According FISS, cumin production in Gujarat in 2019 was low, at 1.67 lakh metric tonnes, compared to 1.71 lakh metric tonnes in 2018.AHMEDABAD

Title: What areas in Sec’bad need better traffic monitoring?
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

With Rachakonda police roping in volunteers to help ease the traffic in Sec’bad, TOI asked readers which areas were facing traffic issues -

Traffic monitoring is the need of the hour from Bolarum to Tirumulgherry and beyond. Roads in various parts of the city are in shambles. Areas such as Bolarum, Alwal, Lothkunta, Tirumulgherry and Vasavi Nagar need better roads. Roads in various areas have bottlenecks thanks to encroachments by shopkeepers, bus stops and illegal parking lots. Not even a single traffic signal is manned properly. The traffic police should study the busy stretches and understand the requirements of each junction. Widening can be a temporary solution but not a complete answer. Traffic islands, traffic signals and manual availability of police personnel at all times is the best possible way out to overcome traffic issues - Deepesh Surana

As many of the important roads are not wide enough, traffic snarls are a common sight even during non-peak hours. However, the busiest roads in Secunderabad such as Paradise junction and Patny junction need special attention. In these areas traffic comes to a grinding halt in the absence of adequate police personnel to regulate traffic from dawn to dusk. For easy flow of traffic, law-enforcing agency should not only strictly prohibit parking on either side of the road but also see that no cart-vendor is allowed to occupy part of the road and transact business. Police must also caution RTC drivers against rolling stops and stopping in the middle of the roads. Home guards must be pressed into service and posted on all busy roads to assist police personnel in smooth movement of traffic - Srinivasan Ramaswamy

Areas such as Lal Bazar junction , Lothkunta junction, Alwal require better traffic management. Several areas such as Uppal, Hubsigua, ECIL 'X' roads, West Marredpally main road, Shenoy Hospital road, old Bowenpally petrol bunk, Hasmathpet road experience regular traffic snarls and this must be looked into - CH Simhadri

The involvement of traffic volunteers is a very good initiative by Rachakonda traffic police. We as citizens must also be a part of this initiative and learn traffic rules and regulations. We must also follow these rules and help those around us do the same - Raja Shekhar Mettu

It is a good idea to rope in traffic volunteers. Those who do not follow the traffic rules must be made volunteers. Authorities must get rid of long meridians that is causing traffic woes in various parts of the city - K Mohan

Title: Uttarakhand shuttler claims titles in Junior Ranking event
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Aditi Bhatt

DEHRADUN: Uttarakhand’s Aditi Bhatt won gold and bronze medals at the All India Junior Ranking Tournament 2020 that was held in Chandigarh.

Second seeds Bhatt and her partner from Kannada, Tanya Hemanth, defeated Uttar Pradesh’s Shruti Mishra and Shailja Shukla 21-11 and 21-9 in the final of the girl’s doubles event.

The triumph in the finals helped the duo to clinch gold medal. In the singles event, Bhatt lost the semi-final to Uttar Pradesh’s Mansi Singh 18-21 and 16-21, which earned her a bronze medal.

The national championship was held in Chandigarh from January 10 to January 14.

Speaking about her success, Bhatt told TOI Thursday, “The finals was not that tough, as we managed to beat them quite comfortably. But, the quarter-finals against the Telangana pair was extremely tough. But I am quite happy that we won because it was the first time I was paired with Tanya Hemanth. Now, the other selection tournament is in Bengaluru, where my objective will be to secure a gold medal in the singles event too,” said Bhatt.

Bahadur Singh Mankoti, secretary of the Uttarakhand State Badminton Association (USBA), credited Bhatt’s mother for her victory.

“She has been a U-17 national champion and even won gold in U-19 all India competition. Her future is very bright as she is giving consistent performances. We are quite sure that she will play soon in major international tournaments. Recently, she performed well in the national as well as international tournaments. The Credit for her consistent performance goes to her mother as she always travels with her for tournaments,” Mankoti said.

Aditi Bhatt’s mother Poonam Bhatt hoped that her daughter replicates her performance in the Bengaluru event.

“I have been devoting my time with Aditi for the last 8 to 10 years. This was one of the two selection tournament. The other one will start next week in Bengaluru. Based on the performance in both these tournaments, players will be selected for international tournaments in Netherlands and Germany. Top 4 players of different categories will be selected and Aditi has very good chances of getting selected,” said Poonam Bhatt.

Title: Dehradun: AYUSH students threatens protest if colleges fail to refund hiked fees
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Trivendra Rawat

DEHRADUN: Even after the chief minister’s directive two months ago and the high court’s order last year, many private AYUSH colleges in the state are yet to refund the hiked fees of over 6,000 students. Irked, the students have now decided to launch their protest again if the state government does not intervene in the matter immediately.

“We had written several reminders to the university and to the government, but no action was taken against the colleges makes, which makes the government’s intentions very clear towards AYUSH students . We are left with no option than to re-start our agitation, as the examinations are fast approaching and the colleges are forcing students to pay the hiked fees to get themselves registered,” president of AYUSH student’s medical association, Faizal Siddique said.

Notably, chief minister, Trivendra Rawat in November last year had assured that the state government would ensure compliance of the orders of High Court which has asked the Ayurvedic colleges to return the hiked fees to all the students within a month’s time. The CM had also announced to make a fee fixation committee which would be headed by a HC judge.

The decision of ensuring the compliance of HC’s order was taken in the emergency meeting called by the chief minister which was attended by Ayush Minister Harak Singh Rawat, Ayush secretary Dilip Jawalkar and authorities of Ayurvedic University.

The colleges had hiked the fees to Rs 2.5 to Rs 3 lakhs, which was just Rs 80,000 earlier. The students had approached high court last year and even the court maintained that the fee hike was unreasonably high and ordered the colleges to return the fees.

Title: Uttarakhand: Clinic sealed by health department, admin in Bhagwanpur
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

ROORKEE: A joint team of health department and local administration of Roorkee sealed an illegal clinic, which also facilitated maternity services, which was running in an industrial area of Bhagwanpur . Villagers living nearby had lodged a complaint against the clinic with local administration a few days ago. District health department has cracked down on about 10 such illegal clinics, mostly run by quacks across Haridwar in the last two months.

The officials of health and administration of Bhagwanpur sub-division in Roorkee on Thursday sealed Jyoti Clinic at Bhagwanpur. The clinic, a maternity centre, was run by a woman. When officials asked to show her credentials of medical profession, registration of clinic and other registration certificates of bio-waste management, she could not produce them.

Title: Nagpur: Five times increase in hacking cases in two years
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: Artist Bijayananda Biswal, a noted painter who was even mentioned by Prime Minister Narendra Modi in a speech, is the latest victim of hackers. They managed to take over his social networking account which had images of most of his creations over the years. The former railway employee said he was stunned to find out he could no longer access his award winning art works online, or interact with his thousands of followers.

A Right to information (RTI) Act query recently underlined how hacking cases have increased from 21 in 2017 to over 100 last year. It makes for a 79% jump from 57 in 2018 to 100 the following year.

The rise in hacking leaves behind the increase in cases of cyber frauds. In 2019, there was an increase of 77% in online cheating cases, which rose from 1,349 in 2018 to 2,377 in the following year. Apart from hacking, there was also a rise in crimes related to social media, from 573 in 2019 to 393 in 2018.

DCP, cyber crime , Shweta Khedkar said cases of hacking have increased but police are also trying to detect cases and nab offenders as fast as possible. “Websites and social media accounts must be secured with anti-virus applications like firewalls and other protections. Accounts and websites must not be vulnerable to cyber attacks easily,” she said.

“We have managed to crack cases and zero down on culprits too, like in the case of a private bank, but users should practice caution in the first place,” said the DCP. She added that one of the reasons hackers operate is the lure of earning easy and fast money. Some hackers are also driven by psychological aberrations or even criminal designs, like revenge or extortion.

Advocate Mahendra Limaye, an IT expert, said hacking has not been specifically mentioned in the amended IT Act, but is described as illegal access to a computer, system or network. “Hacking or such illegal access can land one in prison for three years and fine up to Rs3 lakh, if proved,” said Limaye.

“One of the plausible reasons behind the rise in hacking may be the increase in the drive to collect more information. One must be careful regarding using unprotected systems or connecting one’s system in public places. Using free Wi-Fi and such facilities at public places is not advisable as unknown systems and networks get access to one’s personal systems,” he said. “Auto-logins and saving passwords at random is also an easy invitation to hackers,” said the IT expert.

Limaye also said that the institution imparting training in ethical hacking should also make their students aware that such practices can lead to legal problems if done with criminal intent.

Title: Delhi: Hassles mount, road users want protest site shifted
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

To avoid being stuck at Ashram, two-wheelers are illegally passing through Okhla Bird Sanctuary

NEW DELHI: How bad can traffic jams be? Shivani Jain, who lives in Sarita Vihar in south-east Delhi , was forced to shift to Noida to avoid the daily jams on Mathura Road. With the shorter, and the relatively freer Kalindi Kunj road closed due to an anti-Citizenship Amendment Act protest, Jain shifted to her mother’s house because she could not afford her children missing school.

“Nursery and KG students are stuck in traffic jams for hours,” exclaimed Jain, recalling how the school bus brought her son home around 4pm instead of 2pm.

Thursday was 33rd day of the protest by the women of Shaheen Bagh . While gathering nationwide attention and sympathy, they have blocked Road 13A, which links the Sarita Vihar underpass and Mathura Road with Kalindi Kunj, leaving office goers, students and health services in a quandary. Slum dwellers near Jasola Vihar who work as maids in south Delhi localities, have also been impacted.

On Thursday afternoon, TOI found seven ambulances stuck in the traffic going towards Ashram. Hospitals in the affected area include Holy Family, Fortis Escorts Heart Institute and Apollo Indraprastha, besides other smaller establishments. Ambulance driver B. Paswan at Holy Family conceded that the protesters allowed vehicles carrying patients to pass through, but barred the empty ones. “What if we receive an emergency call when stuck in a jam?” Paswan asked.

Even patients are inconvenienced. At Indraprastha Apollo Hospital, doctors told TOI of patients caught in traffic. “In emergency cases, these delays can prove disastrous,” said a doctor. At Fortis Escorts, the doctors revealed how in the initial few days of the protest, many patients, especially from outside Delhi, failed to arrive for scheduled appointments fearing violence.

The routine of students going and coming from schools has been disrupted too. Anita Sahani, who lives in Sarita Vihar’s L Pocket, was especially harassed because the school timings of her two children are different. “The school bus does not come and for a month now I have had to either wait at the school or make two journeys via the clogged raid,” said Sahani glumly.

To avoid being stuck at Ashram, two-wheelers now use the road inside the Okhla bird sanctuary. Such unauthorised entry can lead to jail stay and fine, but Mahesh Yadav, a delivery executive, pleaded helplessness. “Delivery to Noida or Faridabad will be much delayed. Instead of 10-15 minutes, I sometimes take 1-2 hours to cover short distances,” he said.

Mohammad Aman, who runs a construction and demolition business, said that though he supported the protest, the government should now coax the protesters to shift. Like him, most residents of Sarita Vihar, Jasola Vihar and Sukhdev Vihar side with the protesters, but sheer necessity has prompted them to seek a change of the sit-in site. On Sunday, a large crowd in Sarita Vihar asked for the barricades at Shaheen Bagh to be removed.

On Thursday evening, the area ACP addressed the protesters, asking them to allow traffic movement on the Kalindi Kunj road since it was affecting business in the area. The cops even offered the protesters an alternate space where they could continue the protest.

Title: Nagpur: Man gets 1-year rigorous imprisonment for sexually harassing minor
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

Title: Nagpur: Man surrenders after bludgeoning live-in partner to death
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: A 35-year-old man surrendered before Wadi police on late Wednesday night after allegedly bludgeoning his live-in partner to death a few hours earlier at their house in Ambedkar Nagar. Wadi police have arrested the accused, Sidharth Sonpiple, and booked him for murder under sections 302 and 201 of Indian Penal Code (IPC).

He was produced before the court on Thursday and remanded in police custody for a day.

Police said Sidharth, a labourer, and his partner Alka were living together since the last three months. The couple was separated from their husband and wife. They used to regularly get into fights as Sidharth suspected that Alka’ was in a relationship with some other person/s. Alka regularly went out at night and came back in the morning, which used to bother Sidharth.

On Tuesday night, the duo had dinner and got into a fight after Alka said that she is going out. Alka went out and came back at around 5am on Wednesday.

On Wednesday afternoon, the duo again got into a fight after Sidharth asked Alka where she had been the entire night. When Alka’s answer failed to satisfy Sidharth, the accused got angry, picked up an iron rod (khalbatta) and started hitting her.

Alka sustained injuries on her head and stomach. Sidharth got frightened and left her in a pool of blood. He locked the house and went outside. After roaming for several hours, he approached Wadi police station at around 10.30pm and confessed to the crime.

Police soon rushed to the spot and sent her body to Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) where the post mortem was conducted. Cops later arrested Sidharth.

Title: Dehradun: To decongest traffic,police come up with special plan
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

DEHRADUN: To reduce traffic congestion in the city, the traffic police department has decided to run a special traffic plan on a trial basis on Sunday. And hence, due to this special plan, a number of routes will be affected, including Darshan Lal Chowk, Survey Chowk, Chakrata Road, EC Road, Lansdowne Chowk, MKP Chowk, Araghar Chowk, Prince Chowk, Clock Tower and Rajpur Road.

“We have decided to experiment with this special traffic route plan and see whether it helps in reducing the city’s traffic or not. As of now, it will take place only on the coming Sunday and based on the feedback, we will plan for its use in future,” said Prakash Chandra Arya, SP (traffic) Dehradun.

Title: Dehradun: Citizen groups take lead in segregating waste, educating residents
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Eco Group in Kewal Vihar, has around 150 families that are segregating their waste and making compost out of w... Read More

DEHRADUN: Disappointed with the poor garbage management of the civic body in terms of segregation of waste, several resident groups have taken it upon themselves to segregate the daily waste they generate in their respective localities.

One such group, Eco Group in Kewal Vihar, has around 150 families that are segregating their waste and making compost out of wet waste.

The group members say they ensure segregation and composting of around 100kg waste daily. The practice has given employment to women from economically backward sections, as the group gives them unused or waste cloth material, which they turn into cloth carry bags.

"On weekends, we also conduct awareness drives in other localities of Dehradun. Different programmes are being planned for different localities. For instance, in slums, we ask children to separate plastic from daily waste and hand it over to us, as we want to make sure that minimum plastic goes to the landfill in Shishambara,” said Ashish Garg, member, Eco Group.

Another group, Eco Campus Drive that began in 2017, is catering to around 800 people living in the campus of the Indian Institute of Petroleum. They started with awareness drives and later proceeded to door-to-door garbage collection. More than 70kg waste is segregated and composted by them daily, the group members claim.

“Our campus is spread over more than 750 acres. Wet waste is composted in pits across the campus. We try to recycle the dry waste, and send the non-recyclable part to the municipal corporation. We have a plastic-to-diesel converter that produces 800 litre diesel from around 1 tonne of plastic waste. We have seven active members and our aim is to make our campus zero-waste,” said Suman Jain, coordinator, Eco Campus Drive.

Residents of Siddhartha Paradise in Panditwari, have also started a group, with 500 residents practicing complete segregation of 80kg of waste they produce daily, since October last year.

“We have six active members. Apart from waste management, we conduct awareness drives especially for maids, as they are the best bet for segregating household waste. A vehicle of the NGO Waste Warriors comes every 10 days to collect the dry waste, while bio-medical waste is collected by NGO Medical Pollution Control Committee every three days. We compost 65% of the wet waste in over 30 drums installed at various spots of the colony. The rest goes to the municipal corporation,” said Narendra Singh Rawat, member, Siddhartha Paradise RWA.

Title: Nagpur: Cutting trees is last option for any project said Nitin Gadkari
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Nitin Gadkari

NAGPUR: In news that could assuage ruffled environmentalists, Union surface transport and highways minister Nitin Gadkari has assured citizens to give his complete support to conservation of trees and environment.

Speaking exclusively to TOI, the two-time city MP said cutting trees “has always been the last option for any project”. Gadkari was speaking a day after the civic authorities decided to drop plans to construct a road through a thriving bio-diversity in Bharat Nagar area of the city which is owned by the Panjabrao Deshmukh Krishi Vidyapeeth (PDKV).

Calling himself an environment lover, Gadkari said, “Whenever I think of development, the prime focus is on ensuring that progress and environment protection go hand-in-hand. I am very alert towards such issues and I assure the citizens to give my complete support.”

Affirming that not a single tree would be cut at the urban mini-forest rechristened as ‘Bharat Van’, Gadkari said, “Many citizens came to meet me and, after various discussions, we decided to find a middle way. Our aim was to come up with a solution which doesn’t damage the trees in Bharat Van. Today, I am delighted that not a single tree will have to be cut for this road project. ”

As reported by TOI earlier, hundreds of environmentally conscious citizens including residents of Bharat Nagar, green activists, children, doctors, senior citizens and members of various civil society groups came together on April 3 last year to meet Gadkari, raising their voice against “environment foeticide” which was set to destroy Bharat Van.

TOI was the first to report about the proposed road which was a part of the nearby Telangkhedi Lake redevelopment project. In Gadkari’s own words, the facelift for the lake by constructing a musical fountain and an elevated viewing gallery has been his “dream project”. This paper had also highlighted how more than 500 age-old trees and a rich biodiversity habitat are threatened by the development plans.

Welcoming the minister’s stance, environment activists in the city stressed that the next focus should be on conserving the Telangkhedi lake. “We are grateful that the minister took a decision keeping in mind the concerns of citizens. Though Bharat Van is now safe, the 220-year-old lake is on the verge of dying. It is full of garbage, silt and water hyacinth due to which its dissolved oxygen levels are dropping. Even if the musical fountains and other activities start, the lake will die within a few years,” said Jaydeep Das, honorary wildlife warden of Nagpur.

Based on TOI’s reports, Das had written a letter to the Nagpur bench of Bombay high court highlighting the adverse impacts of the proposed road. HC had treated his letter as a suo motu public interest litigation on December 3, 2018.

Meanwhile, MahaMetro, which is the executing agency of the project, has stated that dropping the road was a joint decision of itself, Nagpur Municipal Corporation and Public Works Department (PWD). “Metro had no central role in policy-planning of this project. The plan for constructing the road was submitted as per directives from PWD, which is handling the planning and financing of the entire project,” the agency stated. It added that changes at any level were communicated to MahaMetro by PWD.

Title: Nagpur: Cleared a subject in revaluation from 2016? Apply for refund now
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

In a shocking revelation, Nagpur University’s (NU) vice-chancellor SP Kane admitted that the administration fa... Read More

NAGPUR: In a shocking revelation, Nagpur University’s (NU) vice-chancellor SP Kane admitted that the administration failed to spread awareness about refund of revaluation scheme since the last three years, which led to not a single student applying for it. He, however, assured that anyone applying for refund after clearing their subjects in the last three years will be given their dues.

“We started the refund scheme in 2016-17, but haven’t received even a single application. It’s correct that we haven’t created awareness about it. Now, we’ve decided to take bank account details of students along with IFSC code so that their refund could directly be deposited into their accounts,” Kane told TOI, adding that he aims to make the system completely cashless.

With a view to fulfil long-pending demands of various students’ organizations like ABVP, NSUI, MNS and NCP among others, the VC on October 23, 2016, announced to refund the revaluation fees of Rs150/paper if the student cleared the subject. TOI had reported his major announcement which he had termed as one of his dream projects in detail next day.

A recent RTI query by Abhay Kolarkar disclosed that NU collected over Rs3.30 crore from revaluation fees of students in the last three years. In reply to the activist’s questions, NU’s assistant registrar Manoj Joshi said the number of students applying for revaluation had jumped from 20,458 in 2016 examination to 45,500 in 2019 summer exams.

Explaining the rise in figures, the VC said it was due to increase in the number of exams due to introduction of semester pattern. On being pointed out that the new pattern was introduced about three years ago, Kane, who’s tenure is coming to an end on April 7, said that in 2016-17, only BSc courses were offered in the semester system while BCom, BA and other courses were added in later years.

“In the last three years mentioned in the RTI query, six exams were conducted as per semester patten. There’s no question of raising doubts on the evaluators. Unlike common perception, we don’t like receiving revaluation applications from the students. It would be a golden day in the university’s history when there wouldn’t be even a single applicant,” Kane said.

The VC said he had already asked director of students’ welfare (DSW) to issue a notification for refund of revaluation fees and inform all the conducted and affiliated colleges to paste that on their notice boards so that the students would come to know about it.

“Even now, the students can apply on plain paper if they cleared the subject after revaluation. We’re also exploring option of online application,” he added.

Title: Bansidhar Bhagat is new BJP chief of Uttarakhand
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Addressing the media after his anoinment, Bhagat said, “I am thankful to the party for giving me this responsi... Read More

DEHRADUN: Amid sloganeering and bursting of crackers, Union minister Arjun Ram Meghwal announced the name of six-time MLA from Kaladhungi Bansidhar Bhagat as the new Uttarakhand BJP president on Thursday.

Meghwal made the announcement after getting feedback from a BJP panel which also included CM Trivendra Singh Rawat. “There was only one name that we discussed and in keeping with the traditions of our party, Bhagat’s name was cleared unopposed for the state president post,” said the Union minister.

Sources said that the names of candidates who were said to be in the fray such as Kailash Pant, Suresh Joshi and Naveen Dumka were not discussed and Bhagat was elected unopposed by the party.

Meanwhile, former Madhya Pradesh CM Shivraj Singh Chouhan, who was expected to attend the announcement, couldn't make it to Doon.

Addressing the media after his anoinment, Bhagat said, “I am thankful to the party for giving me this responsibility and my priority is to prepare for the 2022 assembly elections by strengthening the party at the booth level.”

Bhagat further said, “The state president’s role is important to coordinate with the state government and boost the morale of the party cadre for different campaigns.” After taking over the reins, the new president also held a meeting with the office-bearers of the state unit at the party office in Dehradun. According to BJP insiders, Bhagat would be setting up his team for the state level in the coming weeks, followed by a whirlwind tour of all 70 constituencies in the hill state.

Senior leaders such as Union HRD minister Ramesh Pokhriyal Nishank, Nainital MP Ajay Bhatt, state cabinet minister Dhan Singh Rawat, and others also reached the party office to congratulate Bhagat.

Speaking to mediapersons, Nishank hailed Bhagat as his contemporary who has deep knowledge of booth-level management and party’s organisation functioning. “I am fully confident that his skills in managing the organisation and immense experience as a legislator would strengthen the BJP in Uttarakhand,” he said.

Outgoing state president Ajay Bhatt said, “Bhagat has a great organisational experience and has a deep connection with party workers across the state.”

Title: Tamil Nadu: Auto driver beaten to death over illicit relationship
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

VELLORE: A 36-year-old autorickshaw driver was beaten to death by a man over an illicit relationship in Vellore on Wednesday.

A police officer investigating the case identified the murdered victim as Barath, of Kansalpettai.

Barath married to Selvi and the couple had two sons. He was in an illicit relationship with a woman in Vellore.

Recently, he allegedly developed illicit relationship with the woman’s daughter. But Michael alias Umashankar, 32, of Shenbakkam, was also in a relation with woman’s daughter. Michael disclosed Barath’s relationship with the woman and her daughter to his wife.

On Wednesday afternoon, Umashankar confronted Barath and entered in a brawl.

During the fight, while Barath Barath went to pick up a stick lying nearby Umashankar attacked him with an iron rod hidden in his hip and fled away from the spot.

Barath was declared dead at Government Vellore Medical College and Hospital.

Later, the Vellore North police registered a case and arrested Umashankar .

Preliminary investigation revealed Umashankar was a historysheeter involved in various cases of attempt to murder in Vellore Taluk police station limit.

Title: Action against diagnostic centre for doing sex determination tests
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Police have seized the ultrasound machine and are preparing to lodge a case against the owners

JHANSI: A diagnostic centre in Jhansi which conducted sex determination test was caught red-handed on Wednesday. Authorities have seized the ultrasound machine and are preparing to lodge a case against the owners.

As per the details, a team from Gwalior headed by deputy collector Deepshikha Bhagat, along with nayab tehsildar Vandana Yadav, visited the diagnostic centre after receiving regular inputs that women from Madhya Pradesh were sent here for illegal sex determination of their unborn children.

During initial investigations, they had rounded up an Anganwadi female worker Aruna Yadav, who used to act as a mediator.

The team got in touch with the local authorities after reaching here. Nayab tehsildar herself, as a decoy customer, contacted a native broker Shubhash Yadav and clinched a deal of Rs 10,000 for conducting the test. The broker took the decoy customer to Jai Matadi Ultrasound Centre situated opposite to Jhansi Medical College where they met with one Ram Naresh Patel.

During the negotiation, other team members also arrived along with Jhansi authorities—ACM Vanya Singh and nodal head (Pre-Conception and Pre-Natal Diagnostic Techniques) Dr Mahendra Kumar—and caught them red-handed.

As per city magistrate Salil Kumar Patel, the centre is registered in the name of Dr ML Verma who was not present during the raid.

The test was being conducted by Ram Naresh Patel, an arts graduate, whereas, Subhash and Aruna worked as brokers. During interrogation, Aruna revealed that in the past, she had brought three more people for the test and charged Rs 10,000 each from them.

“We have seized the ultrasound machine, along with a tracker machine, computer harddisk and a few registers. We are preparing to lodge a case under Section 28 of PCPNDT Act in consultation with the APO,” said the city magistrate.

Title: Nagpur: New format of ‘Travelers Adda’ promises an engaging session
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: A revamped and more interactive version of ‘Travelers Adda’ awaits travel enthusiasts this Saturday evening as the 38th edition of this open forum gets under way.

Travelers Adda was started as a unique experience four years ago, where travelers share interesting tales about their experiences on the road and help others finalize their itineraries.

The ‘upgraded’ Travelers Adda format will kick off with an interesting session by a Nagpur couple, Alka and Shirish Rangole, who drove from the Orange City all the way to Cambodia. The odometer of their car bears testimony not just to the thousands of kilometres on the road but also to an enriching experience which involves different cultures.

Well-known entrepreneur Vilas Kale, one of the key people behind Travelers Adda, said, “That’s a couple in their 60s who took to the road for this once-in-a-lifetime experience. I’m sure that the audience will have numerous questions for them about their travel, right from logistics to a review.”

After this interactive event, three simultaneous mini-plenary sessions will start which will help travelers get a 360 degree view of options available. Nana Agashe will talk about quick weekend getaways which are within 200 kms from city during the session called ‘A day’s tour’. This will help many to get to know about destinations that provide a relief from the hectic city life without the hassles of long distance travels.

Kale and Dinesh Naidu will interact with people about offbeat destinations and unique experiences in India and abroad during their session titled ‘Ghumo Jara Hatke’.

With budget being the biggest deciding factor in every travel, Anup Ghumare will talk about popular destinations and budget travels both in India and abroad in his session called ‘Badhiya tour, chhota budget’. Another unique aspect of this edition of ‘Travelers Adda’ will be putting up a vast collection of travel books, periodicals and albums.

“Everyone can browse through these books which are an amazing resource for travel-related information,” said Kale.

The event starts sharp at 5.30pm at ‘Tamarind’ (Chitnavis Centre). Entry is free. For more details, call 9423033340 or 9423033325.

Title: Sebi clears nine current and former NSE executives
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

MUMBAI: Markets regulator Sebi has given clean chit to nine people, including Ravi Narain, former MD of NSE, in a case in which it was alleged that a host of NSE officials had colluded to favour a handful of brokers to make illegal gains using the NSE’s optical fibre network that connected it to its derivatives trading server. Popularly called the NSE’s co-location or co-lo case, there were several allegations of wrongdoing on Narain and other ex-NSE officials including R Nandakumar , senior VP (operations), Jagdish Joshi, co-lo head, and N Muralidharan and Ravi Apte, chief technology officers (CTOs).

A host of serving NSE officials was also named in the case and have been exonerated. They are Mayur Sindhwad, chief operating officer (Trading), Sankarson Banerjee , CTO-Projects, G Shenoy, CTO-Operations and Suprabhat Lala, VP-Regulations.

Sebi in its order said that none of the nine officials was occupying a post of director and/or a key managerial position at NSE during the relevant period, which was between April and July, 2015. “The materials available on record also don’t indicate even remotely, the role of any of the noticees as an employee of NSE in facilitating Sampark Inftainment to establish the (optical fibre) connectivity at NSE,” the regulator said in its order.

In this high-profile case it was alleged that exchange officials had allowed a non-registered service provider, Sampark Infotainment, to lay optic fibre network connectivity between the exchange’s trading room and the servers of a select brokers in such a way that these brokers enjoyed faster speed of trading over all other brokers. In the exchange trading business where very sophisticated computers that use complex algorithms to take advantage of price discrepancies within micro-seconds, such advantages could result into huge profits. The case relates to the allegations of wrongdoing between 2013 and 2015.

It was also alleged that NSE these nine officials did not act in a fair and equitable manner in their dealing with the brokers. A further allegation was that NSE had amended its rules in an opaque manner to allow Sampark Infotainment to provide network services from within its premises despite the company not being registered with it. Sebi didn’t find any evidence in this matter too to proceed against these officials.

Title: Close shave for passengers as bus overshoots railing
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Kanpur: At least 55 passengers had a providential escape when a UPSRTC bus overshot a broken railing on Lower Ram Ganga canal and its rear portion hung precariously over a canal in Rasoolabad area of Kanpur Dehat late Tuesday night.

The bus, which was from Bulandshahr depot, was going to Delhi from Kanpur.

This is the third incident in the state involving a bus in last one week.

Police said the incident took place after the bus driver, Mohan Singh, lost control while giving passage to a truck coming from opposite direction on Rasoolabad-Bilhaur road.

The bus came to a halt after the driver applied the brake but by then the rear portion was hanging in the air. While many passengers moved cautiously towards the front side and got down safely, others rushed out through emergency exit. Some others jumped off the vehicle through the windows.

Police and transport officials reached the spot and pulled out the bus to safety with the help of JCB and cranes. Circle officer, Rasoolabad, Ram Sharan Singh said: “All the bus passengers are safe. Passengers said the bus was within speed limit but driver lost control while trying to avoid collision with the truck. A major tragedy was averted.” Eyewitnesses said had the bus not come to a halt, it could have plunged into the canal, resulting in casualties.

On January 13, At least two persons were killed and 16 others left injured when a UPSRTC bus travelling in dense fog on Agra-Lucknow expressway fell into a ditch.

Earlier on January 10, at least 20 passengers travelling in a private sleeper bus were charred to death in Kannauj district after the bus collided head on with a truck carrying some inflammable material.

The accident took place on the GT Road stretch of Delhi-Kanpur highway when the bus was going to Jaipur from Gursahaiganj in Kannauj.

Title: Delhi’s biggest segment may not be easy to call
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: Matiala assembly constituency has the highest number of electors, so whoever wants to capture that seat needs to appeal to a wide range — from middle- and upper-class voters in Dwarka’s urban setting to the economically lower sections in the over 20 rural communities. The candidate also has to pass muster with the cynical section among voters — the 18-19 year olds, who number the highest here among all assembly seats.In the relatively well-developed localities, issues like 24/7 supply of water and electricity, more green spaces and pothole-free roads are key concerns. Jaswinder Kaur, a resident of Dwarka’s Sector 10, said her power and water bills had come down since 2015, giving her no reason to vote for a change. “I’m happy with the work that is happening in our area. If development continues, why should people complain?” asked Kaur.Surya Prakash, a Sector 11 resident, remarked that with the profusion of housing societies in Dwarka, guaranteed supply of water and electricity was important to voters. “We’ve seen improvements in water and electricity. Not only has there been a reduction in bills, but there are fewer power outages,” said Prakash.The sub-city, however, is not likely to be the deciding factor in an electoral victory because a bigger chunk of voters live in urban and rural villages. Adjacent to Dwarka is Kakrola, a village that is still pushing for development. Its residents look enviously at Dwarka’s posher sectors for ideal infrastructure and development. “People want to see improvements in our area too. Of course, slowly but surely, they are taking place. The progress in government schools is tremendous,” said Rekha Bhatt, a Kakrola housewife.Deeper in the constituency in villages like Ghumanhera, Chhawla and Rewla Khanpur, the landscape changes dramatically. The urban sprawl of Dwarka is replaced by open mustard fields. And the electoral issues too are completely different: employment, sanitation and transport connectivity with the rest of the city.Farmer Bharat Singh sits outside his house in Rewla Khanpur, enjoying the winter sun. The yellow spread of his mustard field is a heartening sight, but he rues the lack of economic opportunities for youngsters. “Working in fields is not lucrative, so it doesn’t tempt the new generation, least of all those who are educated,” said Singh. He said they were inclined to find urban jobs, but pointed out reaching the city was a task for them.The constituency is currently represented by Aam Aadmi Party’s Gulab Singh Yadav, who won comfortably in 2015, leaving BJP’s Rajesh Gahlot and Congress’ Sumesh Shokeen in his wake.AAP government’s attempts to provide better healthcare and education, according to village voters, are appreciated because they did not have easy access to hospitals or medicines in the past.

Title: Uttarkashi: Safety wall of All- Weather Road collapses
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

The administration barricaded the area and started restoration work

UTTARKASHI: A newly constructed concrete security wall of All Weather Road Project collapsed due to rainfall in Chinyalisaur region of Uttarkashi district on Tuesday. The winter rain which damaged the retaining wall, which is built in hills to prevent soil erosion, has also narrowed the width of the Gangotri National highway, which is now posing threat for residents and tourists.

While local residents and activists raised questions over the quality and technical irregularities in the construction of PM Narendra Modi’s pet project, the Uttarkashi district magistrate said that an investigation has been set up to ascertain what went wrong.

District magistrate Ashish Chauhan said that the administration is doing every bit to ensure safety of the people and smooth functioning of the project. “We are not sure how the incident took place but we have set up an inquiry to ascertain who is at fault. The guilty will not be spared. The road is also being repaired at the earliest,” he said.

Sources said that around a 100-metre-long safety wall was recently constructed under the ongoing All Weather Road project on Gangotri National Highway near Raj Rajeshwari temple of Chinyalisaur region. However, a 50-m stretch of the wall collapsed after a recent spell of rainfall. Soon after the incident, the administration barricaded the area and started restoration work.

Uttarkashi-based activist Shoorveer Singh said, “It is surprising that a massive project like this couldn’t even withstand winter rainfall. The climatic conditions of the region are harsher during monsoons, how will the Centre government’s dream project survive then?”

He added that the incident has exposed the carelessness of the government agencies in implementing the project, for which the government is spending a lot.

A local resident also raised questions on the quality and technical irregularities on the construction work. He said, “Due to shoddy work done by some people, lives of several others are now at risk. After barricading, the road has further narrowed down. The government should take immediate action against careless officers to ensure quality of the project.”

Title: Six killed after car falls into gorge near Devprayag in Uttarakhand
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

The car carrying six passengers, including three women, two men and a girl child, was going towards Rudrapraya... Read More

DEHRADUN: Six people were killed after the car they were travelling in plunged into a 200-metre-deep gorge near Saknidhar on Rishikesh-Badrinath National Highway in Tehri district on Thursday morning.

The car carrying six passengers, including three women, two men and a girl child, was going towards Rudraprayag from Rishikesh when the accident took place before Devprayag around 10am, said a police officer.

“All six people inside the car were family members. Prima facie, the person behind the wheels lost control over the vehicle resulting into the accident. However, exact cause of the accident would be ascertained after investigation,” said Mahipal Rawat, in charge of Devprayag police station.

On receiving information, local police along with State Disaster Response Force (SDRF) reached the accident spot and launched search and rescue operation.

According to police, five people died on the spot and their bodies were pulled up by the rescue teams after a five-hour-long operation.

However, one seriously injured woman, identified as Saupa Singh, was taken to community health centre (CHC) Devprayag, from where she was referred to AIIMS Rishikesh. She later succumbed to injuries during treatment at AIIMS. The deceased have been identified as Makaan Singh, 49, Pankaj Singh, 19, Saupa Singh, 42, Phool Devi, 53, Laxmi Devi, 35, and Neha, 15.

Meanwhile, CM Trivendra Singh Rawat expressed grief over the deaths. He also directed the authorities to look into the cause of the accident.

Title: Dehradun: ‘Capture or kill’ order issued for leopard believed to have fed on corpse
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Chief Wildlife Warden of Uttarakhand Rajiv Bhartari on Wednesday gave orders to either capture or kill the leo... Read More

DEHRADUN: Chief Wildlife Warden of Uttarakhand Rajiv Bhartari on Wednesday gave orders to either capture or kill the leopard, which allegedly dug out a corpse from a graveyard in Haridwar and fed on it.

Notably, the same leopard had on October 26 last year attacked a man near Sector-4 of BHEL area. This year, on January 4 and January 10, the big cat had claimed two other lives near Subhash Nagar and Sector- 5 of BHEL area, respectively.

The incident has led to panic among locals, who want the forest department to cull the leopard immediately, even though the officials and scientists have outright denied the possibility of a big cat scavenging for corpses.

“It is just not possible for a leopard to dig out a body and scavenge simply because it doesn’t have any mechanism to dig out the soil. Though this could have been done by a hyena or other carnivore scavenger which is found in Haridwar area in Rajaji reserve,” said Y V Jhala, senior scientist, Wildlife Institute of India.

Meanwhile, the forest department has sent a team for inspection.

“There were pug marks; however, our analysis shows that it may belong to another animal. Also, the ground inspection revealed the presence of a civet in that area, not of a wild cat, as is being rumoured. These are speculations, which everyone should refrain from,” said Haridwar DFO Akash Verma.

Verma said seven cages have been installed in sensitive areas, which include Western Foundry Gate of BHEL, Sector 3 (BHEL), Sector 4 (BHEL), Sector 5 (BHEL) and Ranipur Road.

“Now, shooters from Uttar Pradesh and Uttarakhand are being contacted to either capture or kill the big cat,” he said.

Title: At DU, Medha Patkar lauds students
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Social activist Medha Patkar addresses a protest against CAA/NRC at Delhi University's North Campus

NEW DELHI: Social activist Medha Patkar , at an event held at Delhi University on Thursday, said that NRC and NPR meant National Resistance to Communalism and National People’s Resistance, respectively. She applauded the students and youth for leading the movement against the Citizenship Amendment Act(CAA), National Register of Citizens (NRC) and National Population Register (NPR).

“Now, the government is scared of you as you are fighting on the principles of the Constitution. What is happening in the country is not about one law. Now, it has transformed into people’s resistance. So NPR is actually National People’s Resistance and NRC National Resistance to Communalism,” said Patkar. She reiterated that documents should not be shown when officials come for collecting NPR data.

At the event held by “Gandhi Calling” organisation, Tushar Gandhi, lawyer Karuna Nundy and others also addressed the students who had gathered in large numbers at the arts faculty. Mahatma Gandhi’s great grandson Tushar Gandhi told the students that they should be ready to sacrifice in this fight. “Now, you cannot stop. This is the second fight for freedom and in the process you have to give a lot of sacrifices,” said Gandhi.

Lawyer Karuna Nundy explained the legal provisions of CAA/NRC/NPR and said the fight should go on till the act is repealed. “NPR, as being claimed, is not just like another census. For the first time, they are going to ask where your parents were born and if you are a citizen of the country. Also CAA does not mean that citizenship for Hindus will be fast-tracked,” said Nundy who later read the Preamble, along with the students.

Title: Nagpur: Teen playing video game on tracks run over
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: Ruhi Belekar (15), a student of Std IX, was run over by Nagpur-bound Ramtek local train at Tekdi in Kanhan on Wednesday. She was playing video game on mobile phone with a male friend on the tracks.

Sources in the police said Ruhi and her friend had plugged in headphones and were engaged in the video game. The loco-pilot repeatedly honked from distance seeing the duo on the track.

As the train came closer, though her friend managed to flee at the last moment, Ruhi slipped on the blast pebbles. She was hit by the train which resulted in multiple injuries on head and body, leaving her dead on the spot. A case of accidental death has been registered at Kanhan police station.

Title: Kanpur: Ganesh Shankar Vidyarthi memorial student accuses professor of molestation
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

Title: Maharashtra: Two sloth bears found dead in a farm well
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

YAVATMAL: Two sloth bears were found dead in a farm well in Nandgaon village of Mohgaon tehsil in Yavatmal on Thursday morning. One Shivaji Sabhaji Adangale of Kottari village of Mohgaon owns the farm.

Forest officials fished out the bodies. Officials Amol Thorat and Hemant Ubale accompanied by veterinary doctor Yogendra Yavatikar conducted panchnama and sent the bodies for post mortem. The bears might have fallen in the well accidentally, said Ubale.

The village is adjoining a thick forest and bears move freely in the area. Bears have attacked farmers on several occasions in the past.

Title: Boy held upside down, case against teachers
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Kozhikode: A case was registered against a teacher and principal of a private school in Wayanad for punishing a a Class IV student by holding him upside down.

The incident occurred at Amrita Vidyalayam, Mananthavady .

The teacher was charged for allegedly holding the boy upside down—a punishment for playing on the school verandah, police said, adding that the principal was charged for reportedly trying to hush up the incident.

The case was registered after the child’s father lodged a complaint based on a court directive.

Police said the case was registered under Section 75 of the Juvenile Justice Act (Punishment for cruelty to child). The school authorities termed the punishment an exercise for hyper-active students. TNN

Title: NSI develops Natural Sugarcane Spread for use in place of jams, jellies
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Kanpur: National Sugar Institute (NSI) has successfully developed 'Natural Sugarcane Spread' which can be used in place of commercially available jams and jellies. From 100 kg of sugarcane, about 15-16 kg of ‘Natural Sugarcane Spread’ can be produced. Also, it is economically viable as the product will cost Rs 27-28 per kg only.

This feat could be achieved after two years of continuous efforts. The sugar technology division of NSI has developed this product that can be made in different flavors.

Detailing about the product, director, NSI, Prof. Narendra Mohan, said that the product made is natural in which no chemical is used for juice clarification and preservation.

“The basic process involves dual filtration, including a high degree of filtration using membrane filters, clarification of cane juice using vegetable mucilage’s and skimmed milk etc. About 80-85% of the water present in the juice is removed by carrying out evaporation at reduced pressure. Thus, the product is natural and besides sucrose, contains carbohydrates, vitamins, glucose, fructose, proteins, fats and minerals originally present in cane juice with no added sugar”, Prof Mohan explained.

He said Natural Sugar Spread can be made in various flavors--chocolate, ginger, cardamom, mint and lemon, using natural extracts depending upon the consumer choice and preferences.

“It can thus be termed as a real natural nutritious health product also. Even without adding any preservative, the shelf life of the product is estimated to be one year which can be extended further by adopting superior packaging techniques”, the NSI director informed.

As regards economics, from 100 kg of sugarcane, about 15-16 kgs of ‘Natural Sugarcane Spread’ can be produced and thus considering the present sugarcane prices, the estimated cost of the product will be about Rs. 27-28 per kg only, he added.

Keeping in view the surplus sugar production which has kept the sugar prices depressed and looking to the growing market of such natural and chemical-free products, this can be a value-added product for the Indian sugar factories, Prof Mohan added.

The institute has already received preliminary inquiries for technical know-how from many firms, he said.

He further said that the National Sugar Institute is committed to developing value-added products in sugar factories so as to enhance its revenue pot for achieving economic sustainability.

Keeping this in view and to train the sugar factory personnel, the institute earlier established a ‘Special Sugar Division’ and is now in the process of setting up a 10 tons per day refined sugar unit.

Title: 4-year-old girl raped, accused held
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Kanpur:A four-year-old girl was allegedly raped by a local under the limits of Kotwali police station in Banda district on Tuesday. The incident came to light after police registered an FIR on Wednesday.

The accused, 26-year-old Jagdeo Kushwaha, lured the girl over some pretext, took her to an orchard and allegedly raped her, police said. The survivor, hailing from Madhya Pradesh’s Chhatarpur district, had come to her relatives place in Banda on Tuesday. The accused stays in the neighbourhood of her relative.

“Following complaint by the girl’s family, the man has been booked under sections 376, 504, 506 of the Indian Penal Code and Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act. He has been arrested. The girl’s medical has been conducted, report of which is awaited,” said Inspector Dinesh Singh.

Title: Man kills wife, drowns while disposing of body in Chitrakoot
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Jhansi: A 32-year-old man is presumed drowned while trying to dispose of the body of his wife in Barua dam in Chitrakoot district after murdering her on January 14 night. Police recovered the body of the 28-year-old woman on Thursday, while the man is still untraceable.

Police said the man, Bharat Diwakar, was a local SP leader and used to take contract of fishing in Barua dam. On Tuesday night he had gone to attend a function along with his wife Namita at his parental village Dahini, but both went missing mysteriously.

When the matter was reported to the police, they interrogated their driver Ramsewak Nishad, who also worked in Diwakar’s fisheries. Spilling the beans, Ramsewak told police that Diwakar had killed Namita on Tuesday night and took her body to the dam to dispose it. Ramsewak said he helped Diwakar stuff the woman’s body in a sack and tied it with a bolder so that it drowned.

They took the body in the middle of the dam in a boat to dump, but the boat capsized. While Ramsewak swam to safety, Diwakar drowned, claimed police.

After a hectic search, SDRF recovered the body of Namita on Thursday, while Diwakar is still untraceable. Police have also recovered the abandoned SUV of Diwakar parked near the dam along with the slippers of the woman.

SP Chitrakoot Ankit Mittal said a case has been lodged against Diwakar under Section 302 of IPC at Bharatkoop police station on the application of Namita’s parents while Ramsewak is being interrogated to confirm his role in the crime.

“We are trying to recover Diwakar’s body and gather more facts. We have sent the body of the woman for postmortem examination to find out the cause of the death. We are also examining the role of Ramsewak after which any action will be taken,” he added.

Title: Private firm employees protest over pending dues
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Hundreds of Videocon employees and their supporters on Thursday took out a morcha

AURANGABAD: Hundreds of employees of a large private sector firm and their supporters on Thursday took out a morcha to the divisional commissionerate demanding the government to make the company pay their dues which have been pending since the past year.

“Our hunger strike has completed 150 days; still the authorities have not intervened. To draw their attention, we took out a morcha to the divisional commissioner’s office,” said their legal advisor Abhay Taksal.

Employees’ union president Gajanan Khandare and Taksal alleged that the authorities have deliberately ignored their hunger strike. “The morcha today was meant to draw attention of the people toward the injustice meted out to the 340 workers, who have resorted to strike in front of the office of the deputy commissioner of labour,” they said.

Earlier, they said the workers resorted to ‘bheek mango’ (seeking alms) agitation and sent Rs 721 to the company owners. The workers have also sent a memorandum to the chief minister Uddhav Thackeray on December 12, 2019, but to no avail, Khandare and Taksal said.

They said they had sought time of the chief minister during his recent visit to the city to voice their grievances. But they did not get an appointment. They said that the government should consider their situation.

Title: Kerala: ‘Ordinance on burial in Christian cemeteries will create problems’
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representational image

KOTTAYAM: The heads of the Orthodox Church have said that the Ordinance promulgated by Kerala government regarding the burial of bodies at the Christian cemeteries would not stand legal scrutiny and will create complications.

Addressing a press conference on Thursday, they said that though the chief minister said that it was being promulgated in the aftermath of the disputes between the Orthodox and Jacobite Churches, after it came out, it has proved to have implications for all Church denominations.

They alleged that the Ordinance is a ploy by the government to circumvent the contempt of court petition filed by the Orthodox Church in the Supreme Court which alleged that court granted rights are not enforced by the government. The Church also expressed its eagerness to know the views of other Christian denominations on the issue.

They said that crystal clear definitions have not been given to several clauses of the Ordinance. The first clause says if a parishioner dies he is qualified to be buried in the cemetery of the church belonging to his parish where his ancestors were buried. However, no definition has been given as to who is an ancestor. “It hasn’t clearly said an ancestor pertains up to which generations? It has not been clearly said who is the authority to establish that one belongs to particular parish and his ancestors were buried in the cemetery of that parish,” said the leaders.

Yuhanon Mar Dioscoros Metropolitan, Orthodox Church spokesperson Johns Abraham Konat and MOSC association secretary advocate Biju Oommen were present at the press conference.

Title: Probe DavinderSingh’s links to Parliament attack, Pulwama: CM Kamal Nath
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Kamal Nath

BHOPAL: Madhya Pradesh chief minister Kamal Nath has demanded a thorough investigation into the 2001 Parliament attack and last year’s Pulwama blast in the light of the arrest of J&K DSP Davinder Singh along with terrorists.

“DSP Davinder Singh, posted in Jammu and Kashmir, was caught allegedly with terrorists. His suspected role in Parliament attack and Pulwama incident has also been revealed. This is a case of a sheer intelligence failure. Many questions are being raised. It should be thoroughly investigated,” CM Nath tweeted on Thursday.

On Wednesday, former Union minister Uma Bharati had said: “We have exposed Davinder’s links with Afzal Guru. Now, it’s for investigators to find out who else he is connected to.”

Davinder was arrested on Saturday in south Kashmir when he was allegedly ferrying three militants, including Hizbul Mujahideen commander Syed Naveed Mushtaq alias Baby, in a car. BJP and Congress have engaged in a verbal duel over Davinder’s alleged terror links, blaming each other for negligence and laxity in security and investigation.

Title: Delhi: Failed robbery led to murder, two held
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Usha Gupta (inset) was waiting for her husband in the car when the men spotted her

NEW DELHI: Police have solved the murder case of an elderly woman, who was shot dead in her car near Patparganj, with the arrest of two robbers from outer Delhi.

The accused — Mohmmad Mazhar and Mohammad Kamrul — who were involved in a spate of robberies in Narela Industrial Area, told cops after their arrest that they had murdered the woman in a bid to snatch her phone and gold chain on September 21, last year.

Mazhar and Kamrul were caught from their residence in Usmanpur. During questioning, Mazhar said that Kamrul was his brother-in-law. Cops are also looking for their third associate. Kamrul was arrested several times earlier also for stalking college students and women at bus stops.

DCP (outer-north) Gaurav Sharma said that efforts to track down the robbers were intensified after they were found using black bikes during the robberies. During questioning Mazhar told cops that both he and Kamrul were fascinated with the new model of the motorbike and would target two-wheeler riders on empty stretches and rob their bikes.

On September 21, they spotted Usha Gupta sitting in her car and decided to rob her. Mazhar parked the bike behind the car and walked up to the driver’s side and started hitting at the car window to break it. When Gupta tried to drive away, Mazhar chased her and shot at her from the window. All this time Kamrul was waiting for him on the bike.

A CCTV footage showed him running back to the bike and the accused speeding off. Police said that they always used helmets during the crimes to ensure they were not caught by traffic police while fleeing or their faces were not identified.

Recently the duo stole a bike from the JJ colony in Bawana and robbed a man near Laxmi Nagar, but while fleeing their bike was hit by a car. They then left the bike at the spot and fled. Two months back they had robbed another man near Pandav Nagar, but few cops spotted them during which Mazhar again abandoned the bike and jumped over rooftops to escape.

Sharma said that a team from Madhu Vihar police station had already informed them about Mazhar’s identity while probing the murder case. It was found that Mazhar and Kamrul were school dropouts and drug addicts.

Title: Kochi: Soon, genome sequencing of Indian oil sardine
Content:
The whole genome sequencing will help researchers understand sardine behavior

KOCHI: The whole genome sequencing (WGS) of the Indian oil sardine is likely to be released this year by the Central Marine Fisheries Research Institute (CMFRI). This will help researchers understand sardine behavior, which is probably leading to falling marine stock or collapse of the fisheries in some areas. The fall in sardine production has affected the overall marine production in most coastal states.According to the CMFRI researchers, the genome sequence is almost 80% complete and has already revealed several distinct characteristics of this commercially important fish which impacts fish production in the country. As the WGS is a process of determining the complete DNA sequence of an organism’s genome at a single time, the DNA markers have already revealed three distinct sub-populations of Indian oil sardine in the Indian ocean region — Gulf of Oman, northwest coast of India and other coasts mainly southwest and southeast coast of India.“The CMFRI will release a draft sequence of genome of Indian oil sardine soon. Even though the CMFRI has found that three types of sardines including Oman sardine have the same genetic structure, separate management strategies are required for these sardines as they live in different waters,” said A Gopalakrishnan, director, CMFRI.The Indian oil sardine fishery is characterized by large annual fluctuations and significant variability in reproduction. The reduction in stock complexity and genetic diversity will affect the resilience of fish stocks and their capacity to recover from extreme reduction in population size due to climatic or environmental effects. Considering these factors, fish stocks should be managed on a regional scale by assessing the number of spawning components and behavioral groups so that stock complexity is preserved and maintained.“Our analysis revealed a population explosion of this species during the Pleistocene Epoch, due to the emergence of upwelling events in the Indian Ocean. In the future, if climate change brings about changes on current patterns and upwelling events, it will affect the abundance and dynamics of Indian oil sardines. Genetic and genomic tools will also provide clues to local adaptations to environmental conditions which are also important in conservation and management of these resources,” said Sandhya Sukumaran, senior scientist, Marine Biotechnology division, CMFRI.

Title: 11 lakh suggestions from Delhiites for election manifesto: Manoj Tiwari
Content:
Manoj Tiwari

NEW DELHI: Delhi BJP chief Manoj Tiwari said his party had received over 11 lakh suggestions from across the city during the Meri Dilli, Mera Sujhav (My Delhi, My Suggestion) campaign, which would be kept in mind while finalising the election manifesto for the upcoming state polls.Addressing a press conference on Thursday, Tiwari said BJP had sought the views of Delhiites on what they think should be the party’s priority after forming government in the capital, and the suggestions received were overwhelming. “The views of the residents of Delhi clearly indicate that they are not happy with the condition of roads, supply of contaminated water, unemployment, and vacancies of teachers and principals in state-run schools,” he said.“We received 11,65,636 suggestions from Delhiites where they have shared their concerns. Several people told us that after two hours of rains, the roads get waterlogged. Pollution is another major issue. Unemployment and vacancies of teachers and principals were prominently mentioned. People of Delhi are in pain,” the Delhi BJP chief said. The press conference was also attended by Rajya Sabha member Vijay Goel and New Delhi MP Meenakshi Lekhi.“Our teams are compiling the suggestions. We will draft a timeline to work on the each of them,” he added.Tiwari said that BJP volunteers also collected suggestions from people by directly placing ‘drop boxes’ at over 2,000 places in the city. He said that party volunteers also interacted with over 3.5 lakh respondents and encouraged them to submit feedbacks.Around 49 customised vans, equipped with digital screens, were sent to all assembly constituencies and major commercial centres, universities and other public places to collect the views of Delhiites.

This story is from January 17, 2020

Manoj Tiwari

NEW DELHI: Delhi BJP chief Manoj Tiwari said his party had received over 11 lakh suggestions from across the city during the Meri Dilli, Mera Sujhav (My Delhi, My Suggestion) campaign, which would be kept in mind while finalising the election manifesto for the upcoming state polls.

Addressing a press conference on Thursday, Tiwari said BJP had sought the views of Delhiites on what they think should be the party’s priority after forming government in the capital, and the suggestions received were overwhelming. “The views of the residents of Delhi clearly indicate that they are not happy with the condition of roads, supply of contaminated water, unemployment, and vacancies of teachers and principals in state-run schools,” he said.

“We received 11,65,636 suggestions from Delhiites where they have shared their concerns. Several people told us that after two hours of rains, the roads get waterlogged. Pollution is another major issue. Unemployment and vacancies of teachers and principals were prominently mentioned. People of Delhi are in pain,” the Delhi BJP chief said. The press conference was also attended by Rajya Sabha member Vijay Goel and New Delhi MP Meenakshi Lekhi.

Title: Junctions turn into a traffic nightmare
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Kozhikode: The unscientific traffic movement at small junctions on the national highways and other roads in the city are turning these junctions into problem zones.

Unsignalized and unmanned junctions have become accident-prone zones with the increased flow of vehicles.

Successive and unsignalized intersections are causing traffic blocks along the national highway stretches in the city limit. The shortage of manpower in the police also makes it impossible to deploy personnel at every junction.

Absence of warning boards and signals regarding the presence of junctions is a major problem for long-distance vehicles, said Rakesh Mohan, a motorist. The motorists plying on the NH fail to detect the presence of arterial roads and the chances for accidents are high, he added.

The junction on the Puthiyangadi-Kunduparama road connecting to Karaparamba Road, the Puthiyangadi Junction , Chakorathukulam Junction , Vandippetta Junction on NH 766 , East Hill Junction, and YMCA Junction are a few such unmanned junctions which have become traffic bottle necks owing to unscientific movement of vehicles.

Absence of medians and traffic circles and the absence of walkable pathways are also causing difficulties to motorists and pedestrians at such junctions. Inadequate visibility of the intersection, high speed of the vehicles, increased volume, presence of bus stops and auto rickshaw stands at the junctions also increases the chances for accident.

The widening of the road, installation of traffic signals or the appointment of police personnel to control the movement of vehicles are ways to tackle the issue. A number of minor accidents involving two-wheelers and other vehicles were reported on the West Hill Engineering college junction, Barracks Junction and other junctions.

The Puthiyangadi Junction, Kunduparamba Junction and other small junctions are also prone to accidents. Speeding of two-wheelers and other motorists is considered the key reason for the accidents.

Besides, the diversion of traffic through arterial roads and small junctions during road repair work and during the visits of VIPs also cause trouble to public. The use of connecting roads by heavy vehicles including school buses and private buses during congestions worsens the situation as they take extra time to move though the small junctions.

The police cannot appoint cops at each junction as we do not have sufficient manpower, said a senior official. However, we deploy personnel at all junctions when we impose any traffic diversion and the chances for congestion are high, the official added.

Title: Former airline staffer held for fraud
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: A 31-year-old man, who worked as a cabin crew earlier, was arrested for trying to dupe people on the pretext of job openings in an airline.

Accused Sanket Jha , who hailed from Maharashtra, posted a message informing job aspirants about the launch of ‘ Yo Airlines ’ in Thailand . He asked interested candidates to send their applications for the job of cabin crew.

Police said that Jha posted an advertisement on Instagram about the vacancies. He had also posted a link asking the candidates to fill in their details and apply. On Wednesday, he called candidates for an interview at a hotel near Bangla Sahib Gurudwara. Jha was a BCom graduate and worked as a cabin crew with an airline for four years.

Officers said that around 300 candidates appeared for the interview, during which Jha asked them to deposit around Rs 2.5 lakh for confirmation of job. One of the women candidates then became suspicious and called police.

A case of cheating was registered and two women, who were also present with the accused, have been served notice to join the investigation.
