Title: Bhopal cops make helmetless riders write ‘why I don’t’ essays
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Cops & riders during the drive

Bhopal: After hearing far too many imaginative excuses from helmetless bikers, Bhopal police are getting them to put their creativity to better use: write 100-word essays on ‘why I don’t wear a helmet’.

For some, putting 100 words to paper is proving to be a tougher punishment than a Rs 100 fine. Those who write, and write well, stand to get a prize. No prizes for guessing it — a helmet.

“People make ridiculous excuses when they are caught driving without helmet. So, why not ask them to write it,” SI Vivek Gour, who was deployed at Roshanpura Square for the essay writing event on Thursday, told TOI.

Title: Burglars steal 41kg of silver jewellery from two stores
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Pune: A gang of burglars broke into two jewellery stores in Wakad and made off with 41kg of silver ornaments and 100gm of gold jewellery, totally worth Rs21.55 lakh, in the early hours of Thursday.

The burglaries happened between 3am and 5am. Pravin Devkar (36), who owns Kanak Jewellers in Kaspte Vasti, and Manohar Chuahan (30), owner of Ambika Jewellers in Rahatni, have lodged complaints with the Wakad police.

The burglars stole 35kg of silver ornaments, the gold and a little cash from Kanak Jewellers. They stole 6kg of silver from Ambika Jewellers.

Devkar told TOI that he was informed at 7am that his store’s shutter was broken. “I reached there and found that they broke the central lock and gained entry,” Devkar said. He said he had installed CCTV cameras in his store. “They stole the DVR and also changed the angle of a CCTV camera of an eatery near my shop,” he said. The complex’s security guards found nothing suspicious at the store during their rounds, around 3am, he said.

Police suspect that the burglars, after the theft at Kanak Jewellers, might have broken into the other store — the lock of the shutter was broken and a safety grill was cut, an officer said. The burglary was discovered around 8am, when a neighbouring shop owner alerted Chauhan, police said.

Assistant inspector Harish Mane said they have dispatched teams to trace the burglars. “We are also checking CCTV footage,” Mane said. Sub-inspector R S Mudal is investigating the case.

Title: 3 electricity sub-stations commissioned
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Kannur: Minister for electricity M M Mani has said the power deficiency in the district would be solved very soon with the commissioning of the new sub stations.

Inaugurating the newly upgraded 110kV substation and the 110kV double circuit line connecting Sreekantapuram and Vellaparamba at Sreekantapuram in the district on Thursday, he said the government had promised there would be total electrification and there would not be any power cut. Both these promises have been kept and many new projects are coming up in the power distribution sector, he said. The capacity of the earlier substation there was 66kV.

The Rs 4,000-crore project, Dhyuthi, to ensure that there is no power failure, has been started and also the Rs 10,000-crore trans-grid project which would double the transmission and distribution system in the state has begun, he said.

“All these projects would be implemented in a phased manner and once completed the power transmission in the state can be flawlessly managed for the next 50 years,” he said.

In response to the demand mooted by MLA K C Joseph who presided over the function, the minister said the government is ready to open a Vydyuthi Bhavan in the district if a proper place is made available.

The works of the existing hydroelectrical projects are being completed and there is a plan to have a second power station in Idukki, he said. At the same time, solar power has more potential in future and the target is to produce 1,000MW electricity using solar power, said the minister. Out of this, 500MW will be rpoduced using rooftop solar panels while the remaining 500MW would be produced by installing solar panels at the dam sites. As of now the state produces 200MV using solar power and the efforts in this direction are a model for the nation, he said.

Talking about total electrification in the state, the minister said the electrification is remaining in only those places where there is obstacle due to forest. At Edamalakkudy in Wayanad, electricity was provided after installing 35km-long cable, he said.

The minister also commissioned the substations at Kelakam, Nedumpoyil and Vasliyavelicham, all in the hilly areas of the district. Out of this, the one at Nedumpoyil has been upgraded from 66kV to 110kV.

Title: Fog in Delhi: Cloudy and foggy Friday morning in Delhi-NCR
Content:
Morning visuals from Rajpath (ANI photo)

Foggy conditions reported in parts of #Delhi after a spell of drizzle early on Friday #DelhiWeather https://t.co/kdRqqUtOLg — TOI Delhi (@TOIDelhi) 1579233609000

NEW DELHI: After light rain and hailstorm struck parts of the capital on Thursday, the National Capital Region witnessed partly cloudy sky and moderate-to-dense fog on Friday morning.From 8.30am to 5.30pm, Safdurjung recorded 4mm, Palam 0.8mm, Ridge 2.8mm, Ayanagar 1.7mm and Najafgarh 1mm rain. At 6.4mm, Lodhi Road saw the maximum rain. According to IMD, a western disturbance as a cyclonic circulation way lying over central Pakistan and the neighbourhood, bringing scattered rain to north and parts of central India.Track the pollution level in your cityAt 9.5 degrees Celsius, the minimum temperature in Delhi settled two notches above normal while the maximum was 16.4, three notches below normal, a Met official said. On Friday, the maximum and minimum temperatures will be around 17 and 8 degrees Celsius, respectively. Very light rain may be witnessed in isolated parts of the city.The air quality deteriorated slightly with the air quality index (AQI) touching 281 in the ‘poor’ category against Wednesday’s 218 in the same category. According to SAFAR, a central forecast body, an improvement in the air quality to the moderate-to-lower end of the ‘poor’ category is expected by Friday. AQI is likely to be at the higher end of the category on Saturday.

Title: MBA admission fraud rocks Pune University, 4 pupils booked
Content:
Savitribai Phule Pune University

PUNE: Four students from Jharkhand and Bihar, three of them women, were booked by the Chatushrungi police on Thursday for securing admission to the MBA 2018-19 course at Savitribai Phule Pune University ’s department of management sciences by furnishing forged mark sheets of the AIMS Test for Management Admission.The test is a recognised national entrance exam for management studies.Three of the booked students are from Jamshedpur and Singhbhum districts in Jharkhand and one is from Gaya district in Bihar. Surabhi Jain, head of the university’s department of management sciences, lodged an FIR against them on Wednesday.The police invoked IPC sections 420 (cheating), 465 (forgery), 467 (forgery of valuable security), 468 (forgery for purpose of cheating), 471 (using a forgery as genuine) and 34 (common intention) of Indian Penal Code.The four students were granted provisional admission through the Centralised Admission Process conducted by the state Directorate of Technical Education (DTE), the university’s registrar Prafulla Pawar said.“They appeared for the test and the DTE officials had normalized their scores with the state common entrance test (MH-CET) for allotment of seats on merit. Their names figured in the list of students to be admitted to our department of management sciences. We admitted them since the allotment list came from the DTE,” Pawar added.The directorate recently instructed them to cancel the admission of these four students after their verification process for confirmation of admissions revealed the forgery. “We have since acted on the instruction by cancelling their admissions and have also reported the matter to the police,” Pawar added.The students, who completed over a year of their MBA studies at the SPPU, have returned to their native places post-cancellation of their admission, but face police action.“We have sought all the relevant papers from the university, the directorate and the test authorities as part of our evidence collection process before taking a call on arresting the students,” senior inspector Anil Shewale of the Chatushrungi police told TOI.The DTE found discrepancies in the test scores and the score sheets the students had submitted. A further inquiry led to the detection of forgery.

Title: CP hopeful about Nagpur getting rid of ‘Crime Capital’ tag
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

The CP feels that the data of State Crime Records Bureau (SCRB), which is generally released after the NCRB da... Read More

NAGPUR: The low rank of Nagpur among cities having offences per one lakh population, as per the statistics released by the National Crime Records Bureau ( NCRB ) for 2018, has made the police chief BK Upadhyay hopeful about seeing the city finally getting rid of its ‘ Crime Capital ’ tag.

The CP feels that the data of State Crime Records Bureau (SCRB), which is generally released after the NCRB data, for the year 2018 will bring cheers for the city. He feels that with crimes going down, the city would be at least out of the top five.

At a recent press conference, CP had stated that in 2019 the crime rate reduced by 10% as compared to the previous year.

In the NCRB data for 2016 the city was on the second spot in the country in terms of crime rate. It ranked seventh in the statistics of the following year. The city since then has been dubbed as the ‘Crime Capital’, especially to corner former chief minister Devendra Fadnavis who also held the home portfolio then.

Upadhyay said, “In 2016, Nagpur was third in the state as per the SCRB data in crime rate after Amravati and Aurangabad. In the last two years, the number of crimes has gone down by 2,000-2,500 as compared to 2016, which means Nagpur would be comfortably down to either 6th or 7th position or even lower.”

The CP said that showing the city in bad light by calling it ‘Crime Capital’ would be unfair. “Nagpur should be projected as ‘Safe City’ which is a statistically proven fact now,” he said.

Title: Pune: Youth suffers burns in bid to steal copper rod from power substation, dies
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

A police officer inspects the substation in Ambegaon taluka

PUNE: A 20-year-old youth’s bid to steal copper rod from a power substation in Ambegaon taluka, about 65km from the city, cost him his life on Wednesday.

The youth, Pavan Kadale, suffered 70% burns while trying to remove a copper rod from a live isolator at the Maharashtra State Electricity Transmission Company Limited (MSETCL) substation at Pimpalgaon Khadki on Wednesday morning. He succumbed to injuries at the Sassoon General Hospital late in the night.

Devendra Patil, the deputy executive engineer at the MSETCL substation in Pimpalgaon Khadki, lodged an FIR with the Manchar police. He explained, “Isolators transmit power, while the copper rods are used for earthing.”

The tragedy came to light after technicians working at the substation heard a loud noise and rushed out. They saw a youth lying on the ground with burn injuries. “The technicians immediately alerted police and Patil,” the Manchar police said.

Police, after investigations, said the youth and his accomplices could have scaled the wall of the substation to enter its premises after cutting the barbed wire fence. “The substation is secured with a compound wall and a barbed wire fencing. The entrance has 24X7 security and the MSETCL technicians also stay at the substation round the clock,” Patil said.

The Manchar police said the group managed to remove 23 copper rods from three different supply lines when the power was shut. “The youth suffered burns when he tried to remove a copper rod from a live isolator,” the police said.

His accomplices left him injured at spot and fled with 23 copper rods, collectively worth Rs75,000, the police said.

The police took the suspect to a nearby hospital. “He had suffered 70% burns and was shifted to the Sassoon General Hospital in Pune. He had initially given us a fake name to avoid any trouble. When we recorded his statement at the hospital, he revealed his actual identity. He also claimed that he had come alone to the substation,” an officer of the Manchar police said.

The MSETCL’s deputy executive engineer, Patil, said the number of missing copper rods indicated that more people were involved in the theft.

The police have registered an offence under the relevant sections of the Indian Electricity Act. A police team led by inspector Krishnadev Kharade has launched a search for the remaining suspect/s.

Title: Meerut’s mentally handicapped teen rescued from Bareilly railway station
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Bareilly: A 17-year-old mentally handicapped and injured youth was on Thursday rescued by government railway police (GRP) from Bareilly Junction. When asked if the youth was a victim of child trafficking, sub inspector of GRP Ashok Kumar, who had rescued the youth, said, “It was not such a case. The boy couldn’t tell much about his family, except his name which was Amit. He is a resident of Meerut.” The GRP informed the child-line which admitted him at district hospital since the youth had a big cut in his stomach.

Shailesh Sharma, director of an NGO, said, “On getting information, we reached the station and took him to hospital. The boy told us that he had undergone a surgery a few days ago after he met an accident in Meerut. The stitches on stomach were broken.”

Meanwhile, chief medical superintendent of district hospital Dr TS Arya told TOI, “The boy has severely been infected of septicaemia. We have provided him treatment and will carry out an ultrasound tomorrow to investigate his internal condition.”

Title: Man flees with Rs 9 lakh valuables from late employer’s flat in Pune, held
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The Alankar police on Wednesday arrested a 43-year-old man for stealing gold and cash worth Rs9.40 lakh from the home of his late employer in Karvenagar on January 13.

According to the complaint, the suspect stole 300gm of gold biscuits and Rs1.90 lakh. The police said they have recovered the gold biscuits.

Police said the suspect had been employed as an assistant by Satyen Dobhada, a urologist, who died in an accident in June 2018.

Dobhada’s wife Leena (44) lodged an FIR with the police on Wednesday, alleging that the valuables were stolen from her flat. A team of police investigated and arrested Kamble from Kothrud. “We have recovered gold biscuits from the suspect. We are yet to recover the cash,” a police officer said.

According to the complaint, Leena, a medical practitioner, left her flat at 2pm on January 13. When she returned three hours later, she found the locks of the main door and the safety door broken. “She found Rs1.90 lakh and the gold biscuits missing from the cupboard,” the officer said.

After receiving her complaint, a couple of police constables began collecting information about possible suspects. “We got a tip-off about Kamble’s involvement and took him into custody for questioning,” the officer said.

Under sustained questioning, Kamble admitted to stealing the valuables.

Police said Kamble had worked for Dobhada as an assistant. In June 2018, Dobhada — on his way to Lonand, Satara, to perform surgeries, was killed after his car had collided with a van at Nira on Pune-Pandharpur road. Two others died in the accident, while Kamble and the driver escaped with their lives.

Since Kamble had proven trustworthy, Leena started taking his help with odd jobs. “The suspect took advantage of it and committed the burglary,” the officer said.

Title: Hours after wedding, bride killed in accident; groom, four others critical
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Bareilly: Hours after her wedding, 20-year-old bride Shivani was killed when the car she was travelling in with her groom Manoj Kumar and four others crashed into a roadside tree on Agra-Moradabad highway in Sambhal district on Thursday. Manoj and four others, including two women and a child, sustained critical injuries.

A resident of Hisavati village in Bulandshahr district, Manoj tied in a nuptial knot with Shivani, a resident of Chungi Mohalla locality in Chandausi, on Wednesday. After the rituals, the newlywed couple left for Bulandshahr around 7am on Thursday. When the car reached near Bhagatji International School in Behjoi, the driver lost control over the vehicle and crashed into a roadside tree.

Upon hearing their screams, farmers working in nearby fields rushed to the spot and rescued them. They had to chop off the tree to pull out the passengers from the mangled car and informed police.

Police shifted the injured — Manoj and his sisters-in-law Madhu and Neeraj and Madhu’s son Prince, and driver Deepak — to a community health centre, where doctors referred them to a higher medical facility in Moradabad.

Behjoi station house officer inspector Ravindra Pratap Singh said they informed families of the injured and sent the body for postmortem.

Title: New technology may make angioplasty easier, safer
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: For patients with a blocked artery , involving heavily calcified blood vessels, a new technology introduced in India recently promises to make angioplasty much easier. It involves ablating the calcium deposition in the artery using sonic waves before putting a stent for improved blood flow.

Having calcified artery causing blockage is seen in about 10% to 15% of patients, especially those who are elderly and diabetic, say doctors.

According to Dr Ashok Seth, chairman, Fortis Escorts Heart Institute, in such patients it becomes difficult to open these blockages and implant stents.

“Intravascular Lithotripsy generates sonic pressure waves to break up problematic calcium so that artery can be opened with ease and blood flow restored with the placement of a stent. The therapy leverages a minimally invasive approach that has been embraced by physicians for decades to treat kidney stones,” he said.

Dr Seth and his team performed the first case in the country on a 67-year-old man with heavily calcified artery. Dr Praveen Chandra, chairman, interventional cardiology at Medanta – The Medicity, Gurgaon, said that they also performed a case using the new technology last week. “Earlier, we had to drill into the artery using special equipment to remove the calcium deposition. It was risky,” he said.

Intravascular Lithotripsy uses a small generator to produce therapeutic sonic pressure waves from a catheter that is threaded through the arterial system to the site of the blockage. The pressure waves pass through the soft vascular tissue, preferentially disrupting the hardened calcified plaque inside the arterial wall by creating a series of micro-fractures, said Gurmit Singh Chugh, CEO, Translumina, partners of Shockwave Medical for India.

Title: Retail traders’ stir aims at e-commerce companies
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Pune: The Pune District Retail Traders’ Association recently organized a protest against online e-commerce firms as part of the nationwide protest held by the Confederation of All India Traders (CAIT) opposing the visit of a leading e-commerce firm’s chief executive officer to India.

Sachin Nivangune, president of the association and CAIT Maharashtra secretary said that the protest was organized in several areas, including Kothrud, Sinhagad Road, Shivajinagar, Sadashiv Peth, Wagholi, Bibvewadi, Karvenagar and Balewadi, among others.

“CAIT has been spearheading an aggressive nationwide movement against e-commerce firms and we support it fully. The Competition Commission of India (CCI) on a petition filed by Delhi Vyapar Mahasangh has also ordered DG Enforcement of CCI to investigate the business module of two popular e-commerce firms and investigate the allegations of predatory pricing, deep discounting, loss funding, exclusivity, preferential seller treatment and influencing prices,” said Nivangune.

He added that CAIT will continue its nationwide agitation against such e-commerce players and the action taken by Pune retailers would be based on the decision taken by the confederation. “We have a straightforward agenda that these firms should comply with FDI policy both in letter and spirit or they have to leave India,” he said.

Title: Robbery on Parvati hill: Cops apprehend suspect
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Pune: Officers from the Dattawadi police station on Wednesday arrested a 19-year-old man from Janata Vasahat for brutally assaulting and robbing a salesman with a garment shop of his cell phone and cash, collectively worth Rs7,200.

The police investigation revealed that the man arrested, Swapnil Datta Awale is a resident of Janata Vasahat. He allegedly attacked and robbed Manoj Bahutule (35), who also lives in the same area, as he wanted a cell phone and money to purchase liquor. “We have recovered Bahutule’s cell phone and Rs200 from the suspect,” sub-inspector Kuldip Sankpal of Dattawadi police station told TOI.

On Monday around 4pm, Bahutule had gone to Parvati hill for a stroll as it was his weekly off. He was sitting on the wall on the route towards Kartik Swami temple when the suspect approached him and threatened him, brandishing a sharp knife. Bahutule had started resisting when the suspect tried to snatch his cell phone. The suspect went on to assault him with sharp weapons and even thrashed him, his complaint states. Bahutule suffered a cut on his chin and lost three teeth. The victim also suffered fractures to his left wrist and left leg in the sustained assault. The suspect fled the spot with Bahutule’s cell phone and Rs200 after noticing security guards were approaching them.

While investigating the case, Sankpal got a tip-of that the suspect involved in the robbery was waiting for someone on Sinhagad Road. “We rushed to the spot and took the suspect Awale into custody. We have recovered Bahutule’s cell phone from him,” Sankpal said.

He added that Awale is a daily wage worker. He did not have any previous criminal record. “He robbed Bahutule for his cell phone and used the money to buy liquor. Awale has been remanded to police custody till January 17,” Sankpal said.

Title: City girl in T20 WC squad
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Vadodara: Nineteen-year-old Radha Yadav, who plays for Baroda Cricket Association (BCA), has been picked up for the ICC T20 Cricket World Cup that will be played in Australia this year.

Yadav is the first woman cricketer from Gujarat to be picked up in a world cup team. This is her second stint at WC. In 2018, she played her first ICC T20 cricket world cup in West Indies.

When asked how she felt after being picked up for the T20 World Cup for the second time, Yadav said, “It’s a great and very special feeling to be a part of the Indian team, especially because I will represent the country in the world cup.”

Yadav added that she hopes to bring the world cup home.

BCA officials said that Yadav had performed well with ball in the recently held Challengers Trophy. “She was picked up on the basis of these performances,” a BCA official said.

An all-rounder, Yadav made her international debut in 2018 when she was picked up for the Indian team touring South Africa in February. She was later picked up twice for the Indian T20 team.

A left-arm spinner, Yadav is a good fielder and can bat too. Yadav, who used to play for Mumbai, shifted to Baroda Cricket Association (BCA) in 2014-15.

She has played for Baroda in U-19 West Zone tournament, senior women’s one-day tournament, senior women’s T20 tournament and U-23 West Zone one-day tournament.

In senior women’s T20 tournament, Yadav played 11 matches in 2016-17 and 2017-18 season wherein she bagged 16 wickets and scored 108 runs. She has also played for India Blue team in the Women’s Challenger Trophy.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Man gets 10 years in jail for sodomising minor
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

BAREILLY: The Shahjahanpur POCSO court on Thursday awarded 10 years rigorous imprisonment and Rs 20,000 fine to a man who was found guilty of sodomising an eight-year-old boy in Madnapur area of Shahjahanpur district in 2013.

Sohan Singh was booked by police in 2013 under sections 377 of IPC and 3/4 of POCSO Act. A monitoring cell constituted by Shahjahanpur police in 2019 pursued this case and ensured speedy trial and conviction, claimed police.

The judgement was pronounced by additional district and session judge Rashmi Nanda, after additional district government council Rajiv Awasthi produced convincing evidence in court against the accused.

This incident was reported in January 2013, when the victim was playing outside his house in the village. The accused lured him by offering a candy and sodomised him at an abandoned place. The accused was arrested after a police complaint was made by the boy’s parents. A chargesheet was filed and court proceedings initiated in 2013 itself.

Awasthi said, “We welcome the strict punishment which will send a strong message to society against sexual crime against children. Accused Sohan Singh will serve 10 years in jail and pay Rs 20,000 as well. The time he has already spent in jail will be deducted from his total term.”

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: ‘Mishaps due to lack of road infra high’
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The road accidents statistics for 2018, released by national crime records bureau (NCRB) a few days ago, has a table of data that could prove to be an embarrassment for the capital district. As per the data available with NCRB , Thiruvananthapuram tops the list when it comes to the number of accidents reported due to the lack of proper road infrastructure.

According to NCRB data, Thiruvananthapuram recorded 59 accidents in 2018 where 99 persons were injured and seven others died. The table also had figures of five other major districts in the state. While the figure was zero for Kannur, Kollam and Kozhikode, Kochi recorded 13 accidents with 11 injured persons and Malappuram had 11 accidents where 13 persons were injured.

Kerala Road Safety Authority commissioner N Shanker Reddy said that the lack of proper road infrastructure is a problem for all districts in the state. The reason for the high number of accidents in the capital might be the high traffic volume and undesirable road practices of motorists.

“There is a chance that victims in most of these cases could be pedestrians as many roads here still lack proper footpaths or zebra crossings on roads,” he said. He added that Thiruvananthapuram has a vast area with a lot of narrow roads outside city limits, where accidents may be high.

“Having said so, there has been some improvement on roads here as suggested by the latest figures,” Reddy said. For example, there was a negligible increase (0.2%) in accident fatalities when the figures of 2018 and 2019 are compared. The overall conditions such as road infrastructure, safe driving practices and law enforcement, are improving he said.

Meanwhile, a scientist with national transportation planning and research centre (Natpac) said that though lack of road infrastructure is indeed a problem, the conditions may not be that bad as cited by the figures.

“It all depends on the input given by police personnel who attend different accident cases. Often, a detailed further inquiry does not go into accident cases and officers may cite the cause of accident after drawing conclusions from the preliminary inquiry alone. Another thing we can consider in this case is that police personnel of other districts do not care to go into minute details of the accidents and hence the figures in those districts might appear less,” he said on condition of anonymity.

Title: Police: Petrol pump staffers fell for commission bait
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The three attendants of a petrol pump in Camp, arrested by the police on Tuesday for installing skimming sensors on debit/credit card readers to steal data from the account of card holders, were lured into carrying out the act by Delhi-based suspects on the promise of a hefty commission, police said.Altogether four persons — Mithun Ali, Noel Shaikh, Saimuddin Ali and Zulfikar Ahmed — were arrested in connection with the incident. All of them hail from poor families in Malda, West Bengal, senior inspector Jayram Paygude of the cybercrime cell said.“The two prime suspects, who are based in Delhi, approached the four men in Pune about a month ago with the proposal, according to which they would use skimming sensors to steal card details and also note down the PIN of card holders with the last four digits of the cards,” he said.“The suspects promised them a commission of Rs 20,000 each and they accepted the proposal,” Paygude said.The four men, all school dropouts, came to the city in search of work three months ago. Mithun, Noel and Saimuddin read an advertisement of a labour contractor about openings pasted on an electricity pole. They approached the labour contractor and he offered them job at the petrol pump, Paygude said.“The petrol pump owner paid Rs 11,000 as salary to these men but the contractor deducted about Rs 2,000 from their salaries. Failing to meet their ends, they readily accepted the proposal of the Delhi-based men,” he said.As per a preliminary estimate of cybercrime police station, the duo based in Delhi, had siphoned off Rs 8 lakh from the accounts of 60 people who visited the petrol pump in the last one month.Mithun, Noel and Saimuddin were employed at the petrol pump in Camp for last two months. Zulfiker was their handler.

Title: File report on Church’s ‘love jihad’ charge: NCM to Kerala
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

NEW DELHI: Citing a resolution of the Synod of the Syro-Malabar Catholic Church wherein it was alleged that Christian girls are increasingly being converted to Islam through ‘love jihad’ for terror activities, National Minorities Commission vice chairman George Kurian has sought a report within 21 days from the DGP of Kerala .

The NCM VC’s office issued a statement which said: “the Synod observed that half of 21 individuals who joined IS in 2016 from Kerala were Christians who were converted to Islam. The Church lamented that even though several complaints were registered, the Kerala Police had failed to take appropriate and timely action. This has led to terror outfits intensifying their nefarious activities with impunity. ”

TOI reported on Thursday that the Church had said that Keralite Christian girls were being targeted and killed in the name of love jihad.

Title: Compliance with circulars on safety in schools must, says Delhi high court
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Delhi high court

NEW DELHI: Delhi high court on Thursday stressed that there should be “strict compliance” with the AAP government’s circulars on safety and security standards in schools .

The court’s directions came as it disposed of a suo motu matter to improve the conditions in Delhi schools, and for framing guidelines to make them accountable for children’s safety. A bench of Chief Justice D N Patel and Justice C Hari Shankar said Delhi government has already issued circulars and taken steps to maintain safety and security standards in schools, and there remained no justification for HC to continue monitoring.

The bench disposed of the matter after AAP government informed that the circulars were issued asking the schools to carry out a police verification of the support staff, counselling and sensitisation of all staff, installation of CCTV cameras and providing separate washrooms for girl students.

Taking note, the court said only the implementation of the circulars, in letter and spirit, by the schools was required to be ensured, and ordered “there shall be strict compliance with the circulars by the schools in accordance with law.” It added that if there was any violation by any school, action would be taken.

Prior to passing of the order, advocate Ashok Agarwal said that while the government was taking steps and issuing circulars, they were not being complied with by the schools.

Title: Pune: Worker loses cash, phone in night loot
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The Yerawada police on Thursday arrested Tony Alex Fernandes (30) on the charge of robbing a daily wager of cash and cellphone, collectively valued at Rs11,000, near Irani Market.

Fernandes threatened Tipu Shaikh (26) with dire consequences before feeling with his valuables on Tuesday night.

A Yerawada police officer said Shaikh had lodged an FIR on Wednesday. “The incident occurred when Shaikh was on his way home after buying goods from the market. He was crossing an isolated lane when Fernandes waylaid him. After seeing a bag in Shaikh’s hand, Fernands absued him and fled with his cash and other valuables,” the officer said.

“Fernandes was allegedly under the influence of alcohol at the time of incident. He was arrested under Section 392 (robbery) of the IPC,” the police officer added.

Title: 125 commercial complexes sealed over tax defaults
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Rajkot: In a major drive against tax defaulters , officials of Rajkot Municipal Corporation (RMC) sealed as many as 125 commercial complexes in the city on Thursday.

“We have set the target of Rs 260 crore tax recovery for the year 2019-20, of which we have already collected Rs 148 crore. Now, in order to recover the remaining Rs 112 crore, we have launched the drive in various parts of the city,” said a senior RMC official.

Before starting the drive, the tax department had prepared a list of 6,000 tax defaulters, whose tax of over Rs one lakh was due.

“Much before the drive, we had sent notices to the defaulters, asking them to clear their dues. It was after they did not heed the notices, we launched the drive on Thursday,” added the official.

The commercial establishments sealed in the different zones of the RMC during the drive included 34 in the central zone encompassing Mahila College Chowk, Kadia Navline, Yagnik Road, Jawahar Road, Canal Road and Gondal Road, 34 in the west zone covering Kalawad Road, Ramapir Chowkadi, Lakshminagar, Mawadi Road, Raiya Chowkadi, Nana Mawa Road, Tirupati Industry area and Gokuldham, and 39 in the east zone including Rohidaspara, Sadgurunagar, Lati Plot, Pedak Road, Market Yard, Ranchhodnagar, Manda Dungar, Saint Kabir Road, Atika and Patelnagar.

Title: Four killed as truck hits autorickshaw in Moradabad
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

BAREILLY: Four people were killed and five others sustained injuries when a truck hit the autorickshaw they were travelling in on Kanth road under Chhajlet police station limits in Moradabad .

Three victims — all natives of Nahtaur town in Bijnor — have been identified as Anuj (21), Mithun (22) and Gaurav (30), all electricians. The unidentified auto driver was also killed in the accident, said police.

Police have arrested the truck driver, who dragged the three-wheeler for several metres and impounded the vehicle.

Police said the trio was on the way home after finishing their job for the day. “Since they couldn’t get a seat on the train, they hired a three-wheeler and met with the fatal accident.”

Chhajlet police station SHO Sunil Kumar Chaudhary said, “A police response vehicle (PRV) was stationed near the spot where the incident took place. After hitting the three-wheeler, the truck driver tried to flee the scene, but the PVR team chased him and arrested him. We have informed the families of the victims, but we are yet to identify the driver, who was driving without a licence.”

Police sent the bodies for post-mortem examination and registered an FIR against the truck driver.

Title: Monsoon deadline to finish Ambil Odha restoration work
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

The project is estimated to cost around Rs250 crore

Pune: The civic body has set the monsoon deadline for finishing the Ambil Odha repair and rejuvenation project, including construction of a retaining wall along it.

A meeting regarding the restoration project was held in the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC). “The civic administration has approached the state government for financial help for the project. The work must be completed in five months. If the funds are available, it will be completed within the deadline,” said Prashant Waghmare, the city engineer, PMC, on Thursday.

The deluge on September 25 had flooded Katraj, Sahakarnagar, Satara road, Katraj-Kondhwa road, Indiranagar, Bibvewadi and some other areas. Several lives were lost, too. Public amenities like gardens, water pumping stations and cultural halls were damaged.

The PMC has planned a restoration project for Ambil Odha at an estimated cost of around Rs250 crore. The civic administration will spend Rs78 crore. The corporation has sought help of the state government for funding the rest of the amount — Rs172 crore. The civic administration is also seeking help from other government authorities like Pune Metropolitan Region Development Authority (PMRDA).

The money would be spent on fitting protective mesh along the nullah, deepening of the channel, reconstruction of culverts and roads along the nullah, action against illegal constructions and encroachments, and survey of properties along the nullah.

A delegation of political leaders and civic officials had surveyed the flood-affected areas in December.

Title: Giripremi’s Kangchenjunga feat leads to climate change insights
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Nearly 60 people participated as support trekkers in the eco expedition held last year

PUNE: New scientific revelations have come out of city-based mountaineering club Giripremi’s Kangchenjunga eco expedition last year.

Mountaineers and trekkers had collected samples from the base camps and the expedition which they brought back to scientists at Savitribai Phule Pune University and other research institutes.

Umesh Zirpe, team leader of the expedition, said, “This is the first time in India that such an expedition was conducted. Kangchenjunga is on the border of India and Nepal. So the eco expedition was on both sides to the base camps. Nearly 60 people participated as support trekkers, and we called them eco trekkers,” he said.

Avinash Kandekar, assistant professor of the department of geography from the Savitribai Phule Pune University, was the coordinator of sample collection throughout the expedition.

“The base camp expedition was divided into two groups, one from the Sikkim side and another group from the Nepal side. Seven students from the SPPU’s department of geography also took part and three went on to do their research on this,” he said.

Core samples were taken from four glacial lakes of Sukha Pokhari, Lakshmi Pokhari, Samiti Lake and Lam Pokhari. “We drilled a hole into the rocky portions of these lakes to collect the samples,” he said.

Shubham Gavhane, who participated as a postgraduate student of geography, submitted his dissertation on the expedition entitled — Late Holocene Environmental Magnetic changes at Lam Pokhari Lake; Implications to climate change .

Now, an assistant professor of geography at D Y Patil Arts Commerce and Science College in Pimpri, Gavhane said, “We conducted an analysis on mineral magnetic change which gives an idea of the climate change that took place over the last few years. As we go deeper, we get the longer years’ record of climate.”

Mineral magnetic analysis gives the trend of change in climatic condition in that particular valley. “We also took up the particle size analysis which gives an idea of the variations in the size of particles in different layers. Lastly, we conducted a mineral identification under microscope and identified the different minerals at different depths in the samples that were collected,” he added.

Through the samples, Kandekar said, they were able to gauge that it dated back to around the time of the Holocene era.

“The Holocene period is an inter-glaciation period, where the snow started melting. Some samples we got are from the bottom of the lake and most of them have a chance of being either from the Holocene period or before. We have sent the samples to an Ahmedabad-based institute for the exact dating. The samples are divided into the bottom, middle and surface samples where the sediments have settled over ages,” Kandekar said.

Title: Pune: Four rob Undri grocer of Rs 40,000, two held
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A timely alarm raised by a grocery shop owner helped a patrolling team nab two bike-borne men, minutes after they robbed him of Rs40,000 near Sanskriti School in Undri on Tuesday night.

A court here on Thursday remanded Santosh Vilas More (38) and Sagar Mohan Jadhav (36) in police custody till Saturday.

“Sohanlal Agarwal (40) was riding a bike back home around 1030pm on Tuesday when four men on two motorcycles intercepted him. They assaulted and robbed him of Rs40,000 and sped away towards NIBM Chowk,” sub-inspector of Kondhwa police Santosh Shinde said.

“When the four men were fleeing, Agarwal nabbed More and raised an alarm. The police patrol team arrested him,” Shinde said. During questioning, More revealed Jadhav’s name. Jadhav was arrested on Wednesday.

“We are questioning More and Jadhav to identify the two others,” Shinde added.

Title: Illegal cockfights held in outskirts of Vijayawada, 27 cases registered
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Vijayawada: The outskirts of Vijayawada within the commissionerate limits witnessed several illegal cockfighting events and cops managed to crackdown on 104 persons and registered 27 cases during the last two days of Sankranti festival.

According to official data, they also seized 62 cockerels and recovered Rs 1.7 lakh cash from gambling spots.

Cops also recovered 103 cockfighting knives commonly known as Tari.

The enforcement figures of Krishna district police unit stand much higher than Vijayawada due to their larger jurisdiction.

A total number of 313 persons were arrested and Rs 1.1 lakh cash was seized along with 185 roosters and 208 knives. Apart from the cockfighting gambling rackets, cops also cracked down on other gambling rackets like ‘Kotha Mukka’ and ‘Matka’ card games and recovered more cash. In Vijayawada, they seized Rs 4.4 lakh cash and registered 13 cases against 87 people. Krishna district police unit registered 47 cases against 143 persons and seized Rs 8.2 lakh cash from them.

Regardless of the enforcement, the bloodsport did take place unabated at the suburban regions of Yanamalakuduru, Pedapulipaka and Edupugallu villages under the commissionerate limits. They also took blatantly place in Gudivada, Nuzvid, Avanigadda and other places in the Krishna district where the stakes were higher as several lakhs of cash are said to be exchanging hands.

The steps taken by the police to keep cockfights and gambling in check have not been entirely successful in the area.

Title: Coimbatore: Vegetable prices drop as local supply picks up momentum
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: Prices of several commonly used vegetables have started to gradually drop as the harvest season is around the corner. While in some cases prices have already decreased by 10%, farmers said they would become more cheaper in the next two weeks.

While harvest has begun in other states and a few other places in Tamil Nadu, the district is gearing up for the same. A source said the district was likely to harvest vegetables starting next week. While farmers are watching the prices cautiously, many homemakers are heaving a huge sigh of relief.

On Thursday, big onion was priced at Rs 63 per kg, compared to Rs 80 in the first week of January and Rs 100 in the last week of December. The cauliflower price, which remained at Rs 52 per kg through December and January first week, dropped to Rs 48, while Beetroot prices came down to Rs 58.5 per kg from Rs 68.

While tomato and carrot prices have marginally increased by Rs 2 to Rs 8 per kg, people said the hike wouldn’t affect the kitchen budget. Hemalatha A, a resident of RS Puram, said, “Compared to two months ago when the price of vegetables such as onion and drumstick increased by Rs 80 to Rs 100 per kg, this week is a relief to shop.”

She said there was nothing to be concerned over the marginal increase in the tomato and carrot prices as onion, beetroot and cauliflower have become cheaper. “It won’t affect our budget. In fact, we could now spend more on fruits,” she said.

Vegetable traders said except for shallot and drumstick, prices of vegetables were slowly returning to normal. S S N Jothi, from Odanchathiram vegetable market, said, “Prices have begun coming down as we are receiving supplies from surrounding districts and villages. In fact, we are primarily selling only local vegetables now.”

However, drumstick and onion continue to come from other states such as Karnataka, Gujarat and Maharashtra, among others.

While harvest of vegetables has begun in the region, farmers said it would take another one week to start the same in a full-fledged manner. P Kandasamy, state secretary of Tamil Nadu Vivasaigal Sangam, said, “Our vegetables are growing well because of good rain that we received during monsoon. Harvest will take place over the next one week in the region.”

G A Wahab, a member of Saibaba Colony Vegetable Traders’ Association , attributed the fall in vegetable prices to increased supply from Sathyamangalam-Annur stretch, where harvest has begun. “We can expect the prices to fall further as local supply increases. Brinjal price hasn’t seen any fluctuation so far as the crop is hit by fog and mist situation.”

Title: PMC says trash dumping down to ‘zero’ at Uruli
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Pune: The civic administration on Thursday said dumping of garbage at the Urali Devachi depot has been finally stopped.

A senior Pune Municipal Corpration (PMC) official claimed that the practice of open dumping of garbage in Uruli Devachi came to an end on Wednesday after 25 years and the administration was looking forward to continue with the new arrangement.

The civic body had in the past pledged to not send garbage-laden trucks to Uruli Devachi and Phursungi after December 31, 2019. However, it had failed to meet the deadline. This prompted the residents of the two villagers to stop the trucks reaching their areas. They were also mulling over to intensify the agitation. The residents had then put on hold the agitation, as the PMC sought two more weeks to stop the practice.

“We have brought down garbage dumping in Uruli to ‘zero’. The waste is now going to other plants for processing. We have been doing this on an experimental basis for the past 15 days,” said Dnyaneshwar Molak, head of the PMC’s solid waste management department.

The official said the administration has increased the daily garbage processing at its existing processing plants to treat the trash not reaching the Uruli depot. “Besides, a 700-tonne capacity plant at Hadapsar, which was not working at its full capacity, is now operational at the optimum capacity. Steps have been taken to ensure that the waste is not left unattended to at the ramp sites, Molak said.

A senior official from the solid waste management department said the civic body was planning to permanently stop dumping of garbage at the depot in the next four months. At least eight plants of various capacities are expected to become operational by then.

The residents of Uruli Devachi and Phursungi have said they would keep a watch on the situation for the next few days. Bhagwan Bhadale, a resident, said, “We need to see if the PMC keeps its promise this time. The civic administration had violated such promises on many occasions in the past.

Civic activists have sought detailed analysis of the PMC’s claims and how the garbage was being processed in the city. “If the PMC can start processing garbage at the existing plants within two weeks, then why was it not done before December 31, 2019? The PMC should make public details of waste processing during the last three months,” said Vivek Velankar of citizens’ group Sajag Nagrik Manch.

Title: Electoral bonds help YSRC to record 93% increase in income
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Vijayawada: YSRC received Rs 181 crore as donations from individuals and organisations during 2018-19.

Of this, Rs 99.84 crore came through electoral bonds. This is 55% of the total donations received by the party till March 31, 2019.

YSRC received only Rs 14 crore during 2017-18 but its income increased to Rs 181 crore during the last financial year, recording 93% increase in the overall income.

According to a statement submitted by YSRC before the Election Commission, the party headed by chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy got Rs 36 crore in donations from non-business entities and Rs 18 crore from corporate houses.

The statement, which is mandatory under Section 29C (3) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, showed that it had paid about Rs 37 crore to Indian Political Action Committee (I-PAC) that looked after the YSRC campaign in Andhra Pradesh.

The party also spent about Rs 87 crore on election campaign and newspaper advertisements among others. At the end of the financial year, the party was left with a balance of Rs 93.39 crore.

Showing the statement for income, the party said Rs 36 crore was contributed by non-corporate entities, Rs 18 crore by corporate entities, Rs 99.8 crore through electoral bonds and Rs 27 crore through electoral trust.

The donations ranged from as little as Rs 91,000 to Rs 27 crore. Prudent Electoral Trust based in New Delhi had donated Rs 27 crore between June 13, 2018 and March 30, 2019. In March 2019 when elections were held in AP, the trust made two contributions--March 24 and March 30.

MV Builders based in Visakhapatnam had donated 10 times to YSRC from August 6, 2018 to January 17, 2019 totalling Rs 9 crore. MVV Satyanarayana, also from Visakhapatnam, had donated Rs 2 crore.

Other major donors included Andru Minerals of Rajahmundry (Rs 9 crore) and IND Sing Developers of Bangalore contributed Rs 5 crore. The donors included some real estate firms. Some of the contributions were made through IMPS or RTGS and the party did not name the donors.

Title: IndiGo flight diverts to Mumbai after mid-air engine vibrations
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Over 180 passengers aboard an IndiGo flight to Jaipur suffered a mid-air scare in the early hours of Thursday when the Airbus A320neo aircraft, with Pratt & Whitney engines, had to be diverted to Mumbai after heavy vibrations.The flight had taken off from the city around 3.40am, a source said, and was supposed to land in Jaipur by 5.35am. Heavy vibrations in one of the engines of the aircraft rattled the passengers at an altitude of around 30,600 feet. The lead pilot (commander) then decided to divert and land at Mumbai airport, the nearest at the time.A spokesperson of the airline said, “An IndiGo flight 6E-6129 (A320) operating from Pune to Jaipur was diverted to Mumbai this morning. During the flight, the pilot got an engine vibration alert and followed the laid standard operating procedure. The flight landed in Mumbai. The aircraft is currently under inspection there. All passengers were accommodated in another aircraft to Jaipur.”A source said, “At 4.25am, the emergency was declared, and the pilots decided to divert the aircraft. The flight landed in Mumbai around 4.40am. The other flight assigned to the passengers departed around 7.35am for Jaipur.”A passenger aboard the aircraft said, “There was a sudden jerk, followed by a few more. We did not quite understand the issue, but realised that something was wrong. The cabin crew was initially quiet. The pilot then announced that the flight was being diverted, and that’s when some passengers panicked.”Another source said the engines of the aircraft was last inspected on December 9. The next inspection was scheduled after the completion of 500 cycles (flights), but one of its engines developed snag during the 255th flight.The Directorate General of Civil Aviation (DGCA) earlier directed that these aircraft (A320Neos) could operate if at least one of their engines was modified. The DGCA recently extended the deadline for modifying the Pratt & Whitney (P&W) engines of these aircraft to March 31 from January 31. Apart from IndiGo, GoAir has A320Neo aircraft with P&W engines.Both the airlines encountered similar incidents in the recent past. This is the 21st snag petaining to IndiGo aircraft in two years. In October last year, a Pune-bound IndiGo plane returned to Kolkata after take-off because of an engine snag. Another IndiGo flight from Pune to Nagpur had to return to the city in April last year because of a similar problem.
