Prakash Javadekar

Title: 29 detained for anti-CAA stir without nod
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Bareilly: Police in Bareilly have detained 29 anti-CAA protesters who tried to stage a sit-in at the Azad College ground without permission on Wednesday night.

Police initially tried to convince them to take requisite permission before entering the college ground for the sit-in, but the protesters, who were not led by anyone and a few of them were from outside the Bareilly district, refused to budge. Police had to use force to disperse the crowd.

Among the 29 detained, eight were charged under section 151 of IPC (knowingly joining or continuing in assembly of five or more persons after it has been commanded to disperse) while others were released after warning.

According to sources, several people from neighbouring towns of Uttarakhand and a few from Jharkhand and Bihar, who are living in Bareilly for their livelihood, had come to the ground to support the protest of Ittehad-e-Millat Council (IMC) chief Tauqeer Raza Khan. Raza was protesting at Islamia school ground since Monday but he decided to call off the protest on Wednesday evening after a few groups attempted to sit at the same venue in support of CAA.

Bareilly SSP Shailesh Pandey sent extra force from reserve police lines to the spot and SHOs from Premnagar, Kotwali, and Cantonment police stations were also rushed to tackle any untoward situation.

Additional SP Abhishek Verma, who led the police action, told TOI, “After IMC’s protest was over, several outsiders from Uttrakhand, Bihar and Jharkhand attempted to stage protest and even tried to disrupt peace. They were around 500 to 600 in numbers and were led by Mohammed Rizwan from Kichcha town in Uttarakhand. After requesting them for several hours, we had to use our force to disperse the crowd at midnight. Our intelligence report said that a few antisocial elements were intending to spread violence here. We had checked with local leaders but no one was leading the protest from Bareilly.”

“We had taken 29 persons under custody and 20 of them were released upon furnishing personal bond while 9 were presented in court where seven were granted bail while their leader Rizwan was sent to 14-day judicial custody. No one was hurt in the process,” the ASP said.

“We have registered an FIR against 29 named and nearly 200 unidentified persons under relevant sections of IPC at Baradari police station. We are keeping an eye on all the suspicious activities and all our security agencies are on alert,” he added.

Tauqeer Raza Khan told TOI, “We called off our protest because a few antisocial elements were attempting to disrupt peace. We have no idea about the outsiders who came to join protest. For us, peace in the city is our priority.”

Title: PIL afoot to make local bodies responsible for water supply
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Pune: Akhil Bharatiya Grahak Panchayat, a Pune-based consumer activists group, intends to file a Public Interest Litigation (PIL) in Bombay High Court, demanding that the government make all local civic bodies responsible for providing water if building permission is granted by them for any construction.

A mere affidavit from the builder declaring that he would provide water from any of the available sources should not merit grant of building permission, stated activist Vijay Sagar. He along with the Pune district housing federation president Suhas Patwardhan and members of various housing societies have written to the state government on the issue.

Now, they intend to file a PIL demanding that all local civic bodies be made responsible for providing water if building permission is granted by them after collecting the required fee.

The group is currently in the process of collecting data of water usage and requirement for water tankers from all housing societies in Pune. With many housing societies in fringe areas such as Kharadi, Wagholi, Undri and Katraj dependent on water tankers for almost throughout the year, developers who had submitted affidavit for granting of building permission have backed out, leaving the citizens to fend for themselves.

The activists in their letter stated that the local authority should not hold individuals, such as developers or consumers, to run after water source after the construction is completed.

Corporations and even the metropolitan authorities accept affidavits from builders stating that they are responsible for supplying water. Building permission is granted once the local authority receives the affidavits.

In 2007, residents of Mohammadwadi and Vimannagar raised the issue with the local authority but without much success.

The residents told TOI that they have to depend on tankers for water supply. “It is an ordeal for us year after year and our society spends lakhs on tankers,’’ said a resident.

Three years back a divisional bench of Bombay HC had imposed temporary restrictions on PMC from sanctioning new projects in the Baner-Balewadi areas or granting occupancy certificates for completed buildings till the water issue was addressed.

Their demands

Local authority should be held responsible for all infrastructure provisions, including water

The onus should be made accountable and not builder

Water affidavits should not be the yardstick for granting building permission to increase their coffer

As development fee is collected, water has to be provided

Title: Delhi: 14 cars parked on empty plot in Vivek Vihar charred in fire
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: Fourteen cars, including a BMW , were charred in east Delhi’s Vivek Vihar in the wee hours on Thursday . The cars belonged to a sale and purchase dealer, who had parked them in an empty plot opposite to the Vivek Vihar police station due to lack of space. Three fire tenders were rushed to the location to douse the blaze.

The cause of the fire was yet to be ascertained.

The dealer, Vivek Walia, alleged that someone had purposely set the cars on fire. “There is no way all of them would have caught fire together. These cars were not even covered under insurance,” he said.

According to the fire department officials, a call was received around 2.30am on Thursday about a blaze opposite the Vivek Vihar police station. “The fire engulfed fourteen old cars but no one sustained any injuries in the blaze,” they added.

“Our guard informed us about the fire. We reached there only to see 13-14 cars in flames. We want a through enquiry into this. Cars do not catch fire like this. They were parked at a distance from each another,” said Walia.

The crime and forensic team was called to lift evidence from the spot.

Title: Sangli farmer plans bike tour across 94 cities to promote organ donation
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

nfjlwenvgjwerfn

Pune: Kidney donor Pramod Mahajan (68), a marginal farmer from Sangli district, will soon set out on a tour of 94 cities covering 17,500km on his motorbike from January 18 to spread awareness about organ donation.

“I am hale and hearty and raring to take up this mission. I look forward to this journey as it has given me a cause,” Mahajan said.

Pune-based NGO ReBirth Foundation, in association with Zonal Transplant Coordination Committee (ZTCC) and Regional Organ and Tissue Transplant Organization, will flag off Mahajan’s pan-India motorbike tour from Patrakar Bhavan in Navi Peth at 11am on Saturday. Mahajan is a member of the NGO, which works in the field of organ donation and keeps a record of potential organ donors.

“This time, I will be riding an Avenger motorcycle with 220CC engine. ReBirth Foundation has provided the motorbike for the expedition. In 2018, I had used my own Yamaha Libero motorcycle for the 100-day bike expedition for organ donation,” Mahajan said.

In 2018, Mahajan, had embarked on the solo journey from Shaniwarwada on October 21, and completed it on January 25, 2019, at Sarasbaug. It had taken him 100 days to travel over 12,000km across the country. Over 10,000 people had supported the cause by filling in organ donation forms during the course of his journey.

“Unlike last year, when I had travelled to 19 states in 100 days, I am going to cover 28 states in 132 days this year. I have included states in northeast India and some union territories like Diu and Daman in this year’s itinerary,” Mahajan said.

His talk on organ donation has inspired many. “People listen to me with intent and take my word seriously because I am not just delivering talks on organ donation, I have myself donated one of my kidneys to a needy stranger,” Mahajan said.

He had donated one of his kidneys to a former employee of Central Industrial Security Force around 18 years ago.

“Besides, Mahajan embodies the very fact that a kidney donor can actually lead a normal and healthy life. He confesses that he has had absolutely no health issues since donating his kidney,” said transplant coordinator at ZTCC Aarti Gokhale.

Mahajan lives with his wife in Sangli district’s Dhavali village. Apart from farming, he sells books to earn a living. “During the last bike expedition, except for a cold, I didn’t suffer any health issues. I am fitter and I do not have any underlying medical conditions,” Mahajan signed off.

Title: This expo offers alternatives to single-use plastic
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

eco-friendly: Minister A C Moideen takes a look at an installation made of plastic bottles at the exhibition a... Read More

Thiruvananthapuram: Ever thought of sipping your juice with a grass straw or carrying a food in a bag made from tapioca extract? An exhibition that is organized as part of ‘ Suchitwa Sangamam 2020 ’ in the city offers an array of such alternatives for single-use plastic .

The exhibition consists of around 120 stalls and demonstrates methods to avoid plastics from daily life.

A group of MSc students from School of Environmental Sciences, Mahatma Gandhi University, made bio straw from common invasive grass species. Shijo Joy, Abijth and Ajith are the brains behind this. “We all know about the side-effects of plastic. When we thought of a solution to reduce plastic, we thought of bamboo straws and those made of special grass in Vietnam. So we decided to work with the raw materials available in our area and tried with many plants, including paddy and wheat, and finally ended with grass,” the students said. The product is made from the stem of common grass, locally called as ‘Potha’.

It is a handmade product, where the hollow stem of the grass is cut and cleaned with some treatments to prevent fungus and other bacterial growth. Then the stems are dried in sunlight. The durability of these straws is 4 to 5 months and rate is Rs 1. The students plan to take this product into the market and to make it commercially available.

The show also presents carry bags made of starch extracts from eatables such as tapioca and is mixed with biodegradable polymer. These bags have high-loading performance and can be recycled with paper. The bags are soluble in water and will produce carbon when burned as paper. This product has been brought to the exhibition by companies ‘Breathing Earth’ and ‘Bio Mart’. Bio Mart also brings out transparent containers made out of corn and plates made of sugarcane starch. There are other stalls also which showcase plates and spoons of sugarcane bagasse. These companies are looking for a market in Kerala and expressed their hope that the people will support these ecofriendly products.

Kerala Agriculture University showcases fast bio decomposer that runs with electricity.

Title: We The People to organize gathering against CAA today
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: We The People , a people’s movement aiming to uphold the values of Constitution, will organise a gathering titled ‘India is for All’ at Nishagandhi Auditorium on Friday. Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan will deliver the keynote address at 7.30pm.

The event is organised in solidarity with protests against Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) happening across the country. The day-long programme, starting at 9am, will discuss about CAA . The organisers expect a participation of around 10,000 people.

“The existence of Constitution itself is questioned now. The event aims to express solidarity with the movements across the country against CAA. Sitaram Yechury will be among those who will participate in the event. The CPM leaders who are here to attend the central committee meeting are also likely to participate in the event,” said film director Vidhu Vincent, who is the chairperson of We The People.

“The programme at Nishagandhi is the valedictory function of a series of events held as part of the second episode of We The People movement. The previous event was organised in 2018 after the Sabarimala verdict. We want to extend the movement to other states as well,” added Vidhu.

Ministers T M Thomas Issac, Kadakampally Surendran, J Mercykutty Amma, K K Shailaja, Kadannappally Ramachandran, C Raveendranath, mayor K Sreekumar; MLAs K S Sabarinathan, V S Sivakumar, B Sathyan, V K Prasanth, M Noushad, T V Rajesh, I B Satheesh, V Joy and M K Muneer; CPI leaders Annie Raja and Kanam Rajendran, KPMS’s Punnala Sreekumar, activist C K Janu, MES president Fazal Gafoor and social activist J Devikar are among those who will attend. Activists Shabnam Hashmi, Harsh Mander, Chandan Kumar and Sandeep Pandey, student activists Amutha Jaydeep, Akhtarista Ansari and Dolan Samanta, representatives from Queer community are other participants of the event.

The organisers have asked people interested in participate in the event to wear magenta colour clothes and to bring ribbons, placards and banners in magenta colour.

Title: Tamil Nadu: This jallikattu for women tests their intelligence, not bravery
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

NAMAKKAL: Taking a cue from jallikattu , residents of Nandavanam Street in Tiruchengode here on Thursday organized an interesting game for the women folk - they had to catch a hen/rooster tied to their leg.

S Devendran, one of the event organizers, said while jallikattu tested one’s bravery, the game that they organized was intended to put the contestants’ intelligence into test.

“In this game, a hen or rooster will be tied to the participants’ legs using a rope. The participants will be blindfolded and left in a circle. They have to catch the hen or rooster within the stipulated time, while ensuring neither they nor the bird go outside the circle,” Devendran said.

He said the game wasn’t anything new to the village. “We are conducting the event for the 11th consecutive year.”

On Thursday, hundreds of women and girls participated in the event. Winners were given away prizes.

P Sharmila, 28, a participant, said the event was close to her heart. “I am married and settled in Bengaluru. But I come to my native village at this time of the year without any fail to participate in the event, which is filled with fun.”

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Rape survivor gives birth, baby dies within 2 hours
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representational Image

BAREILLY: A 21-year-old rape survivor gave birth to a baby who died two hours after the delivery at a community health centre in Nighasan area of Lakhimpur Kheri district on Wednesday.

The girl was allegedly raped by her cousin in Sampoornanagar last April and the accused is currently lodged in Lakhimpur district jail. The baby’s body was sent for autopsy and a DNA test would be conducted on survivor’s request so that it could be used as evidence against the accused.

According to sources, the girl had visited her uncle’s house last year where she was repeatedly raped by her cousin for nearly a month. Her cousin allegedly threatened to kill her which forced her to remain quiet. The crime came to light when she got pregnant and was sent back home by her uncle. After returning home, she narrated her ordeal to her parents. A police complaint was then filed against her cousin under the section of rape.

There were repeated talks between both the families for a compromise but the accused refused to marry the girl. In the meantime, police continued their investigation and sent the accused to jail on December 10 after collecting evidence.

On the other hand, the girl refused to abort her child and felt labour pain on the night on Tuesday and delivered a baby girl on Wednesday morning. However, the newborn was very weak and died within two hours of delivery. The survivor’s father said that his daughter was under severe depression which possibly affected the health of her baby as well.

SHO Nighasan police station Deepak Shukla said, “The rape survivor’s family had requested us to send the baby’s body for autopsy and collect sample for DNA test, to be used as evidence in their case. The FIR in this case was registered at Sampoornanagar police station and we will share the autopsy report and other information with them as per standard procedure.”

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault

Title: PCMC to start 10 help centres for detection of disabilities in children
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Pimpri Chinchwad: The civic body will start a pilot project for the early detection and intervention of disabilities in pre- and post-birth children up to six years at 10 centres.

Assistant commissioner of urban community development department Ulhas Jagtap said a contract will be signed soon with the district disability rehabilitation centre, Pune, for the project. The Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation will be the first civic body in the state to implement such a project.

A senior civic official said early detection and intervention for disability rehabilitation is the way ahead.

“It comprises disability prevention, reducing severity of disability and preparing a child having permanent disability for the future. It is also a method for parental acceptance of a disabled child in the family for medical and social rehabilitation,” he added.

The civic body proposes to start early intervention centres by strengthening the infrastructure of anganwadis/ balwadis first and then scale it up. “We are approaching the Union government's district disability rehabilitation centre to collaborate,” he said.

The project will be implemented on a pilot basis at 10 centres in five anganwadis and five balwadis which will be shortlisted. The total budget allocated for early intervention for one year is Rs 72 lakh.

The anganwadis and balwadis in the slum and gaothan areas will be picked for the pilot project. A survey of every household in the jurisdiction will be conducted.

“Tests of pregnant women will be conducted for finding any disability in the foetus. Tests will be conducted on newborn children for early detection of any disability. Audiometry tests, OAE and Bera tests brainstem evoked response and audiometer testing will be conducted at Yashwantrao Chavan Memorial hospital in Pimpri, the official,” he added.

Title: Pune: Rs 2.88 lakh stolen from ATM in Chinchwad
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Thieves stole Rs2.88 lakh from a public sector bank’s automated teller machine (ATM) at Mohannagar in Chinchwad early on Wednesday.

The Pimpri police suspect the involvement of an insider as the cash vault of the ATM was opened by using an 18-digit password. A 33-year-old officer from the bank has lodged an FIR with the Pimpri police.

The police said the theft came to light on Wednesday afternoon when a person went to withdraw cash at the ATM kiosk. “When the machine did not dispense cash, the person informed the bank officials, following which the machine was checked and three cash trays were found empty, with Rs2.88 lakh missing,” said an officer from the Pimpri police.

Prima facie probe revealed that the ATM kiosk was unlocked using a duplicate key. “We have obtained the CCTV footage from the kiosk,” the officer said.

Title: Heavy bandobust ahead of India-Australia match today
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Khandheri Stadium gets ready for the international match

Rajkot: Ahead of the India-Australia one day cricket match on Friday in Rajkot, the city police deployed a massive bandobast in the city on Thursday.

“There will be 450 police personnel and 250 private security guards deployed at Khandheri Stadium. There will also be three teams of bomb detection and disposal squads,” said Balram Meena, superintendent of police, Rajkot rural, while addressing a press conference here on Thursday.

“About 30,000 cricket enthusiasts are likely to be present in the stadium. We have banned the entry of cameras, cigarettes, match boxes and water bottles into the stadium. Action will be taken against those who try to enter the boundary of the cricket ground,” he added.

According to officials, in order to manage the rush of the audience going towards the stadium, Rajkot police have diverted the routes of heavy vehicles. The heavy vehicles moving towards Jamnagar from Rajkot will be diverted through Morbi Road and the vehicles coming to Rajkot from Jamnagar will be diverted through Mowaia Circle.

Title: Pune: Boy dies after vehicle-hit scooter crashes into median, friend hurt
Content:
The scooter was damaged on both sides. Soham died on the spot, while Ritesh’ condition is reported to be serio... Read More

PUNE: A 16-year-old boy riding a scooter was killed and the pillion rider (15) suffered serious injuries as their two-wheeler crashed into median after a vehicle rammed it opposite Laxmibai Magar School along Magarpatta-Kharadi road early on Wednesday morning.Both the minors, Standard X students of a school in Mundhwa, were not wearing helmets, police said. The scooter rider, Soham Survase, succumbed to serious head injury. The injured boy, Ritesh Ingole, has been placed on ventilator at a private hospital in Hadapsar.The parents of Soham and Ritesh from Hadapsar claimed to be clueless about where they were going.Inspector Humraj Kumbhar from the Hadapsar police said, “Soham and his classmate, Ritesh, were heading towards Kharadi via Magarpatta when an unidentified vehicle hit their scooter. The biker lost control over the vehicle and crashed into the road divider. The scooter was damaged on both sides. Soham died on the spot, while Ritesh’ condition is reported to be serious.”An offence under the relevant sections of the Indian Penal Code and the Motor Vehicles Act was lodged against the errant driver.“We are checking footage of CCTV cameras and questioning passersby travelling between Magarpatta and Kharadi to identify the killer vehicle,” Kumbhar said.Tea vendor Samadhan Latke, the complainant in the fatal accident case, told TOI, “A vehicle skidded after hitting the median and stopped outside my shop around 7am on Wednesday. There was no one on the scooter. I rushed out to see what had happened and saw the two boys lying in a pool of blood. The rider (Soham) succumbed to injuries, while Ritesh was groaning in severe pain and shivering in cold. I rushed Ritesh to the hospital. I later called a relative of Soham and asked him to come to the hospital.”Rohit Thorat, a family friend of Survases and Ingoles, said, “Soham and Ritesh were classmates and close friends. We don’t know the reason where they were going. We feel that they were on way to meet a known person because all their friends and relatives reside along Magarpatta-Kharadi road. The students came from poor financial background. Soham was not wearing sweater and his family donated his eyes soon after the accident. His funeral was performed the same evening. Ritesh has been put on ventilator.”Security officer Shivaji Survase, the father of Soham, said, “After taking bath, Soham told his mother that he was leaving for some work with his classmate, and that he would return home shortly. I don’t know where my son was going. I don’t know how he got the vehicle.”Bhimrao Ingole, the father of Ritesh, said, “The scooter belongs to my relative. I have no idea where my son Ritesh was going. I have no information on how the accident occurred.”

Title: 2.5L teachers needed for Census process
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Pune: The Census department wants the Maharashtra government to provide 2.5 lakh teachers for the decennial headcount and collection of National Population Register (NPR) data across the state.

Census officials said the teachers would be helpful for the work once the formal notification was issued. Maharashtra is yet to receive the notification on the NPR drive to be carried out between April and September across the country.

The officials said department’s work was listing of houses, the first phase of the Cencus work and NPR data collection. An official said 137 “master trainers” in Pune have been guided and 3,800 teachers would be trained once the notification was issued.

“The notification is expected from the general administration department headed by the chief minister,” a senior Census official said on Thursday. In Maharashtra, the drive was supposed to be held in May-June. Congress cabinet minister Varsha Gaikwad recently issued a statement that the Maha Vikas Aghadi would not allow the rollout of NPR drive in May.

Census department officials have undergone training in the past three months. “Once the notification is issued, no official can refuse the work. It is like election duty. The enumerators entrusted with the house-listing task will have to simultaneously collect the NPR data,” the official said.

The NPR is supposed to record the “usual residents” of the country living in an area for the past six months or more or people willing to stay there for the next six months or more. The Census involves collection of information about all residents of India without listing their names.

Under Section 4 (2) of the Census of India Act, 1948, the state may appoint persons as Census officers to take, aid in or supervise the taking of the census within any specified local area and such persons, when so appointed, shall be bound to serve accordingly. Rule 5 of the Citizenship Rules, 2003, states that every official of the Centre and state government shall assist the Registrar General of Citizen Registration in preparation of the database.

Section 11 of the Census of India Act lays down the penalties — imprisonment up to three years and/or fine — for government or any other staff declining to aid in conduct of census. Any refusal to perform NPR duty may invite up to Rs1,000 fine under Rule 17 of the Citizenship Rules, 2003.

Title: Former minister Sailajanath new APCC chief
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Vijayawada: The long wait for the announcement of the rank and file of AP Congress ended on Thursday with the party’s national leadership appointing former minister Sake Sailajanath state president. Former MP and APCC vice-president N Tulasi Reddy and former MLA Shaik Mastan Vali will assume charge as working presidents.

The APCC president’s post fell vacant following the resignation of former minister N Raghuveera Reddy immediately after the 2019 general elections. Several senior leaders lobbied for the post including former Union ministers M M Pallam Raju and J D Seelam.

However, the AICC leadership cleared the candidature of Sailajanath, a loyalist of late YS Rajasekhar Reddy.

The Congress had lost most of its cadre and voter base in the state to YSRC after Jaganmohan Reddy walked out of the party in 2009 and formed his own outfit.

Title: Amdavadis fine with helmet fines?
Content: Ahmedabad: The state government had in December last announced to give relaxation in helmet rule ‘on public demand’. Even in Ahmedabad city, two-wheeler riders, it seem, prefer paying fine to wearing helmets as fine collection for violating this traffic rule has remained on the top in the past four years.In 2019, the city registered 6.29 lakh cases for which Rs 7.24 crore was collected from the offenders. This was around 31% of the total fine of Rs 23.15 crore levied on traffic offenders in 2019.Compared to 2018, the number of offences decreased in 2019 due to the introduction of the amended motor vehicle act. After this, the fine for not wearing helmet was increased from Rs 100 to Rs 500. In 2018, the city traffic police registered 6.55 lakh cases of not wearing helmet, for which Rs 6.55 crore was collected by them. In 2016, 3.78 lakh cases were registered for which Rs 3.29 crore were paid as fine.DCP, traffic (west), Ajit Rajian, said that the people are aware of their safety and the traffic rules, but it’s a question of habit. Rajian said that it is easier to book someone not wearing helmet which is the reason for high number of cases.Rickshawalas paid Rs 7.67 cr in 4 yearsThe autorickshaw drivers paid Rs 7.67 crore in 3.21 lakh offences from 2016 to 2019. They coughed up Rs 76.72 lakh for allowing passengers to sit beside the driver’s seat. Total 53,784 cases were registered in this category. The autorickshaw drivers had to pay Rs 4.72 crore in 2016, the highest in the four years.3.11 lakh cases against car driversIn 2019, car drivers topped in the number of traffic offences with 3.11 lakh cases registered against four-wheeler drivers. This was 20% of total 15.36 lakh offences in 2019. Out of 3.11 lakh offences, the highest 1.45 lakh cases were for not wearing the seat belt, for which Rs 2.82 crore fine was imposed. As many as 64,260 cases of illegal parking were registered against the car drivers for which Rs 52.77 lakh fine was imposed. The traffic police also registered 25,456 cases of using dark film and collected Rs 59.17 lakh as fine.

Title: IMFL worth Rs 44L seized in Junagadh; two arrested
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Accused in Junagadh police custody

Rajkot: A total of 9 ,528 bottles of Indian Made Foreign Liquor (IMFL) worth Rs 44 lakh were seized from a truck and two bootleggers arrested from Dervan village in Junagadh district on Thursday.

“We had received a tip-off that a truck was going to unload a large supply of IMFL bottles in Dervan village where bootleggers were supposed to gather to divide their share of liquor bottles,” said B H Korat, sub-inspector with Junagadh taluka police station.

However before the raid, the bootleggers appeared to have got a whiff of the police action and fled from the spot. The police arrested the truck driver, identified as Pravin Dahia (32) and the truck cleaner, Sandeep Dahia (35) from the spot.

During their interrogation, the accused said that the liquor supply had been unloaded on to the truck by two Haryana-based bootleggers identified Bijendra and Bhupendra.

“The accused said that Bijendra and Bhupendra had asked them to give them a call after reaching Junagadh to take further instructions,” added Korat.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Man gets trampled to death by own bull
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

KRISHNAGIRI: A 40-year-old man died after his own bull stamped him to death during a ‘bull dance’ event near Anchetty in Krishnagiri district on Thursday.

The deceased farmer has been identified as P Murugan, of Vannathipatty village near Anchetty.

On Thursday, he went with his bull to participate in the bull dance.

It is learnt that his bull suddenly ran amok after hearing the beating of drums.

“The bull started running here and there,” said a police official from Anchetty police station.

“When Murugan attempted to bring the bull under his control, it knocked him down. He sustained injuries on the chest when the bull stamped him,” the official added.

Fellow villagers rushed him to the government hospital in Anchetty for treatment.

Doctors who examined him confirmed he was brought dead.

A case was registered by Anchetty police and further inquiry is on.

Title: ‘Anandi Gopal’ wins big at home, Tunisian film draws top honours
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Pune: The period piece Anandi Gopal and the coming-of-age drama Tujhya Aaila were big winners in the Marathi Competition category of the Pune International Film Festival (PIFF). The Tunisian film A Son bagged the top honour in the World Competition.

The awardees were announced at the ceremony held at the National Film Archive of India (NFAI) on Thursday, which marked the end of this year’s edition of PIFF. All jury members, Malini Fonseka, Dubravka Lakic, Mazhar Kamran, Rajula Shah, Istvan Kovacs, Vishka Assayesh, Lutz Konnerman, and Marie-Pierre Bretas, were present during the ceremony. Veteran actor Vikram Gokhale and sound designer Bishwadeep Chatterjee gave away the awards.

The jury at this year’s festival adjudged films both in the World and Marathi Competition sections, unlike last year. Besides the awards for the best film and director in both sections, the organizers gave away special mentions and jury awards, as well as acting, screenplay, and cinematography awards only for Marathi films.

Mehdi Barsaoui’s film A Son was adjudged the Best International Film of the festival. Bartosz Kruhlik was named the Best Director for the film Supernova. The actor Wagner Moura’s directorial debut Marighella was awarded a special mention. Moura is better known for playing Pablo Escobar in the Netflix drama Narcos.

Sujay Dahake’s film Tujhya Aaila, which deals with abuse that children hear and the ways in which they navigate the situation, got a special jury award apart from awards for cinematography and screenplay for Vijay Mishra and Niyaz Mujawar.

Anandi Gopal, a film about one of the first female doctors in the Indian subcontinent, won the top honour as the Best Film. The award is named after Sant Tukaram and sponsored by the government of Maharashtra. Lalit Prabhakar, who played Anandibai’s husband Gopal in the film, also won the Best Actor award. He said that the process of ‘unlearning’ for his role was a daunting challenge.

“For researching my role, I read the letters that Gopal Joshi had written during his lifetime. Those letters brought out a lot of things, like his views and his personality. There was also the task of unlearning a lot of things. It was back in the 1800s, and there was a way in which people styled themselves and spoke. I had to make sure that while acting, none of my current trappings came in the way,” Prabhakar said.

Mukta Barve took home the Best Actress award for her role in the film Y. That film’s director Ajit Wadikar bagged the Best Director award.

Title: Rescued leopard dies on way to Manikdoh
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Pimpri Chinchwad: An injured two-year-old male leopard died soon after being rescued from Randhe village in Parner taluka of Ahmednagar district on Tuesday.

Ashvini Dighe, range forest officer, Parner, told TOI, “The leopard died while being taken to the leopard rescue centre (LRC) in Manikdoh in Junnar taluka of Pune district.”

GB Waghmare, additional charge of round forest officer, Vadzire, said, “Villagers informed us about sighting an injured leopard around 2pm on Tuesday. The animal was unable to stand on its feet. We left for Manikdoh around 5pm. The leopard, however, died on the way. The post-mortem was conducted on Wednesday.”

SR Bhor, livestock development officer, veterinary dispensary at Alkute, said, “The animal’s post-mortem was performed around 8.30am on Wednesday. The front paws of the leopard were injured and had deep bite marks. There were injury marks on the neck and the lower jaw. It was most probably injured in a fight with another bigger male leopard.”

Title: This teacher of tribal school grooms students, washes their clothes
Content:
S Ayyappan saw that the children were unkempt and weren't groomed properly. So, he took upon himself to give t... Read More

The job profile of S Ayyappan, a 34-year-old assistant teacher at the Government Residential School for tribal children at Lingamavur in Udumalpet, Tirupur, is to teach the 23 tribal children in class

COIMBATORE: The job profile of S Ayyappan , a 34-year-old assistant teacher at the Government Residential School for tribal children at Lingamavur in Udumalpet, Tirupur, is to teach the 23 tribal children in class. However, he doesn’t stop with that. He also grooms them and washes their clothes .The teacher, who joined the school in October 2018, says when he first saw the children, they were unkempt and weren’t groomed properly.“All through the year, the children stay at the school hostel and go home only during festivals such as Diwali or Pongal. Their parents come to visit them once a month. When I asked them why they weren’t groomed, they would say their parents had found no work and couldn’t visit them to take them out for a haircut,” he says.It was then that Ayyappan took upon himself to give the students their regular haircut. “When I was young, I had learnt to cut my own hair. With that practice, I started giving haircuts to my students,” he says.There are 12 boys and 11 girls in the school, aged five to 10 years. They are studying in classes I to V. The children belong to tribes such as Irulars and Kadars from Thirumoorthy Malai, Udumalai, Valparai and Anamalai. Their parents work as labourers in farms or tea estates. The school was started in 1997.Earlier, the students used to wash their clothes on the bathroom floor. Ayyappan, with the help of the school headmaster M Pandi, built a washing stone in the campus.“But even then, the kids were playful and didn’t wash their clothes properly. So, I started washing their clothes,” adds the teacher.Ayyappan did his schooling from Ramakrishna Ashram’s Children’s Home at Pallapalayam in Coimbatore. “There, we had to take monthly turns in doing ashram work, such as puja, cooking, tending to cattle, etc. This instilled a sense of service in me, because of which I want to help my students,” he says. Ayyappan credits his Class XII teacher Murugesan who helped him pursue teacher training at the institute of education training in Kotagiri.Pandi says Ayyappan is the first teacher he has seen who does so much for the students. “Because of his approach, students’ behaviour too has improved in class. His friendly and helpful nature have made students behave well and pay attention in classes,” says the headmaster.

Title: Advisory body set up for organ transplants
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Panaji: The state health secretary will chair the advisory committee, comprising head of the department of urology, Dr Madhumohan Prabhdesai, transplant nephrologist Dr Shital Lengade, Sandip Naik of the Matruchaya Trust and , former judge of the high court justice (Rtd) Avinash Lawande among others, to advise the government on organ transplantation.

Goa Medical College has been conducting living- donor kidney transplants. After the the state organ tissue transplant organisation is set up, GMC will be equipped to retrieve and transplant kidneys and other organs from deceased donors as well. TNN

Title: Govt to hold joint session of assembly and council
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Amaravati: The state government has decided to clear the bills proposed to repeal AP CRDA Act and The AP Decentralisation and Equal Development of All Regions Act, 2020 through a joint session of the assembly and council on January 22.

The decision has been taken keeping in view of TDP’s majority in the Upper House which is most likely to veto the bills proposed by the government. The joint session will bring the uncertainty over the capital city to an end despite uproarious protests in Amaravati.

The state government has already decided to convene the special session of the assembly on January 20 and council on January 21. Although YSRC could get through the bills in the assembly thanks to its massive majority in the House, the bills are likely to be turned down by the Council where TDP has numbers to dictate terms.

As per the procedure, the bills vetoed by the council would again go to the assembly for reconsideration. The bill will once again go to the council after ratification by the assembly.

Although the council could not reject the bill for second time, the government does not want to wait for the process to get completed.

With a view to avoid delay in clearing the bills which chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy wanted to rush through, the government is contemplating to convene the joint session of the assembly and council on January 22.

In such case, the government could easily sail through the voting as it has bumper majority if the numbers of both the Houses are taken into count.

YSRC political strategists took the recent experience where the TDP dominated council rejected the bill to introduce English medium in government schools even after it was cleared by the assembly during the winter session.

“We have our own strategy to get the bills cleared. People gave us mandate to take the decisions that benefits the larger sections of the state. We will not disappoint anyone except the gangs working with vested interests and are headed by Chandrababu Naidu,” said chief whip Gadikota Srikanth Reddy.

Title: Missing women affirm affidavits
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Ahmedabad: After affirming their affidavits first from Virginia in the US and St Michael in Barbados, the two missing women from Nithyananda ashram have affirmed their affidavits before the Indian high commission in Jamaica.

The affidavits were tendered before the Gujarat high court on Thursday in response to the habeas corpus petition filed by the father of the women. The HC was not satisfied with the affidavits filed on two earlier occasions and had suggested that the court may take them into consideration, only if they are affirmed before the Indian high commission.

However, the girl’s father vehemently opposed the affidavits and raised questions on their authenticity. It was suggested on his behalf that such affidavits should be verified by an Indian embassy, for his daughters appeared to have been coerced to sign the affidavits.

The father’s advocate reiterated that her daughters’ lives are in danger and they should be asked to appear personally before the court and express their wish. The father has been claiming that Nithyananda and his associates have forcibly detained his daughters and illegally sent his younger daughter (19) to an island in the West Indies via Nepal in November last year after he demanded custody of his three children living in the Ahmedabad ashram.

In the third batch of affidavits also, the petitioner’s daughters rejected their father’s claim that they have been detained forcibly.

Title: Absconding, loot and murder accused nabbed from Khambhalia
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Accused in police custody

Rajkot: An absconding loot and murder accused was nabbed near Khambhalia of Devbhoomi Dwarka district on Wednesday.

Police said the accused, identified as Navaz Detha, had allegedly bludgeoned Allarakha Bhati to death in Pirlakhasar village of Khambhalia taluka last year.

Detha had allegedly committed the murder along with his friend Gulab Qureshi.

After Qureshi came to know that Bhati was carrying cash, he hatched the loot and murder conspiracy with Detha. Both attacked Bhati with bats and iron pipes, killing him on the spot. They hid Bhati’s body in the bushes near a river and had looted Rs 4,000 cash from his pocket.

Besides this, Detha had stolen 20 metre long cable wire worth Rs 12,000 from a windmill in Shethakhai village of Bhanwad taluka in Devbhoomi Dwarka district, three years ago.

“We had received a tip-off that Detha was going towards Pirlakhasar village from Khambhalia on his two-wheeler, following which we kept a watch there and nabbed him,” said M D Chandrawadia, inspector with Devbhoomi Dwarka local crime branch.

Title: Hit-and-run case: Forensic team examines car for clues
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Police sources said preliminary examination of the vehicle did not yield any evidence that the vehicle was inv... Read More

Thiruvananthapuram: On Thursday, a forensic team examined the brown Maruti Suzuki Estilo that was allegedly involved in a hit-and-run accident near Sasthamangalam that killed two persons at 9pm on December 29. Police sources said that preliminary examination of the vehicle did not yield any evidence that the vehicle was involved in an accident.

“Prima facie, the car appears to be in good condition and there were no dents or damages that could happen due to a collision,” said an officer who is part of the probe team. The car belongs to Sadanandan (47), a clerical staff of Raj Bhavan, who stays in the staff quarters. On Wednesday, police had confiscated his car.

The forensic team has not drawn conclusions from spot examination. Since the car was tracked down after over two weeks, there is still the possibility of the owner carrying out repair works. Hence a detailed scientific examination will be conducted to ascertain that angle and the team collected evidence from the car for the purpose.

Online food delivery executive Abdul Rahim (44) from Nedumangad and Aditya B Manoj (21) from Sasthamangalam were killed in the accident. While Abdul Rahim, who was standing on the side of the road, died on the spot, Aditya, who was riding a motorcycle, died on January 10 after battling for his life in a hospital.

Police are yet to comprehend the sequence of events that led to the accident. A car was seen on CCTV as it stopped momentarily at the accident spot and later disappeared mysteriously as onlookers were busy trying to get the injured to a hospital. They only remembered a brown Estilo.

Police found the car after compiling a list of 1,600 Zen Estilo cars registered in city. Police filtered the list down to those registered near Vellayambalam and Sasthamangalam region and finally located it. Sadanandan was then summoned to Museum police station for questioning on Wednesday.

During questioning, Sadanandan claimed that his vehicle was not involved in the accident and that he had heard a loud noise while passing the spot, on December 29. He then slowed down his car and saw the mishap. A passerby had then accused him of causing the accident. He claimed that he explained the sequence of events to that person and that person let him go. Police have not registered a case against Sadanandan as his role in the accident is yet to be ascertained.

Title: Japan company invests Rs 100 crore in plant near Coimbatore
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: Hirotec Group, a Japan-based firm which manufactures automotive assembly welding fixtures, hemming, stamping dyes and sheet metal parts, inaugurated a new facility at its plant in Keeranatham near the city on Thursday. The new facility would produce stamping dyes for the automobile industry across the country.

A release said a total investment of Rs 100crore is being made, of which Rs 35crore will be dedicated to infrastructure and Rs 65crore for machinery.

Within the next 10 years, additional investment of Rs 140crore would be put into the facility, which would meet the growing demand for stamping dyes from car manufacturers across the country, said the release.

The 7,400square metre facility would give additional employment to 150 people, it added.

The release quoted Nori Uno, president of Hirotec Group, saying that the group has “plans for continued investments in India and aims to achieve an annual manufacturing capacity of 100 dyes by 2025.”

Title: Coimbatore: Four arrested for selling imported liquor in black market
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representational image

COIMBATORE: The prohibition enforcement wing (PEW) of the city police has arrested four people - a manager and three sales executives of a duty free shop at the city airport - at Kalapatti for selling imported liquor bottles illegally. Police have seized 64 liqour bottles from them.

Police said the accused, R Jeevanantham, 29, o Kulithalai in Karur district, A Rajanbabu, 41, of Chennai, S Siraj, 24, of Thrissur in Kerala and Kebin, 30, of Nagarcoil in Kanyakumari district, were selling the liqour bottles at an exorbitant price from a bakery at Nehru Nagar in Kalapatti. They were booked under sections of the Tamil Nadu Prohibition Act.

Acting on a tip, sub-inspector of police Kandasamy and his team conducted a raid near the bakery on Wednesday. They found the bottles and arrested Jeevanantham, Rajanbabu and Siraj. Kebin was held on Thursday. All the four were let off on station bail. Further investigation is on.

Title: Digambar’s CAA comments hate speech: BJP
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Margao: BJP has taken strong exception to a statement made by Margao MLA Digambar Kamat at a recent anti-CAA(Citizenship (Amendment) Act) protest rally held at Lohia maidan here to the effect that the government has amended the Constitution by linking citizenship to religion. It has also objected to the “hate speech” and a similar statement by retired IAS officer Aravind Bhatikar at the same meeting.

“This misleading conduct by the Margao MLA was a deliberate attempt to misguide and divide people over the CAA 2019, by terming it as an ‘amendment in the Indian Constitution’,” general secretary,Margao BJP mandal Navin Raikar said, accusing the opposition of creating confusion that can spark communal tension.

Title: Coimbatore: Decked up cows, native games are part of Mattu Pongal festival
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Farmers lead cattle through Kalayam, an earthen structure filled with coins, ornaments, kumkum mixed water and... Read More

COIMBATORE: People thronged CODISSIA grounds to celebrate Mattu Pongal in a traditional way in the city on Thursday.

The celebrations, which were organized by Nayam, an event planner, included traditional games like Aadupuchi Attam, Uriyadithal, Vazhuku Maram, Silambam and Malutham as well as traditional dances like Parai, Parai Thapattai, Karagam and Mylattam.

Several people, who could not visit their native towns or villages, took their children to the venue to show them traditional ways of Pongal celebrations. “The organizers allowed individuals to participate in games like pambaram and tug of war. This is better than children sitting in front of the television the whole day,” said D Sriram, who brought five children from his family. A livestock exhibition was also conducted at the venue.

People living in the western parts of the district brought their children to the Madeshwaran temple opposite to the Aavin office on Thadagam Road. They witnessed hundreds of dairy farmers bringing their cows in a long procession to the temple to offer their prayers. Many of the cows were decorated with vermillion and sandal paste rubbed on their back and forehead. Large “Nandhi” idol on the temple was also decked with sandal, turmeric and several tonnes of fruits.

Families with cows decorated their cattle and offered prayers to them, thanking them for the livelihood and milk they provide and praying for their fertility.

Farmers began the day by giving their cows and calves a bath early in the morning, rubbing the cow and bull’s bodies with turmeric and kumkum and painting the bulls’ horns in colours of red, orange and blue. “While we wrap silk scarves on bull’s horns, we put them on cows, as we believe silk bring bountiful prosperity to cattle,” said T Murugan, a farmer from Thondamuthur.

Title: BJP lying to hide its failures, says Delhi deputy CM Manish Sisodia
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Manish Sisodia

Title: Mastermind of gang involved in burglaries in Coimbatore district arrested
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: One of the masterminds of a gang involved in series of burglaries in Thudiyalur and surrounding areas in Coimbatore district was arrested by the Mannuthy police in Thrissur district , Kerala, on Wednesday.

The mastermind, Pattarai Suresh, of Madurai , was arrested based on inputs given by one of the gang members, K Rajasekar, 38, of Azhagapuram in Salem.

Rajasekar was arrested last month by the Thudiyalur police and recovered 124.5 sovereigns of gold ornaments and 4kg of silver articles from him. During inquiry, Rajasekar also named Sullan Suresh as the other mastermind of the gang. Three police teams were formed to nab the gang members.

Preliminary inquiries revealed that Pattarai Suresh and his gang members robbed an elderly couple in Mannuthy police limit. Following the arrest of Pattarai Suresh, a team from Thudiyalur police visited Thrissur to conduct inquiry with him.

One of the gang members, Pulipandi from Tenkasi, was arrested a few days ago by the Tenkasi police and he was lodged at the central prison in Palayamkottai. The Thudiyalur police have planned to take Pulipandi into custody soon.

The gang members broke open a house and looted 167 sovereigns of gold ornaments from the house at Vellakinar Pirivu on July 21, 2019, and they managed to escape in a car.

When the police tried to trace the car, they abandoned the vehicle. In the same month, the gang broke open a house and looted 56 sovereigns of gold ornaments.

On November 19, the gang had broken into a house of building contractor, K Kanagraj, 59, at Luna Nagar near Kavundampalayam and decamped with 134 sovereigns of gold ornaments and Rs 15 lakh cash.

Title: Two UP power corporation officials booked for embezzlement
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

MEERUT: Two power corporation officials posted in Hapur have been booked for embezzlement of Rs 65 lakh. The crime came to light after an audit of 2018 power bill collection data. It was revealed how two Technical Grade 2 officials-- Praveen Sharma and Sanjeev Kumar-- had not deposited the sum in the treasury despite collecting dues after manipulating grid software system using their IDs.

This comes months after 29 UP power corporation officials were suspended in May last year after an inquiry found them guilty of embezzling Rs 3.68 crores of the power dues deposited by consumers in Baghpat division.

Deputy SP of Garh Mukteshwar, Tejveer Singh, said, “The total amount embezzled is close to Rs 65 lakhs and on the police complaint of executive engineer’s office, an FIR has been lodged against the two Technical Grade 2 officials under IPC sec 409 (Criminal breach of trust by public servant).”

Title: Onion prices down to Rs 60, likely to normalise next week
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Panaji: Onion prices have dropped to Rs 60 per kg from Rs 80 in the retail market on Thursday.

It could drop further by 50% in the next two weeks as the winter harvest of the crop has resulted in arrivals from Maharashtra and Karnataka, vendors said.

“The rates are likely to fall further in the coming days and are likely to even reach Rs 40 per kg. Onions imported from Turkey are still coming into the market and selling at Rs 40 as of now,” said a vegetable vendor from the Panaji municipal market. At the government-run horticulture outlets, onion rates had started falling from Rs 67 to 63 last week and had come down to Rs 50-51 this week.“Onion rates will see a downward trend from now on. Prices are expected to normalise from next week onwards. Our suppliers from Belagavi are also optimistic about supplying larger quantities of onion to Goa,” managing director, Goa State Horticulture Corporation Ltd (GSHCL) Sandeep Faldesai said.

At the GSHCL outlet located at Altinho, horticulture manager Prasad Haldankar said after two months of scrimping during the shortage, consumers were going back to their old purchase patterns, picking up two to three kgs of the bulbs again.

Title: Mastermind of gang involved in burglaries in Coimbatore district arrested
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: One of the masterminds of a gang involved in series of burglaries in Thudiyalur and surrounding areas in Coimbatore district was arrested by the Mannuthy police in Thrissur district , Kerala, on Wednesday.

Title: Meerut: Man found dead in nursing college hostel
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

MEERUT: A body of an unidentified man was found in suspicious circumstances on the first floor of family wing hostel at College of Nursing in the premises of Lala Lajpat Rai Memorial (LLRM) Medical College on Thursday afternoon. The room where the body was found was not allotted to anybody and the matter came to fore when a few electricians working here opened the room.

In a letter informing the superintendent in chief, LLRM Medical College, Sunita Gupta, hostel warden, College of Nursing, said, “I want to inform you that I got to know at 3pm on Thursday that a body was lying in room number 1 on the first floor of family wing. This room is not allotted to any person.”

The matter was immediately brought to the notice of police and the body was sent for post-mortem. Kulveer Singh, station house officer, Medical College police station, said, “Prima facie, the man looks like a rag picker who might have entered the room and died there due to some attack or stroke. However, we will have better clarity about the matter once the post-mortem report is here. The body has been sent for post-mortem and an investigation has been set up in the matter.”

Title: Cold wave sweeps Gujarat, Ahmedabad shivers at 9.6 degree Celsius
Content:
Biting cold winds forced citizens to get snug under blankets, in warm jackets and shawls.

AHMEDABAD: Biting cold winds forced citizens to get snug under blankets, in warm jackets and shawls, as the daytime temperature in the city fell to 22.7°C, a good 5.2 degrees below normal on Thursday. The minimum temperature was 9.6°C, 2.5 degrees below normal.Weather officials said cold wave conditions are prevailing over the state, especially in Saurashtra-Kutch and parts of central Gujarat such as Ahmedabad, Gandhinagar, Deesa and Vadodara.“Cold wave conditions are likely to prevail in the state over the next two days, Friday and Saturday. The minimum temperature is likely to be below 10°C in many parts of the state,” a weather official forecast.Officials said a cyclonic circulation is currently lying over south-east Rajasthan and adjacent parts of Madhya Pradesh.On Thursday, the mercury dipped below 10°C in many parts of the state at night. Naliya was the coldest place in the state with a minimum temperature of 5.8°C. The state capital Gandhinagar recorded a minimum temperature of 10°C.The sudden dip in temperatures and cold winds forced people to stay indoors especially in the early mornings and late at night.“It was extremely cold in the morning and I was forced to cancel my morning walk,” said Trupti Patel, a resident of Satellite. She said women in her neighbourhood also cancelled their outdoor yoga exercises due to the biting cold. Doctors advised that people protect from exposure to the chilly winds and reschedule morning or evening walks to when the sun is still up.

Title: Pawan lacks clarity of thought, says Ambati
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Amaravati: Stating that Pawan Kalyan has once again proved that he has neither stability nor clarity, YSRC legislator Ambati Rambabu questioned why Pawan Kalyan joined hands with BJP without fighting for Special Category Status (SCS).

He said Pawan, who changed alliances many times in his brief political career, had no moral right to criticize the YSRC government the state.

Speaking to reporters here on Thursday, he said the YSRC was not bothered about the BJP-Jana Sena alliance as such partnerships were very common during elections and people were clever enough not to be fooled by these tactics. He, however, said that Pawan Kalyan had the moral responsibility of explaining to the people why he had joined hands with BJP without fighting for the SCS. He lashed out at Pawan for his comments against the state government.

Title: CET’s 1970 batch moots steps to celebrate golden jubilee
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

gratitude: The celebration of golden jubilee of the 1970 batch began with a ‘Gurupooja’ where former professor... Read More

Thiruvananthapuram: Students from the 1970 batch of College of Engineering, Trivandrum are celebrating their alumni’s golden jubilee year. The celebration, named Mahasangamam , began with a ‘ Gurupooja ’ where former professors of CET were honoured. The celebrations were inaugurated by former Isro chairman G Madhavan Nair at 3pm on Thursday.

“The contribution of our batch — in terms of academics, sports and cultural activities — were significant to the growth of CET as a pioneering educational institution in our country. So instead of merely celebrating the golden jubilee year of our batch, we thought of doing something unique and productive for our college. Only through such deeds we can be remembered by our college,” said S Gopakumar, an alumnus of the batch.

On July 25, CET will honour these students at the college. “As a part of the celebration, we decided to sponsor the studies of students belonging to economically-weaker sections of the society and support researches that are conducted for recycling plastic. Along with that, we are suggesting the reuse of debris from Maradu flat demolition to build blocks, interlocking tiles and fences,” he said.

The batchmates will stay at a resort in Kovalam with their families to reminisce and relive their college days. “All of us are well over 72 and now we are guided by memories. The college administration told us that they are ready to give us a stage every month as the college is also celebrating its 80th year. We will be organizing programmes every month along with other alumni associations, which will be beneficial to students as well as the faculty,” he said. Out of 240 students belonging to five different batches of 1970, only 180 are alive.

Title: Borrower who attempted suicide 3 months ago dies
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Rajkot: Harassed by two loan sharks , the man , who had consumed acid near Pradyumannagar police station in Rajkot on October 10 last year, died on Thursday.

After the death of Bharat Bhaktani (22), police booked Sagar Valecha and Mustaq Khiyani for the abetment of suicide.

“We booked Valecha and Khiyani on the complaint of Bhaktani’s mother Lajvanti, who alleged that the accused were pressurizing Bhaktani for the recovery of the interest on Rs 60,000 loan he had taken from them,” said an official from Pradyumannagar police station.

According to Lajvanti’s complaint, both Valecha and Khiyani had threatened to kill Bhaktani, if he did not pay the amount. This prompted Lajvanti to approach the police.

“When Lajvanti went to Pradyumannagar police station along with Bhaktani, both Valecha and Khiyani came after her and pressurized her not to lodge the complaint against them on October 10 last year. It was at this time that Bhaktani took out an acid bottle from the boot of his two-wheeler and consumed its content,” added the official.

Meanwhile, the cops have launched a manhunt for Velecha and Khiyani.

Title: Amdavadi stars top CA Finals at first attempt
Content: Ahmedabad: In the CA final exam results announced on Thursday for the exams held in November last year, five students from Ahmedabad were in All India Top 50. For the old syllabus, the Ahmedabad centre reported 23.72% success rate which was higher than 10.19% success pan India.Similarly, for the new syllabus, the Ahmedabad centre reported 23.43% success against 15.12% in all India.It was their first attempt for all students in the Top 50.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: In a first, SIT books 33 for provoking children to pelt stones
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representational image

MUZAFFARNAGAR: Special Investigation Team (SIT) probing the cases of violence during the anti-CAA protests have booked 33 jailed protestors for allegedly provoking children to throw stones at policemen during the clashes. The probe agency has invoked sections of Juvenile Justice (Care And Protection of Children) Act, 2015 against the accused. All the 33 accused were earlier charged under various sections of the IPC and sent to jail.

Several new offences committed against children, which are so far not adequately covered under any other law, are included in the

Juvenile Justice (Care And Protection of Children) Act, 2015. These include use of children by militant groups, sale and procurement of children for any purpose including illegal adoption and offences against disabled children.

The SIT got the permission to slap the additional charge on the 33 accused from chief judicial magistrate Ravikant Yadav’s court.

“SIT has added an extra section of the Juvenile Justice Act, 2015, against 33 offenders of the violence,” said Wakar Ahmad, a lawyer who is fighting cases of some of the accused of the violence which erupted on December 20 last year in Muzaffarnagar.

During the clashes, several minors were seen throwing stones at the policemen and vandalizing properties.

According to police, as many as 47 cases were registered at Nagar Kotwali and Civil Lines police stations, in which more than 250 people were named. Police have arrested more than 80 people so far in the matter.

Another senior lawyer Chandraveer Singh said that the sections of the Juvenile Act, 2015 were invoked as there was no such provision in the Indian Penal Code (IPC) to book people for such offences.

Title: Coimbatore: SACON event for students to be held on Sunday
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

COIMBATORE: The Salim Ali Centre for Ornithology and Natural History (SACON) is conducting their annual Salim Ali Trophy Nature competition on Sunday. The competition will test students knowledge on environment, birds and ability to identify various species, among others.

The competition will consist of elocution, essay writing, poetry writing, story writing (both in English and Tamil), painting, pencil drawing and nature quiz. This year, it will also include a unique competition—bird watching or ‘spot the bird’. The winner in this category would be declared the young bird watcher of the year. The topics for the competitions will be given on the spot to test the student’s spontaneity, knowledge and skill. Students in the first three positions in every competition will fetch points for their schools. The school with the highest points will become the champion of the year.

Title: Pawan Kalyan: Jana Sena Party president Pawan Kalyan defends BJP on NRC, CAA
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Jana Sena Party chief Pawan Kalyan. (ANI photo)

VIJAYAWADA: Extending support to BJP on the National Register of Citizens and Citizenship Amendment Act, Jana Sena president Pawan Kalyan on Thursday said political parties were creating fear among people.

He said there was no threat to Indian Muslims with the new laws initiated by the Centre. Speaking to media here on Thursday, Pawan said the Citizenship Amendment Act was brought to give citizenship to minorities persecuted in neighbouring countries. “India was never declared as a Hindu nation. Hindu minorities in Pakistan and Bangladesh are facing torture and the CAA has been brought to provide citizenship to such people who migrated to India under fear,” said Pawan.

Kalyan said there was no truth that Indian Muslims would lose citizenship with the CAA and NRC. He said that the controversy about the CAA and NRC was unnecessary.

The Jana Sena president said Prime Minister Narendra Modi and BJP president Amit Shah were taking the nation into growth corridor. Explaining his U-turn on his fight against the BJP-led Centre on the Special Category Status (SCS), Pawan said the TDP leadership had committed a blunder by agreeing to the special package to ignore the SCS.

Pawan also criticized YSRC’s three-capital cities theory saying that no one would call a city as capital because it hosts the high court. He said it was a diversionary tactic.

He said that he had found fault with the TDP regime when it pooled 33,000 acre for the capital city. Pawan promised to uproot casteism from politics in the state. He said Jana Sena was ready to work with BJP .

Title: BJP slams Bezos-owned daily for anti-Modi stand
Content:
Mr @JeffBezos , please tell this to your employees in Washington DC. Otherwise your charm offensive is likely to be… https://t.co/YyZpUY7PBB — Dr Vijay Chauthaiwale (@vijai63) 1579171599000

NEW DELHI: On the day commerce minister Piyush Goyal made light of Jeff Bezos’s offer to invest $1 billion in India, a prominent BJP functionary chose to make plain the saffron establishment’s displeasure with Washington Post, the influential US daily owned by the Amazon boss.“Mr Jeff Bezos, please tell this to your employees in Washington DC. Otherwise, your charm offensive is likely to be a waste of money,” tweeted Vijay Chauthaiwale , head of BJP’s foreign cell.The tweet reflected the indignation of the government and BJP over what they called the “relentless hostility” the Modi government had faced from Washington Post and other “liberal” foreign media outlets since the revocation of J&K’s special status in August.When approached, Chauthaiwale made no bones of his displeasure with Washington Post, but maintained that it would have no bearing on how the government deals with Amazon. “I am not against Amazon. In fact, I am a regular customer of Amazon. But I am certainly against the one-sided, biased, agenda-driven anti-Modi editorial position of Washington Post,” he said.He also said he wanted to highlight the huge chasm between Bezos’s praise for India as a vibrant democracy and the dark portrayal of the country on the pages of Washington Post.

Title: Ahmedabad-Mumbai Tejas Express to be flagged off today
Content:
The second Tejas express in the country — from Ahmedabad to Mumbai — will be flagged off today.

AHMEDABAD: The second Tejas express in the country — from Ahmedabad to Mumbai — will be flagged off by the Union railway and commerce minister Piyush Goyal and Gujarat chief minister, Vijay Rupani from Ahmedabad today. It will run simultaneously in the opposite direction to Shatabdi express. The commercial run of the train will start from Sunday from Ahmedabad, the railways said.There will be no tatkal quota or premium tatkal quota in the train. There will be only general quota and foreign tourist quota. Foreign tourist quota of 6 seats in EC and 12 seats in CC will be available for foreign tourists. Besides travel insurance, IRCTC will pay each passenger a compensation of Rs 100 in case the train is delayed by more than one hour and Rs 250 in case of delay of more than two hours.The Tejas Express will be operated by the Indian Railway Catering and Tourism Corporation (IRCTC). The airconditioned train will run six days a week, except on Thursdays. According to schedule, the train will leave Ahmedabad at 6.40am and reach Mumbai Central railway station at 1.10pm., covering the entire distance of 533 km in 6 hours and 30 minutes.The train will have six halts including Nadiad, Vadodara, Bharuch, Surat, Vapi and Borivali. On its return journey, the train will leave Mumbai Central at 3.40pm and reach Ahmedabad at 9.55pm. In October, the IRCTC started the first Tejas Express between Lucknow and New Delhi.Tejas will have an executive class airconditioned chair car with 56 seats and nine airconditioned coaches. The train will have tea and coffee vending machines along with CCTV cameras, LED TV, and automatic doors.Th train fare will be dynamic keeping in consideration the prevailing bus, taxi, rail and airfares. Train fares will be on point-to-point basis. Current bookings will be available after preparation of first chart, which will normally be between four hours before and up to five minutes before the scheduled departure of the train. Passengers travelling on the IRCTC train will get rail travel insurance of up to Rs 25 lakh free of extra cost. This complimentary travel insurance also includes an exclusive coverage of Rs. 1 lakh against theft or robbery during the travel period of the passengers.

Title: Silver jubilee of Yuva Mahotsav to witness new platforms for talent
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Margao: The 25th edition of Goa Yuva Mahotsav organised by Konkani Bhasha Mandal (KBM), which will kick off on Friday at Ravindra Bhavan in Margao, will witness a mammoth congregation of youngsters from across the state. Chief minister Pramod Sawant will be the chief guest at the inaugural session to be held at 11.30am.

KBM’s Anwesha Singbal said that altogether 39 educational institutions have registered for the 3-day event. “While there will be a direct participation of over 2,500 youth, we expect a crowd of over 10,000 young people,” she said.

As this year marks the festival’s silver jubilee, the organisers have introduced a new programme ‘Yuva Nakhetra’ which will see past participants of the Mahotsav unleash their talents, it was informed.

Pradip Kakodkar, a chartered accountant, who had participated in several such festivals since its inception, says the event provides participants a new perspective about Goa’s rich social and cultural heritage. “Looking back, I can say with pride that only after stepping on the stage of Goa Yuva Mahotsav, I got a better understanding and developed affection towards the diverse aspects of Goa’s vibrant culture, history, heritage, folk art, etc,” Kakodkar said.

Reminiscing about the various agitations he participated in over the years, along with his co-participants at the mahotsav, Kakodkar points out to one such protest staged by Goa Hitrakhan Manch, where they cornered and confronted the then post master general into withdrawing a circular that would have harmed the prospects of Goans seeking employment in the postal service. “I remember the post master general called me up at 2am to say that she is withdrawing the circular,” Kakodkar says.

Nevertheless, the mahotsav has also attracted criticism, particularly from veterans of the Konkani movement. They argue that while the mahotsavs of late have lent a celebratory dimension to the Konkani movement, these have failed to build a strong youth force that would take to the streets to fight for the cause of Konkani as and when needed.

Dinesh Manerkar, who was closely associated with the event during its initial years, counters the criticism. “The youth festival has succeeded for the last 24 years in keeping the talents of Goan youth alive. Today’s educational system is so rigid that students are burdened with their internal exams and attendance,” he says.

“The Yuva Mahotsav has no doubt created a revolution,” Kakodkar says, “but the event should result in creating a strong young leadership that will take up the issues concerning Goa long after the curtains are drawn on the event.”

Title: Lokotsav turns 750kg wet waste into compost daily
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Panaji: Around 750kg of wet waste and 1,500kg of dry waste is generated every day of the Lokotsav. Keeping in mind the volume of waste generated, this year, the festival has introduced a waste management project in a step towards solving the garbage issue.

Here, the wet waste is directly fed into the processor unit built into a mobile van to be processed into organic material, while the dry waste is segregated into seven categories before being handed over to the Corporation of the City of Panaji (CCP).

“This is an attempt at making the festival a zero-waste event. The wet waste will be converted into compost to be distributed among farmers through the directorate of agriculture,” said Ashok Parab, deputy director, directorate of art and culture (DAC).

Having bagged the event-planning contract this year, Fusion Events suggested to the DAC to make the festival a zero-waste event. The event management team then reached out to Indore-based Swaaha Resource Management Pvt Ltd to execute the project.

The team has executed this project at various events in Indore. “The biggest event, however, was the Bohra-community festival Ashara Mubaraka in 2018, wherein we processed 25 tonnes of wet waste per day on site. Over the course of the 10-day festival, 250 tonnes of organic waste was converted into compost. This was then handed over to the farmers of the Bohra community,” said Rohit Aggarwal, director, Swaaha. The mobile processor unit has a capacity of processing 2,000kg of wet waste per day in eight-hour shifts. At the Lokotsav, the unit operates for two to three hours per day to process the 750-odd kg wet waste into compost.

The dry waste is segregated into plastic bottles, glass bottles, polythene bags, paper cups, newspapers, cardboard, tetra packs and tin cans. Around five people segregate dry waste while one person manages the mobile wet waste processor.

“A truck from CCP comes to the festival venue twice a day to collect the segregated dry waste,” Aggarwal said.

Title: Cockfighting menace makes way into north AP
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The menace of cockfighting, once confined to the twin Godavari districts, made its way into northern Andhra Pradesh this Sankranti. The blood sport was hosted across Visakhapatnam, Vizianagaram and Srikakulam this year.

In Visakhapatnam, the police busted 25 cockfights between January 10 and January 16. Over 60 roosters were seized and Rs 5 lakh cash was confiscated as the police arrested more than 60 people in course of their raids.

Senior police official A Trinad Rao said that people managed to organise cockfights in some places across Visakhapatnam despite police raids and warnings.

Cockfighting is an illegal blood sport where knives are tied around the necks of roosters as they fight each other to death while people place bets. A fighting rooster sold for Rs 5,000 to Rs 8,000 this Sankranti season.

T Anil Kumar, a punter said that fights between black roosters and black and red roosters drew the biggest crowd and bets ranging from Rs 25,000 to Rs 50,000 were placed on each fight in Vizianagaram district.

Title: ‘Use civil disobedience to protest CAA’
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Margao: Human rights activist from Gujarat, Fr Cedric Prakash on Thursday called upon the people to resort to “civil disobedience” by refusing to divulge details if and when government authorities come to them demanding evidence of their Indian citizenship. “Tell them point blank, ‘Sorry, I don’t have to prove my citizenship’,” Prakash said while delivering a talk on CAA/NRC/NPR at Margao.

“The economy and GDP are in a shambles, unemployment is at the highest rate, the education system is a mess, medical care doesn’t reach the people, farmers are committing suicide. So this is a way to defocus,” Prakash said. TNN

Title: Rajkot: PSI booked for culpable homicide, suspended
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Family members of Himanshu Gohel accepted his body only after senior police officials assured them of strict a... Read More

RAJKOT: A day after a 30-year-old spa owner was shot dead in an accidental firing, Rajkot A division police station suspended probationary police sub-inspector P P Chavda after booking him for culpable homicide on Thursday.

At around 4pm on Wednesday, Himanshu Gohel, a friend of Chavda, had come to the police chowky to hand him tickets for the India-Australia one-day match to be held on January 17, when a bullet from Chavda’s firearm hit him accidentally and he died from the injury.
