Official said, the JMRC started internal trial run in November last year on Phase IB corridor which has underground length of 2.4km from Chandpole to Badi Chaupar in the Walled City. The underground corridor, which is expansion of Phase-I (Mansarovar to Chandpole) is expected to be operational by March 2020, as per the plan.

In September 2018, the internal trials were initiated to enable former chief minister Vasundhara Raje to flag off the project like her successor Ashok Gehlot did it in 2013. However, the plan failed as project was not completed, official sources said.

The length of entire Metro corridor Phase 1A and 1B is 12.07km. After BJP came to power, Raje inaugurated Jaipur Metro Rail Project (Phase 1A) in June 2015. This corridor was made operational in 2015 after spending Rs 2,023 crore. An official said, “The project cost of underground Phase-IB project is Rs 1,126 crore. Out of which, Rs 969 crore has been provided by the Asian Development Bank (ADB).”

Sources at JMRC said, the Metro Phase 1B missed its June 2018 deadline due to various reasons including Supreme Court ban on sand mining, shifting of seven temples and design change of two underground stations. The JMRC officials believe there will be increase in ridership after the Phase 1B) is operational. In absence of Phase 1B, the performance of Phase-IA of Jaipur Metro was ‘poor’ as the average ridership dipped.

“At present, average 20,000 passengers commute through Metro daily, as against the projected figure of one lakh. But Phase-II is expected to boost the numbers,” said a senior official.

Title: Dravyavati river project works done without tenders by Rajasthan government: Minister Shanti Dhariwal
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Urban development and housing minister Shanti Dhariwal at the inauguration of multi-level parking at C-Scheme ... Read More

JAIPUR: Urban Development and Housing (UDH) minister Shanti Dhariwal has accused the previous BJP government of carrying out several works under the Dravyavati river project without issuing tenders.

“Both the projects, Dravyavati river and Ring Road are delayed due to BJP’s lack of planning. The ring road cannot be made operational as railway permission is pending,” said Dhariwal

The minister attacked the previous government while inaugurating a multi-level parking at C-Scheme locality on Thursday. After change of regime in December 2018, the multi-crore project was moving at a snail's pace as contractor was demanding the due amount. The minister, however, said that the firm carried out work, which was not mentioned in the tender agreement.

The project, which will accommodate 400 cars. The parking is expected to provide relief to number of office-goers as there is no space in the area.

An official source at the JMC said, construction of the multi-level parking project started about nine years ago on public private and partnership mode. The contractor was given rights to construct a commercial space on government land in exchange.

“The project was embroiled in controversy after the contractor moved an application to raise the height of building (commercial space) from 15 metre to 22 metre. However, objections were raised by the department for the same. The project was delayed for this reason,” sources said.

Parking has been a major issue in the fast-growing Jaipur as the number of registered vehicles increases by 12% annually. “Vehicles parked on roads not only obstruct traffic, lack of parking space also creates a difficulty for the visitors at the major markets. The parking will resolve the problem in the area,” sources said.

Title: Census from April 16-May 30
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Panaji: The first phase of the Census of India 2021 will be held between April 16 and May 30.

The Goa government has approved to set aside the 45 days’ period for conducting the first phase of the census. This period will be used for houselisting and simultaneous updation of the National Population Register (NPR). This data will serve as the basis for officials to carry out the actual individual related data work on which will take place in 2021.

TOI had reported that field workers going door to door will enter data on an app in English, Konkani and Marathi among 15 other scheduled languages. tnn

Title: Fifth such operation in Jaipur, first took place in 2015
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

SMS Hospital

JAIPUR: The first heart transplant of the city, also first in the state, was performed on August 2, 2015 at a private hospital when a 18-year-old resident of Sanganer was declared brain dead at Mahatma Gandhi Medical College & Hospital (MGMCH) in Jaipur. He was undergoing treatment for injuries he suffered in a road accident.

On November 7, 2016, a 22-year-old man undergoing treatment at a private hospital in the city donated his organs and his heart was transplanted into a 35-year-old patient. On August 26, 2017, a 55-year-old person Madan (name changed) suffering from dilated cardiomyopathy, received a heart which was donated by the family of a 21-year-old person, after being declared brain dead. It was the fourth heart transplant at a private hospital.

SMS Hospital developed new facility with a cost of Rs 20 crore for heart transplant, which was inaugurated on October 5, 2019 by chief minister Ashok Gehlot . In the state, there are four private hospitals, which have already been approved for heart transplants.

The third heart transplant of the city was conducted at a private hospital on February 24, 2017 when a 57-year-old resident of Madhya Pradesh received heart of a 35-year-old patient declared brain dead.

So far, relatives of 30 families have donated organs of their near and dear ones since February 2015, after they were declared brain dead by committees formed to declare patients brain dead in hospitals. From those 30 donors, 16 hearts were harvested for transplant. But only four were transplanted in hospitals in Jaipur, while others were flown to Delhi or other centres. SMS Hospital doctors performed the fifth heart transplant in the city.

A team of doctors headed by SMS Hospital’s cardiac surgeon Dr Anil Sharma spent sleepless nights as they conducted the heart transplant. They were excited to perform the surgery. An ambulance with ICU facility was arranged which transported the donor from ITO to main SMS Hospital at around 11pm on Wednesday. The donor was shifted to the newly developed heart transplant ICU.

A fleet of more than 30 doctors and nursing staff remained awake, including the teams of organ transplant coordinators, urologists, anaesthesia specialists, hepatologists, cardiac surgeons. At around 8am, the process of transplant was complete.

Title: SMS becomes Rajasthan’s first government hospital to conduct heart transplant
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Relatives with the donor’s body outside Sawai Man Singh Hospital in the city on Thursday

JAIPUR: Sawai Man Singh Hospital scripted a major success in performing its first heart transplant on the intervening night of Wednesday-Thursday. The cardiac surgeons retrieved the heart of a 25-year-old man and transplanted it into a 15-year-old boy, suffering from dilated cardiomyopathy.

The recipient had an enlarged heart due to the disease and it was functioning at less than 15% of its capacity. The recipient had complained of decreasing urine output, breathlessness and also he had edema over his body, which made him almost bed-ridden. He was in touch with the SMS Hospital doctors as he was undergoing treatment at the hospital. He belongs to Sawai Madhopur.

When the doctors called him over the phone about a donor whose relatives had given consent to donate his organs — heart, liver and two kidneys, the boy’s family rushed to the hospital for the transplant, which started at around 4am and it was completed at around 8am. The doctors took four hours to complete the transplant.

Chief minister Ashok Gehlot tweeted, “Happy to know that first ever heart transplant has been performed in SMS government hospital, #Jaipur today. I pray to God for it to be successful and may the patient regain health soon. #Rajasthan.”

Health minister Raghu Sharma congratulated SMS Hospital's team for performing the heart transplant in a government hospital. Dr D S Meena, medical superintendent, SMS Hospital said, “The donor belonged to Bheem of Rajsamand district, who was brought to the hospital as he had suffered severe head injury on January 10 in a road accident.”

He said that the youth was unconscious and despite the doctors providing him treatment, he did not regain consciousness. A committee, which declares patient brain-dead and certify it by conducting certain tests, declared the 25-year-old brain dead on Wednesday afternoon. Following that, a team of counsellors of the hospital encouraged the relatives of the patient to donate the organs. The family gave its consent and at around midnight, the doctors started procedure of retrieving his organs. The patient was undergoing treatment at SMS Hospital's Institute of Traumatology and Orthopedics (ITO), he was shifted to main SMS Hospital's building, Dhanwantri building’s second floor.

There, the doctors started retrieving his organs. His liver was transported to a private hospital in Jaipur for transplanting it into a liver-failure patient. “The two kidneys harvested from the donor were transplanted into a 35-year-old male and 37-year-old female, who were undergoing dialysis for past few months. Both kidneys were transplanted into patients at SMS Hospital,” said Dr SS Yadav, senior professor and head of the department (urology), SMS Hospital.

At one point of time, the vital parameters of the donor became unsuitable for organ donation as his blood pressure and pulse rate had also gone down but later his parameters improved, which made the transplant possible.

Title: First flight will takeoff in Jan 2022: Pramod Sawant
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

PANAJI: Chief minister Pramod Sawant said on Thursday that the Supreme Court’s decision paving way for the construction of the greenfield international airport at Mopa was “a great relief” for the state and it would become operational in January 2022.

As per the earlier schedule, the first phase of the Mopa airport was supposed to be completed by September 30, 2020.

Sawant said the government was keen to fast-track the project and appealed to people “not to crate obstructions for small reasons”. He also urged the people of Goa not to block the development of the greenfield project in the larger interests of the state, and its tourism industry.

In an obvious message towards activists and environmentalists, Sawant called on Goans to co-operate with the state government. “We don’t want to damage the environment. We will take care of the environment while ushering in development,” he said.

The chief minister also said some people, in the name of the environment, try to stop or block the development of the state. “This should not happen,” he said.

“The Mopa airport will open up new avenues for Goa, and propel the state’s economic growth,” Sawant said.

“Our government is committed towards sustainable development that priortises its people and environment,” he said.

Title: Margao civic body’s ‘part occupancy’ kept in abeyance
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Margao: Director of urban development Tariq Thomas in his order passed on an appeal against the “part occupancy” certificate issued by Margao Municipal Council (MMC) for a commercial project at Aquem, Margao, in November 2019 has been kept it in abeyance until the next date of hearing.

The appeal has been filed by Margao resident Shirish Kamat pointing out that the project stands on a wetland which is in an open space and that all approvals by various authorities have been obtained “illegally”.

Kamat in his complaint pointed out that there is no such provision in the law to issue any such thing called ‘part occupancy ’ and that the certificate issued by MMC wasn’t as per the format specified in the Goa Land and Development Building Construction Regulation 2010.

The complaint had stated that on the strength of the part occupancy certificate, the developer will induct third parties in the building, thereby creating third party rights, complicating matters further.

He further pointed out that the MMC chief officer couldn’t issue any occupancy, let alone part occupancy, in any manner until he decides on the “serious illegalities” raised before him.

Title: Fill teachers’ vacancies with petitioners: Rajasthan high court
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: Rajasthan high court directed the panchayati raj department to find out the number of posts remaining unfilled out of the 41,000 posts of third grade teachers announced in 2012, and fill the vacancies with the petitioners.

The division bench of Justice Sabina and NS Dhaddha gave the order on a petition by Namonarayan Sharma and about 80 others. The petitioners claimed that the candidates who had scored less marks than the appellants were selected.

During the pendency of the writ petition, the results were revised because of revision of answer key, the candidates who had scored lower in merit than the appellants also made it in to the selection process. But such candidate was retained in service on the directions of a single bench order which was upheld later by a division bench.

So, the court directed that the petitioners be accommodated in the vacancies existing out of the 41,000 posts announced.

Title: SC clears construction of Mopa international airport under NEERI watch
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

NEW DELHI / PANAJI: In a major relief to the state government, the Supreme Court on Thursday lifted the suspension on construction of greenfield Mopa international airport , being developed by GMR , after a year and asked the National Environmental Engineering Research Institute ( NEERI ) to oversee the project to ensure that there is no environmental damage or danger to flora and fauna of the area.

A bench of justices D Y Chandrachud and Hemant Gupta also directed the concessionaire of the project to adopt a zero-carbon programme in construction and operational phases of the airport.

The Supreme Court last year found fault in the environment clearance given to the project before staying construction and directed the expert appraisal committee (EAC) to re-examine it.

The court said conditions imposed by the EAC and National Green Tribunal (NGT) are sufficient to protect environment.

Over 54,000 trees were felled on the project site and the developer has been directed to plant 5.5 lakh trees.

The Supreme Court also said that the project proponent would bear the expenses and fees of NEERI.

As per the earlier schedule, the first phase of Mopa airport was supposed to be complete by September 30, 2020.

After examining all aspects of the project as directed by the apex court, the EAC cleared it but imposed additional conditions to protect environment. The concessionaire has now been subjected to over 100 mitigatory conditions, which include 16 at the behest of NGT and 40 imposed by EAC in the second round of clearance.

Expressing satisfaction on the conditions imposed, the bench said, “the EAC has adequately addressed these concerns and laid down additional conditions to ensure adequate protection of the environment”.

It refused to accept a plea that EAC failed to analyse the impact of the project comprehensively and said, “it cannot be said that the EAC has, in its appraisal process, ignored the concerns”.

In its earlier judgment, the Supreme Court had highlighted numerous deficiencies by the project proponent leading to the grant of EC. The court had also noted the abject failure of the project proponent to provide complete information on the existence of reserved forests.

Approving the decision of EAC, the bench said, “The evaluation of merits is a matter which primarily rests with an expert authority. The court can certainly supervise procedural compliance and ensure that all necessary inputs which are required to be factored into the decision-making process have been duly borne in mind. Once this has been done, the court must be circumspect in micro-managing the decision-making process by EAC by substituting its own opinion for that of EAC. Undoubtedly, no process can be perfect or free from studied criticism.”

Title: Rethink anti-people Motor Vehicles Act: State minister to Centre
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Rajasthan transport minister Pratap Singh Khachariyawas

JAIPUR: State transport minister Pratap Singh Khachariyawas said that the Central Motor Vehicles Act is totally anti-people and asked the Union surface transport minister Nitin Gadkari to rethink the new Act.

He was speaking at the road safety council meeting held in New Delhi on Thursday. He said the penalty in the new Act is so high that about 80% of the people could not afford it and drive in fear as they do not have that much money in their pockets to pay penalty. He pointed out that only eight states have implemented the new Motor Vehicles Act and the Central government should listen to the people where they were not able to pay such a hefty penalty.

He said there are chances of more accidents if drivers in their effort to evade penalty, resort to rash driving. He said under Section 200 of the Act which comes under the purview of the state government, Rajasthan has decided to reduce compoundable penalty. But he said non-compoundable penalty is very high and could not be reduced by the states. So, he said the Motor Vehicles Act requires revision.

Title: Jaipur: Youth who jumped to death at mall identified
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Cops investigate the case at the mall where the youth committed suicide

JAIPUR: Police have identified the youth who, in a suspected case of suicide, jumped from a mall near Bais Godam in the city on Wednesday. His family has been informed, though it is still uncertain if he fell accidentally or jumped on his own.

The deceased has been identified as 27-year-old Keval Sharma and his body was handed over to the family after post-mortem on Thursday.

Shreemohan Meena, SHO, Ashok Nagar police station said, “Although the deceased has been identified and it is almost certain that it is a case of suicide, the reason for it remains unclear. No suicide note was found on his body. The staff heard something hit the ground and when they rushed out, they saw Keval lying there in a pool of blood.”

The CCTV camera footage showed Keval taking the elevator up and police are looking further to check the floor which he jumped from. “Till now, the footage shows Keval taking the lift but we are trying to confirm the floor from which he jumped, though it appears that it is likely to be from the highest point of the mall,” added the SHO.

Keval was unmarried and cops are questioning the family as well to ascertain the reason behind the suspected suicide. The official said, “We will question the family as well to see if they had any idea as to why Keval took the extreme step. Probably, he was under some kind of stress but that remains to be found yet.”

Last year in November, 26-year-old Rohit Sharma jumped from a mall in the city just a day after getting married. Sharma had gone to the mall to buy a gift for his wife but instead jumped to his death. During investigation, police had found that initially Sharma had planned on consuming phenyl but for unknown reasons, chose to jump from the fifth floor of the mall.

Title: Michael Lobo for law to curb non-Goans from buying farm land in Goa
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Michael Lobo

CALANGUTE: Stating that Goan identity was in danger of being wiped out because of the huge influx of non-Goans who have settled in the tiny coastal state, ports minister Michael Lobo said the only way to save it was to bring in a legislation to stop them from buying orchard and agricultural land in the state.

“Outsiders come and buy orchard and agricultural land, build houses and settle down in Goa because this land is cheap. They should only be allowed to purchase flats as they are more expensive, and fewer people can buy them,” he said. The number of non-Goans would be restricted if this is imposed, the ports minister said at the Opinion Poll Day celebrations organised by the Calangute panchayat on Thursday.

Lobo said he was contemplating tabling a bill in the state assembly, which would enable only those with 25-year domicile to buy land in the state.

The minister said he would lobby with chief minister Pramod Sawant and state BJP chief Sadanand Shet Tanavade to pass a law in the state assembly, allowing non-Goans to only purchase flats and land tracts which are already converted into settlement zones.

He said the original figure of Goans has not increased, and expressed fears that the indigenous population could soon reduce to a minority.

Stating that it is not possible to debar people from other parts of the country from buying land in Goa, Lobo who represents Calangute constituency, the hotspot of tourism in the state, said a legislation could help curb the trend.

Describing the 1967 Goa Opinion Poll as historic, the minister said it was only because of it that the state has retained its distinct identity.

“Unfortunately, the state government has still not given it the importance it deserves. Opinion Poll Day should be a state function. When Manohar Parrikar became chief minister in 2017, I had discussed the matter with him and he had said he would form a committee to take the proposal forward, but unfortunately he died soon after,” Lobo said. “I will work on this. There should be a resolution in the assembly that Goa should only be for Goans,” he said.

The family of Jack Sequeira complimented the Calangute panchayat for taking the initiative to install a statue of the father of the Opinion Poll in Calangute. “I have been coming here for the last 18 years on this day because Calangute first started celebrating this occasion, thanks to Joseph Sequeira,” Lily Sequeira, the daughter of Jack Sequeira said.

Jack Sequeira Jr, the grandson of the late leader, said if Goa had merged with Maharashtra, “today we would have been a backyard of Maharashtra”. “The Opinion Poll gave us an opportunity to grow and develop our own identity. Hopefully, one day the state government will take cognisance of this and give it due recognition,” he said.

Title: Nagpur University confers first-ever DLitt in commerce to Shrihari Chava
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Shrihari Chava (left) receives the DLitt from Chief Justice of India Sharad Bobde

Nagpur: Nagpur University on Saturday bestowed the first-ever Doctor of Letters degree (DLitt) on Shrihari Chava (commerce and management faculty) at the 107th convocation ceremony.

It was conferred at hands of Chief Justice of India Sharad Bobde and NU vice-chancellor SP Kane at a glittering event held at the Suresh Bhat auditorium.

In all, NU conferred 64,993 degrees, including 746 PhDs, 13,037 postgraduate, 50,936 graduate and one DLitt.

Though many legal luminaries have been part of NU’s convocation ceremonies in the past, a CJI was the chief guest was for the first time in the university’s history, NU media coordinator Shyam Dhond said.

Pro-VC Vinayak Deshpande and NU Management Council members shared the dais.

Ayushi Khandelwal, who cleared MBA from Dr Ambedkar Institute of Management Studies and Research, received the highest number of gold medals (7) followed by Sayali Bhave (LLB-5 years) of NU’s Dr Ambedkar Law College and Sakharam Mandpe (MA in Ambedkar Thoughts) from NU’s Ambedkar Thought Department with six gold medals each.

Madhuri Ghugguskar from NU’s postgraduate education department won five gold medals for topping in the MEd exams.

Like the 106th convocation, this time too, NU drastically scaled down the number of medals. It awarded 185 medals and prizes of which 158 were gold and 9 silver. The remaining 18 were prizes.

At the 105th convocation, over 457 medals and prizes were awarded. They included 312 gold, 43 silver and 102 prizes.

Title: Jaipur: Man beaten to death over property row
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: A 35-year-old man was beaten to death with sticks by three to four persons in Jamvaramgarh police station area on Thursday afternoon . The man was killed over a dispute about plucking fruits and breaking branches of a tree in the agriculture field.

According to initial investigations, there appears to be a property feud that turned violent. Police have detained few of the accused.

The incident is of Jhol village in Kanota when the victim Jagdish Meena was plucking fruits and stems of a Neem tree. Lakhan Singh Meena , circle officer, Jamvaramgarh police area, said, “Around noon on Thursday, Jagdish was breaking branches of a Neem tree and plucking fruits for cattle fodder as well as other use. The accused came to field and objected to this and they ganged up on Meena. They were armed with wooden sticks and beat him up. He died due to fatal blow to the head.” According to officials, the victim and the accused are from the same who were feuding over the property. Police have registered a case under IPC section 302 (murder) and the victim’s body was handed over to his family after the post-mortem.

Title: BIDA or RIICO set to take over DMIC project
Content:
Industries minister Prasadi Lal Meena

JAIPUR: With Delhi-Mumbai Industrial Corridor ( DMIC ) work in the state falling far behind the schedule, the government is weighing options to bring the department under Bhiwadi Industrial Development Authority ( BIDA ) or RIICO for fast tracking trunk infrastructure development.Lack of funds for buying land and the non-availability of adequate officials on the ground have been major roadblocks for implementation of the project.On Wednesday industries minister Prasadi Lal Meena even admitted that the other five states sharing the route of the corridor have made significant progress, while Rajasthan is yet to make a beginning.Meena said that the government has identified 532 hectare land in five villages for which compensation worth Rs 128 crore will be given by March this year. The government has already paid Rs 20 crore last year as compensation for land last year.But earlier estimates suggests that the government needs Rs 3,000 crore to pay for 1,425 hectare for Khuskhera-Bhiwadi-Neemrana (KBN) Industrial Smart City. Even though the process for land acquisition started in 2012, no significant progress has been made so far.Additional chief secretary, industries, Subodh Agarwal, who had recently visited Dholera in Gujarat and has been following up other states to understand the DMIC work being implemented there, said, “We are thinking of dissolving the DMIC department and transfering the posts to BIDA or RIICO so that work can be fast-tracked. In fact, there is no separate department for DMIC in Maharashtra, Gujarat, Haryana or Madhya Pradesh that share the corridor. The work in those states are carried out by existing corporations or authorities of the respective governments. In fact, this is one of the reasons why the project in the state has not progressed at the desired pace.”Agarwal said under BIDA or RIICO, the advantages will be manifold in terms of ease of doing business, work culture and retention of officers or employees and they will add impetus to the complex process of implementation that the project requires.“We need dedicated people on the ground to understand and address local issues for hassle-free implementation, while the broader policy and strategic decisions can be taken care by the Industries department. The project has already suffered a prolonged delay and we cannot afford to lose any more time,” added AgarwalThe $100-billion dollar project is being built along the high-speed Dedicated Freight Corridor (DFC) that would reduce the time for goods movement between Dadri near Delhi to Jawaharlal Nehru Port in Mumbai from current 14 days to about 14 hours. The longest stretch of the 1483 km route (about 39%) passes through the desert state that has struggled to make a start.The project is India’s most ambitious infrastructure programme aiming to develop new industrial cities as Smart Cities and converging next generation technologies across infrastructure sectors.

Title: Medical aspirant from Himachal Pradesh hangs self in Kota
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

KOTA: A 23-year-old girl from Himachal Pradesh — who was preparing to crack NEET, the entrance exam for admission in medical colleges, at a coaching institute of the city for last two years — committed suicide by hanging herself to the ceiling fan of her room at a PG on Wednesday late evening in Basant Vihar colony under Dadabari police station of the city.

It is the first case of suicide by a student of a coaching institute this year in the city, while at least eight coaching students had committed suicide last year. The girl, identified as Kanchan Bala, a resident of Himachal Pradesh, committed suicide by hanging herself at a PG in Vasant Vihar colony late on Wednesday evening, said ASI at Dadabari police station. The deceased girl had been preparing to crack NEET, the entrance exam for admission in medical colleges, at a coaching institute in the city for last two years, he added. The reason behind the suicide is yet to be ascertained as no suicide note was recovered from her room, the ASI further said.

One of the girls, living in the same PG, peeped through the window of the deceased girl’s room and noticed her hanging to the ceiling fan, following which she reported the matter to the landlord, who informed the police and rushed the girl to the hospital, where the doctors declared her brought dead, he added.

The family members of the deceased girl reached Kota on Thursday morning, following which the postmortem was carried out at MBS Hospital. The police handed over the body to family members after postmortem on Thursday and registered a case under Section 174 to investigate the actual reason behind the extreme step, the ASI said.

Title: Langa-Manganiyar artistes eye world record
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

District collector Namit Mehta during a meeting with artistes in Jaisalmer on Thursday

JAISALMER: A group of 500-700 Langa-Manganiyar folk artists will come together to attempt to set a world record by playing their traditional instruments on the sand dunes at Khuhadi, on the second day of desert festival.

District collector Namit Mehta directed to make preparations for the desert festival, to be held from February 7 to February 9 in Jaisalmer . A kite festival will be held at Sam sand dunes, a laser show at Sonar Fort and a yoga camp on the banks of Gadisar Lake.

He said that this time, many new attractions will be there at the festival. On the eve of the festival, activities will take place at Pokhran including a procession, mehendi competition, a tug of war etc. On the same day, a laser show will be organised at Sonar Fort. All other cultural programmes will be organised at Sam and Khuhadi. Mehta said that in the festival, a heritage walk will also be taken out from Gadisar to the fort. Moreover, at Khuhadi sand dunes, folk artists to the tune of 500-700 will present ‘desert symphony’ and will try to set a world record. Last year too, a record was made in which 5,000 people simultaneously wore turbans.

Similarly, at Khuhadi sand dunes, sand art will be put on display and at Sam sand dunes, a kite festival will be organised. On all days of the festival, international bands will perform and yoga camp will be organised at the banks of Gadisar Lake. Mehta said that an officer in-charge has been appointed for each activity.

To popularise the desert festival on national and international levels, help of all kinds of media will be taken.

Title: Kolkata: Park Circus protesters get a tent after braving cold for nine days
Content:
Women and kids protest under open skies at Park Circus

KOLKATA: ‘Apolitical’ tents were being put up at Park Circus on Thursday evening for the protesters who are agitating against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and the National Register of Citizens for the last nine days. Provisions for bio-toilets and running water will also be made.Asmat Jamil, who is leading the protest, met chief minister Mamata Banerjee at her residence on Wednesday and requested her to grant permission to put up a shed as it was becoming difficult for the women and the kids to stay in the open at night. She also spoke about the lack of basic amenities — like running water, washroom and light — at the venue.“Within 24 hours, I got a call from chief minister’s office. We will arrange for all the basic amenities with the government’s permission. I am thankful to Didi for understanding our problems and keeping her words,” said Jamil, adding that a request had been made for a white tent as it is a protest without a political banner. During the meeting, Jamil also invited Mamata Banerjee to visit the sit-in at Park Circus.Echoing Jamil, Uzma Alam, another protester, said she was thankful to the chief minister for supporting their cause. “Being a woman herself, the chief minister understood our problems. Everyone who is supporting our cause is welcome to join us but we request everyone to come as a citizen of the country, leaving behind their political affiliation,” said Alam.Local councillor Sana Ahmed said: “I met the protesters at Park Circus on Thursday and listened to their problems.”According to Rafiqua Hayat, a graduate, who has been staying in the open and chanting slogans all night to keep the morale of the protesters high, it’s a small victory that they have achieved.“This will encourage and motivate us to fight the long battle against NRC, NPR and CAA,” she said.Eighty-year-old Nurjahan Shakil comes to Park Circus every day to show solidarity with the movement against CAA. “Most of the young women have infants, who they bring to the protest venue with them because there is nobody at home to take care of them. “They are fighting to defend the Constitution and I am happy that their sacrifice has been recognized and basic amenities are being provided,” said Shakil.APDR’s Altaf Ahmed believes the continuous movement of common people, especially these women, who fought all odds for nine days and stayed in the open to protest against the act, deserves basic facilities. APDR submitted a deputation to the mayor-in-council on Wednesday, requesting the administration to grant permission for tent and bio-toilets.The sit-in, which started last Tuesday with a group of women and students from different campuses, has seen steady rise in the number of participants, with more and more people joining in every day. Hundreds of women are protesting at Park Circus Maidan, which is being identified as Kolkata’s Shaheen Bagh without any basic amenities like running water, washroom and shelter.

Title: Officer’s response to stray dog complaint on Rajasthan portal goes viral
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

UDAIPUR: When Prahlad Keer of Udaipur turned to the Rajasthan Sampark portal to lodge his grievance about the menace caused by a stray dog in the village, the response posted by the village development officer disposing the case, took a comical twist, which is now going viral on social media.

Keer, a resident of Dhava gram panchayat in Vallabhnagar panchayat samiti, had on November 2019, lodged a complaint on the sampark portal, wherein he wrote that a female dog bit everyone in the locality. The village development officer, who made an enquiry about the complaint, uploaded the response on the portal on January 15. The officer Malkesh Meena replied, “After speaking to the locals, it has been found that the bitch did not bite anybody. Many children and people pass through the street and she harms no one. Since the complainant had hit the animal, she barked at him but didn’t bite him. Hence, the complaint is fit to be disposed of.” People are finding the nature of the complaint weird and the authority’s response in disposal even funnier. Some even expressed their reservations over the language used by the officer.

“The complainant was a common man so its understandable that he used unparliamentary words for the animal, but the officer should have been more careful. These people cannot be respectable to poor animals, leave alone fellow peeps who they hold in scant respect anyway. However, the letter, its content and the seriousness of the disposal is truly funny,” said a senior police officer wishing anonymity. Upendra Kumar Sharma, BDO, Bhinder said the letter is not a complete one.

Title: ATK-Mohun Bagan merger news sinks in, slowly
Content:
An installation on Mohun Bagan Lane that commemorates the squad that defeated East Yorkshire Regiment in the I... Read More

KOLKATA: Die-hard fans of Mohun Bagan had a tough digesting the news of the merger of India’s oldest surviving top-tier football club with two-time ISL champion ATK, with some of them lashing out their angst and perplexity on social media. But in the end, the reaction from most fans was obvious — acceptance with a heavy heart.“Logically thinking, the arrangement serves both the clubs. While ATK has the financial stability, Mohun Bagan comes with 131 years of heritage and legacy that no other football club in India can boast of. The merger can turn the club into a formidable force. But being an emotional fan, it is hard to see a club my entire family has been rooting for years suddenly becoming a different entity. I am certain, the passion will be missing,” said Saikat Banerjee, a techie and an ardent Mohun Bagan fan from Behala.For more than a year, fans were aware of the speculation about ATK joining hands with Mohun Bagan. Even then, when the announcement was finally made on Thursday, it was a difficult pill for fans to digest.“RPSG group is the best investor Mohun Bagan can ever have but if the new arrangement results in tampering of the jersey colour, flag or the logo, fans like me will not take it lightly. If the new club has to lure the Mohun Bagan fanbase, they will have to keep some of these aspects intact,” said Sumanta Chakraborty, a banker. Some ATK fans, too, were livid over the fact that they would have to share the stands with Mohun Bagan supporters.Social media was abuzz with sane voices as well. “Being a Mohun Bagan fan, it’s hard to believe that Mohun Bagan isn’t an autonomous body anymore. But somehow, we should be happy that Bangalir football will get more exposure and Indian players will get world-class facilities to develop their skills. If you say about our heritage, where has it gone in last few years? A Bengal derby used have a maximum of two to three Bengali players,” wrote Samrat Banerjee on Facebook.There were also some who raised more pertinent questions like the future arrangements of the players. “Forget about fans and their emotions, what about the players.. currently there are 40 or 50 players playing in these two teams and do not forget ATK has its reserve squad too. What about these players’ future?” asked Arijit Denre, a fan from Howrah.But in the end, most fans said they would have to accept that it was necessary for the legendary club to do away with archaic ways of administration and embrace a professional structure but passionate fans still added that all they want are the name, jersey colour and logo of the century-old club to remain intact.

Title: ATK-Mohun Bagan deal: Acceptance at 130-year-old club’s birthplace
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Mitra Bari, from where Mohun Bagan club was formed 130 years ago

KOLKATA: Gouri Bhaduri, the wife of legendary Mohun Bagan player Shibdas Bhaduri’s great grandson, was hesitant about the ATK-Mohun Bagan deal. For someone who has Mohun Bagan in her blood, the name of ATK is alien. “It would be better if they retain the name of Mohun Bagan. I do not know ATK,” she said.

Though Gouri Bhaduri has never heard of ATK, her son-in-law Paritosh Ranjan Roy has fair knowledge about ISL and ATK. On Thursday, Roy was a bit pragmatic. From his heart he wants Mohun Bagan’s name to stay but he can understand the compulsion. “If it is needed for the existence of the club then I have no problem with the new set-up,” he said.

Another Mohun Bagan supporter Dhruba Ghosal, who is watching his favourite team play for over 50 years, however, was yet to make up his mind. “Perhaps, it was needed but considering the heritage of our club, Mohun Bagan’s name should come before ATK. It should be Mohun Bagan ATK and not the other way around,” he said.

Hirak Kumar Mitra, a descendant of Mitra family, in whose home ground Bagan started its journey 130 years back, was more vocal in support of the merger. Mitra has seen the likes of Sailen Manna and Chuni Goswami playing in Mohun Bagan colours. His grand-father Jatindranath Mitra had watched the historic IFA Shield Final in 1911. “We have not renewed the membership of Mohun Bagan for long. Actually, the old members were not very happy with the affairs of the club. It would be better if ATK can bring in professionalism here. No other clubs in India can match the kind of brand Mohun Bagan has,” he said.

Mitra believes Sanjiv Goenka has some vision of the club. “We all know ISL will be the best league in the country. So there was hardly any other option to be in ISL,” he argued. Utpal Bag, a veteran Mohun Bagan supporter, welcomed the move as well. He has been watching Bagan play since 1976 and became a club member in 1982. “This was needed, otherwise how will the club run? How long an individual will finance the club? If you do not have big sponsor, you stand no chance in ISL and I-League is soon becoming a second division tornament,” he justified. Die-hard Mohun Bagan fan Souvvik Ghosh echoed: “It is a step in the right direction.”

Title: TRS got Rs 141cr through bonds, Rs 41cr donations
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Hyderabad: The Telangana Rashtra Samithi (TRS) has received around Rs 182 crore as donations from individuals and firms including Rs 141 crore through electoral bonds, which is the highest that has been received by political parties in both Telangana and Andhra Pradesh.

While parties like YSR Congress Party (YSRCP) received only 55 per cent of their funds through electoral bonds, the TRS party received 78 per cent of its funds from electoral bonds.

As per the annual audited accounts and annual report of contributions to the party for the year 2018-19, the direct contributions to the party in previous financial year was Rs 24 crore and Rs 16.50 crore was deposited through prudent electoral trust. The electoral bonds were Rs 141 crore.

The audit reports submitted to the Election Commission of India (ECI), the prudent electoral trust paid more to the neighbouring state’s parties — Rs 27 crore to YSRCP and Rs 25 crore to Telugu Desam Party (TDP) and Rs 16 crore to TRS.

The pink party received over Rs 1 crore in direct donations from nine people, including Rs 3 crore from one GV Bhaskar Rao, a resident of Tadbund, Rs 2 crore from M/s Raghava Constructions, M/s Venkateshwara Enterprises and Gland Celsus Bio-Chemicals Pvt Ltd, Rs 1 crore each from M/s Aeroc Space Technologies Pvt Ltd, Hotel Park Continental, minister Chamakura Malla Reddy and Saroja Vivekanand.

Among others, majority of the donors were from infrastructure companies and realtors.

Title: From Rs 14 crore in 2017-18, YSRC income rose to Rs 181 cr last fiscal
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Vijayawada: YSRC received Rs 181 crore as donations from individuals and organisations during 2018-19. Of this, Rs 99.84 crore came through electoral bonds. This is 55% of the total donations received by the party till March 31, 2019.

YSRC received only Rs 14 crore during 2017-18 but its income increased to Rs 181 crore during the last financial year, recording 93% increase in the overall income.

According to a statement submitted by YSRC to the Election Commission, the party headed by chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy received Rs 36 crore in donations from non-business entities and Rs 18 crore from corporate houses.

The statement, which is mandatory under Section 29C (3) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, showed that it had paid about Rs 37 crore to Indian Political Action Committee (I-PAC) that looked after the YSRC campaign in Andhra Pradesh. The party also spent about Rs 87 crore on election campaign and newspaper advertisements among others. At the end of the financial year, the party was left with a balance of Rs 93.39 crore.

Showing the statement for income, the party said Rs 36 crore was contributed by non-corporate entities, Rs 18 crore by corporate entities, Rs 99.8 crore through electoral bonds and Rs 27 crore through electoral trust.

The donations ranged from as little as Rs 91,000 to Rs 27 crore.

Title: Cong, Sena set to join hands in Nandurbar ZP
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Nashik: Congress and Shiv Sena have decided to stitch a post-poll alliance to take control of the Nandurbar zilla parishad for the next five years.

The state leadership of both these parties have directed the local units to join hands in the ZP.

“Since both the parties are coalition partners in the Maha Aghadi Vikas (MVA) government in the state, we have decided to join hands for the Nandubar ZP. It would help the local body get all necessary support from the state government, including funds for carrying out development projects in the tribal-dominated district,” said state tribal welfare minister and local Congress MLA K C Padvi.

The state Congress has appointed Padvi to hold parleys with the Sena camp and work out the modalities of the ZP-level alliance.

Senior Sena functionary from Nandubar and former MLC Chandrakant Raghuvanshi said the state party leadership has directed the local unit to tie up with Congress.

The elections for the posts of ZP president and vice-president are slated to take place on Friday. The Nandubar voters had given a hung verdict in the recently concluded ZP polls with Congress and BJP winning 23 seats each. Both parties are short by six members to cross the magic mark of 29. The support of Sena, which won seven seats, is crucial for Congress. There was no pre-poll alliance between any of the parties in the ZP polls in Nandurbar.

According to the understanding, while the post of ZP president will go to Congress, the new ZP vice-president would be from Sena. “Sena has also demanded the post of the chairmen for two committees, which Congress is unwilling to give, since the number of seats that party has won is far less than what our party has won. We are holding talks with our Sena counterparts to convince them to settle for chairman of one committee,” Congress sources said.

Title: Nagpur: Alumni changing VNIT’s face, five projects to be unveiled on Sunday
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

NAGPUR: Come Sunday and city-based Visvesvaraya National Institute of Technology ( VNIT ) would don a new look, thanks to its alumni association. The premier institution will celebrate its diamond jubilee by unveiling a 10-feet-high bronze statue of Sir M Visvesvaraya, after whom the institute is named.

A new-look entrance, with new fountains, street lights and a LED light show, would also be inaugurated on the day by Union transport minister Nitin Gadkari in the presence of VNIT’s Board of Governors (BOG) chairman Vishram Jamdar, director Pramod Padole, alumni association chairman Shashikant Chaudhary and others. Three more projects funded by the alumni would also be inaugurated by the dignitaries. They include a football ground, two lawn tennis courts, and a modern night tea kiosk for students called ‘Chandrama’.

Interestingly, all projects were entirely conceptualized, funded and implemented by various batches of VNIT.

“Our alumni association has collected Rs5 crore, which would be utilized not only for infrastructural projects, but also for various academic activities. We’ve so far finalized 11 projects to be funded by them. We’ve also entered into a pact with Union Transport Ministry for conducting classes on road safety and audit for government officials, including those from PWD and CPWD,” Padole told the media.

He added that the statue was made by Ram Sutaria, who was part of the team that built the world’s highest ‘Statue of Unity’ in Gujarat. “Fourteen of my PhD students have also contributed to the statue,” he said.

Explaining the other projects, Chaudhary said their association had been working since 2012 and so far has 1,600 life members. “The 1984 batch has taken up the task to gift the bronze statue, while 1985 batch has set up Chandrama. The 1986 batch has helped construct the tennis courts and 1992 batch has sponsored the football stadium. More alumni are coming forward to help their alma mater in the diamond jubilee year. Out of over 22,000 students who have graduated from this prestigious institution, we’ve got details of 20,000, although partially,” he said, adding that it felt nice to give back to your alma mater.

Jamdar informed that VNIT would be setting up a ‘Centre for Excellence in Innovation’ in collaboration with the Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSME) division of the Government of India. “We will be hosting a meeting of directors of various NITs, and 16 of them have already agreed to attend, under this initiative. Vikram Kirloskar from Kirloskar Group has consented to deliver a lecture on carbon policy rating and accreditation on February 8 in our college,” he said.

Padole added that grand nephew of Visvesvaraya — Satish Mokshagundam and his wife Laxmi Satish — would be attending the function on Sunday. “Our alumni chapters are also working in Dubai and the USA apart from all metro cities like Delhi, Mumbai, Pune and Bangalore,” he said.

Title: Bihar man arrested for gold fraud in Keri
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

VALPOI: Mohammad Sauad Alam, 19, a native of Bihar , was arrested by the Valpoi police on Thursday after he tampered with the gold bangles of a woman in Keri on the pretext of polishing them.

Police said Alam visited the house of Devki Gawas in Ghoteli, Keri, and convinced her that he would bring back the original lustre of her gold ornaments. He then applied a powder on two of her gold bangles and dipped them into a liquid. In a few minutes, Gawas noticed that her bangles began turning black and their gold sheen had disappeared.

Her shouts for help were heard by several other villagers, who gathered at the spot and caught the accused. He, however, managed to escape. The villagers then alerted the police and began searching the entire village for him. He was found in the neighbouring village of Shiroli and was handed to the police. A case has been registered under provisions of the IPC.

Title: Kolkata: Hindus, Muslims eat at food ATM run by nuns
Content:
Kids have the food by the food ATM

KOLKATA: As the clock strikes noon, this small empty courtyard in Entally fills up with eager eyes and empty tummies. The promise of food has been bringing the hungry mouths from the neighbouring slums to this courtyard every afternoon since the beginning of the new year. It’s a strange mix here — Christian nuns feed Hindus and Muslims of all ages from the neighbouring slums. They eat and share out of each other’s plates and create a picture of complete harmony that could be a testament to vouch for in these troubled times.We are talking about the food ATM installed by the nuns of the Kolkata Mary Ward Social Centre at Loreto Convent Entally. The initiative was undertaken to feed slum dwellers of the neighbouring Tangra, Motijheel, Dhapa and Palmer Bazar areas. A little under 200 people, mostly kids, are fed lunch now. But the volunteers are hopeful that with more help coming in, they will be able to feed more people soon.For the moment, Loreto schools on Elliot Road and at Entally and Bowbazar are collecting, pooling and ferrying food to the food ATM. Loreto School Dharamtala has also pledged to contribute to the initiative. Students of these schools have been divided into batches. Under the supervision of teacher coordinators, they bring fresh, clean, home-cooked food, packed in containers ready to be distributed to the slum dwellers as they walk in. Every name is recorded in the register maintained at the ATM.“They sit around the courtyard to eat. We provide fresh drinking water, an egg and a banana each, along with the home-cooked food and do not allow them to carry it away. We make them sit there and eat everything because we know that carrying back the food can lead to wastage,” said director of the centre Monica Suchiang, who designed the programme.There’s quite a variety on the menu and no two plates are similar. If Salma Khatoun got a plate of biryani, Baby Singh may have got khichdi and subzi. No one is so selfish that s/he won’t share. In fact, they are happy sharing. On Thursday afternoon, 15-year-old ragpicker Zuber shared his fried rice and chilli chicken with friend and fellow ragpicker Raju who had got puri sabzi along with the egg and banana. “Hum log sab mil baant kar khate hain yahan. Memsaab log ek time ka pet bhar ke khana dete hain. (We eat together and happily share our food. Madams here fill our bellies once a day),” Zuber said.Schoolchildren who donate the food, bring in whatever is cooked at home. This is why no two children’s food pack are the same. Hence, the variety in the meals served. “We are happy that every child is eager to help. Each week, one class has to bring in food just once. Every child brings enough to feed one hungry mouth,” explained Nandini Bhattacharya, a teacher at Loreto Elliot Road, who is coordinating for her school. The centre’s cafeteria also cooks and serves thalis of rice, daal and subzi for the food ATM.

Title: Police crack mobile shop burglary, arrest suspect
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Nashik: Nashik police on Thursday claimed to have solved a city mobile shop burglary case by arresting one of the members of a seven-member gang from Bihar and recovering four iPhones worth Rs 1.20 lakh from him.

The crime branch I, who picked up the suspect from Ghorsahan village of Motihari district, discovered that the remaining six members of the gang are in Nepal and Bangladesh to dispose of the stolen mobile phones.

“The arrested suspect revealed under interrogation that his accomplices have gone to the neighbouring countries to sell the phones and also the modus operandi they adopted,” said they police.

Police said the same gang had targeted a showroom on the Gangapur road and stolen 82 iPhones on December 10 last year, following which an investigation had been launched.

The gang is engaged in stealing only select high-end mobile phones from various parts of the country and disposing them of in Nepal and Bangladesh because it is difficult to track the phones outside India, said police.

The CCTV footage showed that the security personnel posted at a jewellery shop near the mobile phone showroom on Gangapur road here left for home at 5am on December 10. The thieves approached the shop 20 minutes later and broke open the shutter after covering it with a bedsheet. The arrested suspect, along with the other gang members, stole the iPhones.

During the investigation, Gangapur police sent teams to Bihar, from where the crime branch sleuths arrested the suspect.

Police said that gang members are seasoned criminals and know that it is easy to track down the mobile phones if sold to anyone in India.

According to police, the inter-state gang must have targeted many cities in Maharashtra and that the custodial interrogation of the suspect will help in cracking more cases. The suspect was prodced before a local court on Wednesday and remanded in police custody till Sunday.

Title: HC to hear Tarun Tejpal case in-camera
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: The high court of Bombay at Goa has allowed in-camera hearing before it on a plea filed by the survivor in the alleged rape case against Tarun Tejpal . The survivor had approached the high court seeking directions to restrain the defence advocate from asking her “indecent and scandalous” questions in the trial court.

Survivor counsel Vijay Hiremath requested the court to continue hearing in camera in high court. Senior advocate Amit Desai who appeared for Tejpal did not object to Hiremath’s request.

Desai, who appeared for Tejpal, argued that the petition filed by the survivor is not maintainable before the single bench and should be heard before division bench. Hiremanth said that the petition is maintainable before single bench.

The high court has adjourned the matter till February 4 when it will hear in-camera arguments on maintainability of the petition and merit.

Title: Used Google Maps to identify plots in Bikaner: Vadra to ED
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

NEW DELHI: Congress president Sonia Gandhi’s son-in-law Robert Vadra told the Enforcement Directorate (ED) that he used Google map to identify properties for purchase after one of his associates from Bikaner , Mahesh Nagar, brought land registry papers to him.

Mahesh Nagar is brother of Congress MLA from Haryana ’s Lalit Nagar, and was the authorised representative of Vadra’s Skylight Hospitality Pvt Ltd. Vadra had allegedly purchased four land parcels through Nagar and later sold them off at huge margins to Allegeny Finlease Pvt Ltd.

Based on Nagar’s statements, Vadra has been questioned multiple times by the investigating officers of the ED’s Jaipur zone. Sources said, Vadra has been evasive on the source of funds used to purchase these land parcels which were meant for rehabilitation of displaced persons of the Mahajan Field Firing Range.

After two days of questioning in Jaipur earlier this year in connection with the Bikaner land scam, the ED on February 15 had attached Vadra’s Sukhdev Vihar house besides other assets worth over Rs 4.62 crore.

ED in its attachment order claimed Sky Light Hospitality purchased 275 bigha (69.55 hectare) fraudulently for Rs 72 lakh and sold it for Rs 5.15 crore to Allegeny Finlease (P) Ltd and illegally generated profit of Rs 4.43 crore. The attachment order had also accused four others of generating profit of Rs 18.59. Both Vadra and his mother are directors in the Sky Light Hospitality Pvt Ltd and accused in the case.

Title: Kolkata: Meet giraffes, zebras at Eco Park next year
Content:
File photos of giraffes at Alipore zoo from where animals will be brought to the New Town facility next year

KOLKATA: Giraffes and hippos in enclosures may greet visitors to Eco Park from next year. The West Bengal Zoo Authority has got the approval of master layout plan for ‘Harinalaya Mini Zoo’ at New Town from Central Zoo Authority (CZA) recently. The development makes it the 12th recognized mini zoo in Bengal.Though Harinalaya — spread over 10 acres — has been operating since 2016, the move by CZA finally gives it an official recognition.Talking to TOI, state zoo authority member secretary V K Yadav said that the zoo will house giraffes, hippos and zebras that will be shifted from the Alipore Zoological Gardens once the entire facility is ready by the end of this year. “Initially, we plan to bring four giraffes, four zebras and two hippos from Alipore zoo. But before that, the final enclosure designs need clearance from the CZA. The designs are ready and we hope to get an approval for the same from CZA by February,” Yadav said, adding that they will start the construction soon after that. “We are eyeing a deadline of 2020-end. If all goes well, the mini zoo will be fully operational from 2021,” he added.According to him, the mini zoo will also house turtles, an aviary and a pheasantry. Harinalaya is located beside gate number 6 of Eco Park and visitors now don’t have to shell out any additional fees to visit the place. The usual entry fee of Rs 30 per person, includes the charges to Harinalaya.Inaugurated in 2016, by chief minister Mamata Banerjee, Harinalaya now houses a few spotted deer and barking deer. Though forest department had developed its plan, Hidco had allotted funds for it, said Yadav. “We also have plans to write to Hidco, seeking additional 10 acres from them so that the mini zoo can be developed in future,” said Yadav.Commenting further on the enclosure design, a senior official said that CZA gives specifications on enclosures for each and every animal. “So, before bringing the animals, we have to get sanctions for the final enclosure designs, which have been planned as per CZA guidelines, from the central authority,” the official added.This may ease some pressure on the Alipore zoo as well. A senior official had earlier said that the Alipore zoo is now flooded with rescued animals. “A zoo can’t display exotic animals and birds beyond a certain percentage of the total animals on display. Land is the need of the hour and we had earlier urged the agencies concerned to help us find land,” the official had said.

Title: Bhainsa violence: 11 more cases booked
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Hyderabad: Police registered 11 more cases in relation to the communal violence that swept Bhainsa a few days ago and arrested 68 persons till Thursday. Even as campaigning for municipal elections is under way in the town, heavy deployment of police continues to prevent recurrence of violence.

After the communal violence at Bhainsa town on Sunday night and Monday morning, police had registered six cases and arrested 59 people till Tuesday night. The initial cases were booked for violence against police, damage to a place of worship, assault, attempt to murder and destruction of property.

“Subsequently, more people have approached us with complaints pertaining to the violence. Based on the complaints, so far, we have registered 17 cases and arrested 68 offenders,” inspector-general Y Nagi Reddy said. The number of cases and arrests might increase in the coming few days.

“Election campaigning is going on in the town without any problems. We have allowed all political parties and candidates to campaign even in the violence-affected areas,” the IG said. TNN

Title: Art & culture director transferred
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Panaji: Director of art and culture Gurudas Pilarnekar has been transferred and is now appointed additional inspector general of prisons (IGP). He has also been given additional charge of superintendent of jails. The order has been issued by under-secretary (I) personnel Shashank Thakur on Thursday.

Director of civil supplies and consumer affairs Sagun Velip who has also been transferred will take over as director of art and culture.

Siddhivinayak Naik has been appointed as director of civil supplies with additional charge as member secretary of Kala Academy.

Raju Gawas, director (admin) electricity department, has been transferred and is now commissioner of labour and employment. Gawas will be replaced by Jayant Tari in the electricity department.

Title: Karnataka: With jobs scarce, scramble for quota grows
Content:
Illustration used for representational purpose

TimesView Reservations have become a trump card for political parties, who unscrupulously wield it to secure support. It was never intended to be that way. Because they were so impoverished, the Constitution provided special benefits to backward classes and women through reservation with the aim of improving their condition. The system, based on caste, was only applicable for 10 years, but it failed to address backwardness and discrimination. At the start, only SCs and STs were included in this policy, but the 1980 Mandal Commission report, virtually made it a free for all. Now, a solution has become a problem and it refuses to go away.

BENGALURU: The clamour for reservation in government services and educational institutes in the state is growing and experts suggest it has a lot to do with the lack of jobs. While some castes are demanding a hike in reservation, others want to be included in the list of Scheduled Caste and Scheduled Tribes (SC/ST).The Valmiki community for instance has taken centre stage, seeking a hike in ST quota and threatening a stir if their demand is turned down. There is a long-standing demand by Kurubas and Kodavas to be included in the ST category, while nearly 25 other small caste groups have similar demands.Ironically, dominant agrarian communities like Lingayats are also exerting pressure on the government to recognize them as ‘backward’, just so they can avail quotas in education and government jobs. And there is a mad scramble to reserve private sector jobs for locals. In fact, the government is readying a bill to this effect — largely for political reasons as the Supreme Court has capped reservations at 50%.Experts say the scenario reflects the challenges these communities are facing in education and jobs and it stems from the inability to earn a stable income from the agrarian sector. With private sector jobs also dwindling, these agrarian communities see “quotas” as a form of “security” for the community.Sandeep Shastri, political analyst, said the rush for reservation or a higher percentage of reservations is not based on unbiased empirical data on the current level of backwardness of different caste groups.“We have not been able to publish the caste census conducted in the state for fear of political fallout,” Shastri said. “In today’s identity politics, each social group wants to wrest the maximum benefit for its members, again, without any rationale, scientific or evidence-based study of the relative deprivation in each social group. Thus, protest and influence politics appears to define and decide who gets how much and not whether they really deserve it.”Prof Harish Ramaswamy, another expert, said it largely has to do with employability especially in this age of globalisation. “There is a shrinking space for government jobs,” he said. “Private sector demands are not being met by the education we are offering. There is a mismatch that has led to freshers being unemployable. In order to overcome this shrinking job scenario, reservation has taken hold. It ensures an opportunistic option which is premptive of caste consolidation and affirmative leadership. It is political opportunism of a different kind, but is not in the interest of betterment of society,” he said.

Title: Ban on acid sale in Bhopal goes up in smoke
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

BHOPAL: Despite a Supreme Court ban, acid is being sold in the city. Shopkeepers in many areas are selling it on the sly as toilet cleaner.

The main reason for sale of acid is that it is a cheap toilet cleaner and easily clears the stains on toilet tiles. Many locals argue that instead of ban on sale of acid, administration should find way to control its misuse.

Neha Saxena, a homemaker from Sharda Vihar, argued that a bottle of branded toilet cleaner costs around Rs 100- Rs 150, while a bottle of acid is available for less than Rs 50. Acid is more effective in removing floor stains. She said ban on acid results into its black marketing.

Ankit Trivedi, a college student, said that there are a number of shops that sell acid at Loha Bazaar near Peer Gate.

Cases of acid attacks have been reported in Bhopal in the past in May 2019, a 45-year-old man threw acid on his wife while she was returning home from the auto-parts shop where she worked at Hamidia Road in Hanumanganj locality at night.

The acid was so concentrated that the clothes of the woman were completely burnt. She collapsed on the road and the passer-byes covered her body with ‘gamchas’. The enraged locals thrashed the accused husband and he too fell unconscious.

Earlier in January 2019, a 32-year-old woman doctor, posted at AIIMS, was waylaid by bike-borne men and threatened of acid attack. The accused were asking her to withdraw the complaint, she registered against them.

Title: Karnataka: With jobs scarce, scramble for quota grows
Content:
Illustration used for representational purpose

TimesView Reservations have become a trump card for political parties, who unscrupulously wield it to secure support. It was never intended to be that way. Because they were so impoverished, the Constitution provided special benefits to backward classes and women through reservation with the aim of improving their condition. The system, based on caste, was only applicable for 10 years, but it failed to address backwardness and discrimination. At the start, only SCs and STs were included in this policy, but the 1980 Mandal Commission report, virtually made it a free for all. Now, a solution has become a problem and it refuses to go away.

BENGALURU: The clamour for reservation in government services and educational institutes in the state is growing and experts suggest it has a lot to do with the lack of jobs. While some castes are demanding a hike in reservation, others want to be included in the list of Scheduled Caste and Scheduled Tribes (SC/ST).The Valmiki community for instance has taken centre stage, seeking a hike in ST quota and threatening a stir if their demand is turned down. There is a long-standing demand by Kurubas and Kodavas to be included in the ST category, while nearly 25 other small caste groups have similar demands.Ironically, dominant agrarian communities like Lingayats are also exerting pressure on the government to recognize them as ‘backward’, just so they can avail quotas in education and government jobs. And there is a mad scramble to reserve private sector jobs for locals. In fact, the government is readying a bill to this effect — largely for political reasons as the Supreme Court has capped reservations at 50%.Experts say the scenario reflects the challenges these communities are facing in education and jobs and it stems from the inability to earn a stable income from the agrarian sector. With private sector jobs also dwindling, these agrarian communities see “quotas” as a form of “security” for the community.Sandeep Shastri, political analyst, said the rush for reservation or a higher percentage of reservations is not based on unbiased empirical data on the current level of backwardness of different caste groups.“We have not been able to publish the caste census conducted in the state for fear of political fallout,” Shastri said. “In today’s identity politics, each social group wants to wrest the maximum benefit for its members, again, without any rationale, scientific or evidence-based study of the relative deprivation in each social group. Thus, protest and influence politics appears to define and decide who gets how much and not whether they really deserve it.”Prof Harish Ramaswamy, another expert, said it largely has to do with employability especially in this age of globalisation. “There is a shrinking space for government jobs,” he said. “Private sector demands are not being met by the education we are offering. There is a mismatch that has led to freshers being unemployable. In order to overcome this shrinking job scenario, reservation has taken hold. It ensures an opportunistic option which is premptive of caste consolidation and affirmative leadership. It is political opportunism of a different kind, but is not in the interest of betterment of society,” he said.

Title: Man killed, two injured in three separate accidents
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Nashik: A person was killed and two injured in three separate accidents in the city.

A motorist was killed in an accident at Tarwala Nagar on Wednesday at 12.30pm, the Panchavati police said.

The deceased, 59-year-old Nitin Tulsiram More, was a resident of Shingada Talav.

Police said the motorist was riding negligently, as a result, he lost his balance after he jumped over the speed breaker at Tarwala Nagar signal. He suffered injuries in his head after falling from his bike. The hospital declared him brought dead. The police have lodged FIR against the victim for negligent driving under section 304A, 279, 337 of Indian Penal Code and sections of the Motor Vehicle Act 1984.

In a second incident, a person who was on his motorcycle was hit by another motorcycle on Sunday near Datta Mandir signal, Nashik Road.

The Upnagar police said that the victim, Ankush Daulat Jadhav (38) and his wife Pratibha Jadhav (33), were on their motorcycle when it was hit by another bike. The man was injured in the accident. His wife lodged a complaint.

According to the Upnagar police the accused was riding the bike triple seat and none of them wore a helmet.

Police have registered the case under section 279, 337, 427 under IPC.

In the third incident, a truck driver knocked down a person who was riding his motorcycle on January 1 at Shramik Nagar-Satpur road.

According to Satpur police station the motorist was hit from behind. The complainant received severe head injury. The 32-year-old complainant is a resident of Anandvalli.

Title: ‘Sewerage work should be mechanised’
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Panaji: There is an immediate need to stop manual sewerage work and replace it with a mechanised cleaning system, said Manju Diler, a member of the National Commission for Safai Karmacharis, Union ministry of social justice and empowerment.

She was speaking at a meeting with the North Goa collector, directors of social welfare, municipality administration, Corporation of the City of Panaji (CCP) commissioner, deputy labour commissioner and other officials, held in Panaji on Thursday.

The objective of the meeting was to discuss and review welfare measures, work conditions and compensation given to sewerage workers.

“It is necessary to ensure that safety equipment is provided to sanitation workers,” she said. She discussed the minimum wages of the employees of Sulabh International and spoke about the latest development project entailing the laying of sewerage pipelines across the state.

Diler asked for the data pertaining to the promotion of sewerage workers working for urban local bodies such as municipalities, and discussed measures to be taken to improve and enhance their standard of living.

Director of social welfare, Umeshchandra Joshi said the Goa government was implementing various schemes for the betterment of sewerage workers. Awareness camps are aimed at educating sanitation workers about the schemes implemented for their welfare. Diler therefore suggested to organize more camps regularly to create more awareness about the schemes and measures for the workers with proper registration to inform to their office.
