The event was flagged off by chairman of jallikattu organizing committee retired district principal judge C Manickam in the presence of revenue minister R B Udayakumar, Madurai district collector T G Vinay, south zone IG K P Shanmuga Rajeswaram and district superintendent of police N Manivannan.

Madurai city police commissioner S Davidson Devasirvatham, MLAs K Manickam (Sholavandan) and P Moorthy (Madurai East) were present.

The event kick started at 8 am with the release of a few temple bulls, which are not be caught as a customary, and ended at 5 pm, after an extension of 30 minutes based on the request of the jallikattu committee. As many as 936 bull tamers and 700 bulls had registered for the event.

While bikes were presented as gifts at the event last year, a hatch back car was announced as the first prize for best bull tamer this year. Tamers were sent into the playing area in batches - 50 tamers per batches with one hour allowed for each batch.

It was raining gifts for tamers and bull owners. Apart from the car, gold and silver coins, bicycles, silver and bronze utensils, plastic furniture, steel bureau and travel bags were disbursed as prizes to the winning bull tamers and bull owners.

People not only from Madurai district, but also from other neighbouring districts thronged at Palamedu, which wore festive look through the day. Makeshift shops were set up on the roads leading to Palamedu.

A few foreigners also visited the jallikattu. Francois and Corentin from Nantes in France, who are on a nine-month long Asia tour, visited Palamedu. “We reached Madurai on Wednesday and came to know about the sport. It was the first time we heard about it. It was a great experience watching the sport, which is meant for only strong people,” Corentin said.

The event was streamed in large screens in a few places to control the crowd. It was telecast live on Madurai Kavalan app, Madurai district police Youtube channel and Facebook page.

The arena witnessed huge crowd. People climbed on to the terrace of houses nearby to watch the event. Visitors were charged between Rs 500 and Rs 1000 to view the event from some houses and galleries.

Confusion prevailed in the first few rounds as there was slackness in declaring whether bull tamer won or the bull won, leading to dispute between bull owners and tamers in collecting the prizes. More than 2,000 police personnel were deployed at various places to manage the crowd.

Title: Madurai: 66 injured in Avaniyapuram jallikattu
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

As many as 66 people suffered injuries in the Avaniyapuram jallikattu event in Madurai

MADURAI: As many as 66 people suffered injuries in the Avaniyapuram jallikattu event in Madurai, which took place on Wednesday.

As many as 37 of them were bull tamers, while 29 were bull owners and spectators, who had gathered at the venue from various parts of Madurai district and its surrounding districts. Among the injured, nine people were referred to a tertiary care centre as the nature of the injuries were series.

According to officials, a total of 733 bulls were registered for the event and out of which 725 were given permission after screening. As many as 641 bulls were released through vaadivasal before the jallikattu organizing committee called it a day at 4 pm. While 730 bull tamers had registered themselves to take part, only 610 turned up.

Vijay from Jaihindpuram tamed 14 bulls and was adjudged as the best tamer. He was followed by Barathkumar at second position with 13 bulls and Thirunavukkarasu from Muthupattti at third position with 10 bulls. A bull belonging to police inspector Anuradha from Pudukottai district stole the show by giving jittery to bull tamers. They could not stand against the ferocious bull and climbed up to the fence. The bull left the arena after nine-long pulsating minutes. It was adjudged the best bull of the event.

Various elected representatives including Revenue Minister R B Udayakumar were present. Jallikattu organizing committee chairman C Manickam, collector T G Vinay, police commissioner S Davidson Devasirvatham and corporation commissioner S Visakan took part in the event.

Title: Harish says will solve Tellapur woes post polls
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Hyderabad: Minister Harish Rao visited Tellapur and interacted with locals ahead of the municipal polls. He said that a review meeting would be held once the polls were over to address the concerns in the area.

“Within one month I will bring all officials to your area to take up issues that have been bothering you including the need for police outpost, dumpyard, electricity substation, road network,” he said.

About 300 people attended the even organised by the local community members on Wednesday. Ramana Eshwaragari, president, Tellapur Neighbourhood Association, said, “The minister has assured that our demands will be looked into. We are hoping for the best.”

A 10-point memorandum was presented by association members to the minister.TNN

Title: IIFPT signs MoUs with eight institutes
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Thanjavur: The Indian Institute of Food Processing Technology (IIFPT) here has signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) with eight national institutions to share resources for formulating collaborative research, skill promotion and exchange of faculty and students.

Director of IIFPT, C Anandharamakrishnan signed the MoUs and exchanged it with the vice-chancellors and directors of the partnering institutes.

The institutes are Punjab Agricultural University, Maharaja Ranjit Singh Punjab Technical University, National Dairy Research Institute, Central Institute of Post-Harvest Engineering and Technology, Indian Institute of Wheat and Barley Research, Sant Longowal Institute of Engineering and Technology, National Agriculture Food Biotechnology Institute and Guru Nanak College.

“These MoUs will yield huge benefits to farmers and entrepreneurs through technological intervention of the institutions to reduce food wastage, technology for an alternative of single-use plastic, indigenous processing machinery to adopt at farm levels,” said Union minister for food processing industries Harsimrat Kaur Badal, who chaired the ceremony. TNN

Title: Pvt co hands over data of of 1.3L water consumers
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Aurangabad: In a major development towards water tax recovery, the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) has received the data of 1.3 lakh consumers from the private company assigned to manage water supply for two years until September 2016.

A report published by TOI on December 29 highlighted that the municipal corporation is not issuing water bills to its consumers due to the non-availability of data.

Under a contract signed with the civic body, the Aurangabad City Water Utility Company Ltd. (ACWUCL) was managing the water supply of the city for two years. The company issued water bills to consumers and also carried out the recovery of water tax. However, after the AMC terminated the contract with the company in September 2016, no formal handover of the water supply system was given to the civic body.

The ACWUCL also did not share the data of the water consumers with the AMC. Therefore, the civic body was not issuing any water bills to consumers. The TOI report stated that the AMC tax officer had agreed that the municipal corporation does not have their consumer data due to which they could not issue water tax bills. Subsequently, municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey had said that that he will seek data from the previous water supply company in return of clearance of its outstanding dues.

Tax officer Karan Chavan on Thursday said that the AMC has received the data for 1.30 lakh water consumers from the water supply company. “The data includes all the consumers that were being taxed by the compa0ny in 2016. The data was bifurcated into different zones. We have forwarded the data to the respective zones,” Chavan said.

Title: Govt banks on study to curb Agra e-way crashes
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Lucknow: Alarmed over fatal accidents on the Agra-Lucknow Expressway, UP government has commissioned a study of accidents on the 302km e-way.

The transport department has engaged not-for-profit social organisation SaveLIFE Foundation to study the pattern of accidents and find scientific solutions to curb them. The agency would also enable the government to adopt zero-fatality corridors on pilot basis, targeting high-fatality stretches. The aim is to bring down the number of accidents. If successful, the pilot study will be replicated.

“The organisation will help undertake scientific study of the problem and suggest necessary strategy and policy changes to make road journey safer. It will develop an action plan to roll out road safety interventions and also help the department organise training workshops in basic trauma life support, forensic investigation and safe systems,” said transport commissioner Dheeraj Sahu.

The study is significant, considering that the maximum number of lives lost due to road accidents in India are from UP every year.

In 2018, 22,528 people were killed in 44,568 accidents in UP, according to data from the transport ministry.

Founder of SaveLIFE Foundation Piyush Tewari said that his organisation, which has a team of 15 qualified road engineers, would undertake systematic investigation of road crashes.

A separate study of Greater Noida Expressway will also be conducted alongside, said an official.

Title: Withdraw cases against Nellai Kannan said IUML
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

TIRUNELVELI: Indian Union Muslim League (IUML) has demanded that the state government withdraw the cases against writer and orator ‘Nellai’ Kannan. Party general secretary K M Kader Mohideen said that a word colloquially used in Tirunelveli region for ‘work’ and has been culturally and linguistically accepted has been wrongly interpreted as ‘killing’ to frame the orator. He was speaking after meeting Nellai Kannan at his residence on Thursday.

In response to a question on videos in which a Muslim woman condemns Nellai Kannan and seeks action against him for allegedly framing Muslims as terrorists, he said that non-Muslims making controversial statements wearing burka and skull cap has been happening in TN and India at large. “Many such fake videos are doing the rounds in social media. They should not be believed,” he said. Opposing the Citizenship Amendment Act , National Register of Citizens (NRC) and National Population Register (NPR), he said the Centre should withdraw them or make necessary changes. “Otherwise, there will be strong protests across the country,” he added.

Title: Madurai: Podhumbu village youth tames 16 bulls, wins car
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

MADURAI: S Prabakaran, 24, from Podhumbu village in Madurai district with his scintillating performance managed to tame 16 bulls, though his turn came four hours after the event kick started.

Prabakaran, jersey number 41, was given away a hatchback car worth Rs 6 lakh, sponsored by a couple of traders. After receiving the gift from the jallikattu organizing committee amid thunderous applauds and whistle, the youth thanked his friends for their motivation and support inside the arena and outside.

“A neighbour named Chelladurai was the first man to take me to play with bulls when I was a teenager. Since then, I have developed a special bonding with bulls. Over the years I have honed my bull taming skills after learning them from many people,” Prabakaran, a mini load vehicle driver, said.

He has never imagined winning a car and it would be his prized possession as he had took part in umpteen numbers of games in various places and tamed a large number of bulls. But it was a special day at Palamedu, said the school dropout.

Raja, 25, from Iyyapanayapatti village, tamed 13 bulls and Karthick, 19, from Karuppayurani tamed 10 bulls and won second and third prize respectively. Friends and relatives of the winners carried them on their shoulders around the arena to celebrate the success.

A bull belonging to Ramesh from Kamachipuram in Dindigul district was adjudged the best bull. The bull owner received an indigenous cow with a 12-day-old calf, sponsored by Pon Kumar, a jallikattu enthusiast from Alanganallur.

A bull belonging to Selvam from Chettiyapatti won second prize, and the bull of Karthick Kannan from Palanganatham won the third prize.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Man booked for harassing journalist
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: A former emplyoee of a Tamil magazine was booked for mentally harassing a woman journalist of a Tamil television channel with abusive comments.

The sessions court police in Trichy registered a case on Tuesday against Karthik of Trichy on charges of verbally abusing, stalking, criminally intimidating the woman journalist under sections of the IPC, harassing her under the Tamil Nadu Prohibition of Women Harassment Act and transmitting sexually explicit comments in electronic form under section of the Information Technology Act.

According to a complaint filed by the woman, Karthik was administering a WhatsApp group called ‘Uzhaippaligal Kuzhu’ in which he had journalists and several others as members. On January 7, Karthik had posted some comments about the woman’s personal life which came to her notice. Upset over this, she questioned Karthik and asked her to withdraw his comments. But, he refused to do so and continue to harass her. Unable to bear the harassment, she lodged a complaint on Tuesday. Based on her complaint, FIR was registered against Karthik. Police are yet to arrest him.

Title: BJP vetoes civic study tour to Andaman, team to take U-turn and visit Chandigarh
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Chandigarh is a planned city and has good things for us to learn from, said a Shiv Sena corporator

MUMBAI: The BMC ’s civic works committee, which had intended to visit Andaman Islands to study their drainage system, will now head to Chandigarh instead. The Andaman plan was cancelled at the last minute after BJP members in the committee objected to it.

BJP members said Mumbai will learn little from Andaman and added such a tour should be avoided in view of the BMC’s depleting financial collections.

The committee led by Shiv Sena amended its study tour proposal at Thursday’s civic works meeting in favour of Chandigarh. Sena members said BJP had decided against the tour long back following their group leader’s instructions, and no one opposed the proposal.

There are different committees in the BMC, including a works committee that comprises corporators from different political parties proportionate to their party’s strength. They plan national and international study tours for members on public expense, to study existing infrastructure in other cities and countries for implementation in Mumbai. It is alleged in the past, they rarely submitted detailed reports about their visits.

BJP’s Snehal Shah said, “We opposed the tour proposal as there is nothing for us to learn from Andaman’s drainage system. The last study tour was to Shillong but the members did not inform us what they learned there.”

Makrand Narvekar, another BJP corporator, said, “We asked the committee to record our opposition to the visit, following which the tour location was changed. Reports indicate that the BMC’s financial collections are very poor. Then why do we need such a study tour?”

Senior Sena corporator Shraddha Jadhav said civic officials visit various places to learn new things. She said, “Some members were not comfortable with Andaman so I suggested Chandigarh and all agreed to it. Chandigarh is a planned city and has various good things for us to learn for implementation in the city.”

Arundhati Dudwadkar, another Sena corporator, said, “BJP had decided to not join the tour because of instructions from their group leader.”

Title: Woman Maoist surrenders
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Hyderabad: A 26-year-old Maoist , who was underground for a decade, surrendered before the Bhadradri Kothagudem police on Thursday.

She carried a reward of Rs 4 lakh on her head. The surrendered Maoist, Madakam Sunny alias Roja, was Maoist party’s Shabari area committee in-charge and local organisation squad commander of area committee member rank.

“She realised that there is less support for the Maoist party in public and decided to live a peaceful life,” Bhadradri Kothagudem SP Sunil Dutt said. tnn

Title: Tamil Nadu: Key accused in ganja cultivation in Karur arrested
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: Six weeks after illegal ganja crops were found in a village in Karur district, the narcotics intelligence bureau - criminal investigation department (NIB-CID) has secured L Arunachalam, 49, prime accused in the case.

Two people have already been arrested in connection with the illegal activity. Arunachalam was hiding outside Tamil Nadu and had come to his village Mayilampatti to celebrate Pongal.

A NIB-CID team led by deputy superintendent of police E Kamaraj and inspector K Balusamy secured Arunachalam from Mayilampatti bus stand on Tuesday. Balusamy said that Arunachalam was hiding in Bengaluru and could secure him by tracking his mobile tower signal.

On November 27 last year, a team of Trichy city police carried out search at a farm in Thennilai village of Kulithalai in Karur district. They identified ganja plantation raised across 72 cents of land in the midst of a seven-acre maize plantation.

V Murugan, 49, and P Thangavel, 70, both from Varshanadu of Theni district were arrested from the farm that day.

The land belonging to K Zakir Hussain, 55, from Kumbakonam, was taken on lease by Arunachalam for the last two years. He had raised the ganja crop with the help of Murugan and Thangavel who had prior experience in raising the crop.

The entire plantation was brought down and total 2,790kg of green ganja worth Rs 28 lakh was kept in police custody.

Title: Academic audit must for affiliation, colleges told
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

A large section of academic institutions affiliated to Bamu is believed to be running without performing acade... Read More

AURANGABAD: Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar Marathwada University (Bamu) has asked colleges to carry out an academic audit failing which, the institutes will lose the affiliation.

According to an official release, the colleges have also been told to submit necessary proposals before January 31.

A large section of academic institutions affiliated to Bamu is believed to be running without performing academic audits for a few years. The university has around 410 affiliated colleges with cumulative student strength of over 3 lakh and all these institutions will have to comply with the latest directive.

The move, which has been ordered by vice-chancellor Pramod Yeole has been welcomed by the student community.

“The necessary proposals must be routed through official website of the university before January 31 and should be submitted in-person with supporting documents before February 5. Institutions that have undergone academic audit in the recent past must also carry out the desired audit afresh. The message is loud and clear that no affiliation will be granted to any of the institution from the upcoming academic year if the audit is not performed,” Bamu’s pro-VC Pravin Wakte said.

Stating that the objective of the academic audit would be to oversee continuation of affiliation through a systematic process, the university authorities have appealed to all the colleges to carry out the desired exercise in letter and spirit.

The TOI on December 24, 2019, had reported that Bamu, under the leadership of new VC, has defined the necessary framework for carrying out the academic audit.

The academic audit committee shall consist of a retired VC or pro-VC as its chairman and external as well as internal members. The external members will be charted accountant, engineer or architect and renowned academician of the rank of professor.

The internal member will be three experts of the rank of associated professor from different disciplines. As per norms devised by Bamu, the audit committee will recommend to the academic council of the university the period for which affiliation may be granted to the audited institution and can have a right to recommend freezing of admissions for the first year in case of unsatisfactory performance.

Student activist Tukaram Saraf said, “The Maharashtra Public University Act, 2016, has mandated academic audit for all affiliated institutions. Even if the legislation has been implemented since the last two academic years, the provision of an academic audit was skipped by the then authorities,” he said.

Title: Regulation of train services in Madurai division
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Due to track maintenance work, the Madurai railway division has announced changes in following train services from January 18 to 29.

The services of train no. 56624 Madurai – Palani passenger will be fully cancelled from January 18 to 22. Instead a passenger train will leave Madurai at 6.30am and reach Palani at 10am with stoppages of train no. 56624.

Train nos. 56734/56735 Sengottai – Madurai – Sengottai passenger will be partially cancelled between Virudhunagar and Madurai from January 19 to 29, except January 26. Train nos. 56319/56320 Nagercoil – Coimbatore – Nagercoil fast passenger will be partially cancelled between Virudhunagar and Dindigul from January 19 to 24. Train no. 07686 Rameswaram – Hyderabad special is rescheduled to leave at 7.45am instead of 5am. It will be handed over to Trichy railway division at 2.30pm. Train no. 56826 Tirunelveli – Erode passenger will be handed over to Salem division late by 115 minutes on January 18, 19, 21 ,22.tnn

Title: Bengaluru: Heartburn drug still under lens, but 5 doctors give it clean chit
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

Title: Rajesh Tope offers Jayakwadi water for 2.07 lakh hectare
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: Maharashtra cabinet minister and Jalna district guardian minister Rajesh Tope announced on Thursday that the water from Jayakwadi dam will be provided for irrigation on 2.07 lakh hectares during rabi and summer crop seasons.

A meeting of the Canal Advisory Committee was held on Thursday, which was led by Tope. In the meeting, water management of major projects in Aurangabad, Jalna, Beed, Parbhani, Osmanabad and Latur were discussed.

Tope declared the plan of distributing water from major projects including Jayakwadi, Nimna Dudhna, Nandur Madhmeshwar Canal and Majalgaon dam.

He said Jayakwadi has 100% water storage (2170.935 million cubic metre water storage) and water will be supplied from the dam for all the approved water supply schemes for drinking water and industrial needs until July 31, 2020.

“Two cycles of water supply for rabbi crop and four cycles for summer crop will be provided. As much as 2.07 lakh hectare land will be irrigated from water in the Jayakwadi reservoir, left and right canals,” Tope said.

With 100% storage, Nandur Madhmeshwar canal will also supply water until July 31. The water in the reservoir and the canal of the Nandur Madhmeshwar project will be irrigating 17,600 and 4,700 hectare of land respectively.

However, with poor water storage of 13%, the Nimna Dudhna project will be able to support one cycle only for rabbi crop from its dead storage. “Only drinking water and approved industrial schemes will be provided through the project,” the cabinet minister said.

The Majalgaon project in Beed, with 312 million cubic metre water storage, is filled to its capacity and therefore all the drinking water and industrial needs depend on the project. A total of 46,000 hectare land will be irrigated through the project.

Nimna Terna project in Osmanabad has 35% water storage. Apart from drinking water and industrial needs, the project will suffice agricultural needs by irrigating 2,932 hectare land through three cycles in rabbi season. Tope said that due to a large number of vacant posts in the Command Area Development Authority (Cada) and water resources department, the retired officials and new people will be hired on a contractual basis.

Title: Illegal mobile towers: AMC gets Rs 4.14 crore towards property tax
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Aurangabad: The Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) has received a cheque of Rs 4.14 crore from the high court towards property tax dues for illegal mobile towers across the city on Thursday.

With this, the total recovery of property tax from mobile towers this financial year has reached Rs 8 crore. After taking charge on December 9, municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey had underlined that improving AMC’s financial condition was his top priority.

Subsequently, several measures were taking by the civic body, including intensified tax recovery and mobile tower sealing drives. According to AMC tax officer Karan Chavan, two mobile companies had deposited Rs 4 crore in the high court when dispute related to double taxation was on.

“On Thursday, we received a cheque of Rs 4.14 crore from the court in which Rs 14 lakh is towards the interest of the deposited money,” he said.

AMC legal advisor Aparna Thete said the civic body has previously received Rs 4 crore in different instalments for mobile tower tax through the court. “Altogether, the AMC is expecting a recovery of Rs 30 crore towards property tax from mobile companies. However, that amount is calculated based on double tax. The decision of court is awaited on double taxation,” she said.

The AMC had imposed double taxation on telecom companies for erecting illegal mobile towers in city as per section 267 (a) of the Maharashtra Municipal Corporations Act, 1949. The telecom companies subsequently had approached the Aurangabad Bench of Bombay high court seeking exemption from paying penalty for failure to pay taxes.

Mayor Nandkumar Ghodele said that the city has around 600 mobile towers of which only 64 are legal.

“Our lawyer has informed that these illegal mobile towers are not protected under the court directive. Hence, the AMC holds the right to demolish or seal the towers under sections 51 and 52 of Maharashtra Regional and Town Planning Act, 1966,” Ghodele said, adding that the list of illegal towers is with the AMC and action will begin soon.

Title: Beware of fake customer care numbers, Cyberabad Police warn
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Cyberabad Police issued an advisory asking people not to trust random websites displaying customer care numbers of popular brands.

In a recent case reported at cyber crime police station of Cyberabad , the victim ordered sweets worth Rs 200 through Zomato App. “The victim noticed foul smell from the sweets. He searched for Zomato’s customer care number and dialled a mobile number he found on a webpage. It was a fake customer care number set up by a fraudster,” Cyber crime SI Gowtam said.

Promising to refund the amount, the fraudster sought details of victim’s bank account, UPI PIN number and some other details. “After obtaining the details, the fraudsters transferred Rs 70,000 from victim’s bank account. Customer care employees never ask for OTP, UPI PIN or net banking password,” police said.

Title: Madurai: Doctor, six others booked for wrong treatment, threatening patient
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representational image

MADURAI: A doctor, nurse and five others were booked on Wednesday for providing treatment which caused side effects and threatening the patient to not go to the police.

Duraipandi M went to Santh Clinic in Bethaniyapuram on November 7 seeking treatment for fever. The doctor at the clinic, Dr Selvaperumal attended to the patient and duly asked nurse Mahalakshmi to administer an intramuscular injection. However, later, Duraipandi, while not recovering from the fever also developed swelling in the buttocks. He sought treatment again at Santh Clinic, where Dr Selvaperumal referred him to another private clinic in Arasaradi.

After four days of admission there, Duraipandi went for further treatment to another private clinic on the bypass road and paid Rs 10,000. Spending around Rs 4 lakh for the treatment in total, Duraipandi asked Dr Selvaperumal for compensation. After the doctor continued to delay payment, on December 23, five unidentified people came to Duraipandi’s house and threatened him not to ask for money from the doctor nor go to the police. Dr Selvaperumal is allegedly a doctor of siddha medicine but was found to be providing allopathic treatment.

A case has been registered against Dr Selvaperumal, the nurse and the five men under various sections, including under the Indian Medical Council Act, for cheating and criminal intimidation. The Karimedu police are investigating and the accused are yet to be arrested.

Title: Udupi geared up for Paryaya feast
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Udupi: The smell of ghee and melting jaggery is wafting across the streets of the temple town as preparations for the Paryaya feast get under way. Ascending seer Eeshapriya Teertha of Adamaru Mutt is set to roll out the mat for more than 50,000 devotees who will arrive to witness the biennial transition on Saturday.

More than 100 cooks are at work at Bailakere ground from 7am to 5.30pm every day, churning out sweets and savouries for the feast. About 1.2 lakh sajjige vade, and 60,000 pieces each of laddoo and wheat burfi are being readied.

Following in his predecessor’s footsteps, the Adamaru seer has also decided to do away with sugar and maida in Mutt preparations. Jaggery and whole grains will be used instead.

A buffet system has been set up at ‘Annakrishna’ while ‘Annaprajna’ will cater to those who want to squat for a traditional feast. Arecanut plates and steel glasses will replace plastic cutlery.

The first ‘Horakanike’ (feast offering) was from fisherfolk, Bhajana Mandalis and Mattu Gulla Belegarara Sangha. Udupi District Yuva Brahmana Parishad activists have taken the responsibility of the ‘Ananth Ugrana’, the storeroom where Horakanike items are arranged systematically. Forty tonnes of rice, 3 tonnes of jaggery, 1,000 litres of oil, 3 tonnes of Mattu Gulla (green brinjal), 1,000kg of cucumber and 500kg of pumpkin have already been offered. The Yuva Brahmana Parishad will maintain the inventory for the next two years.

Mattu Gulla sambar

on menu

The Krishna Mutt will serve dinner on Thursday (January 17) from 7pm to midnight. Chef Vishnumurthy Bhat said rice, sambar, payasam and buttermilk would be served for dinner. For Anna Santharpana on January 18, two types of curry, rice, Mattu Gulla sambar, masala vade and buttermilk will be served to devotees from 10.30am to 2.30pm. Godhi (wheat) payasam, laddoo and wheat burfi will also be served.

Title: Over 600 bulls take part in Periya Suriyur Jallikattu
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Trichy: With the entry of Suriyur Kasi, the village temple bull, through the Vadivasal to the jallikattu arena in Periya Suriyur village, Trichy district witnessed its first Jallikattu of the season on Thursday.

District collector S Sivarasu inaugurated the event at 8 30 am, and it went on till 4 pm with the participation of 610 bulls. The event held on Mattu Pongal witnessed as many as 344 bull tamers entering the arena in six batches.

Periya Suriyur jallikattu happens every year on the second day of the Tamil month of Thai. On Thursday owners of untamed bulls and successful bull tamers went home with prizes including bicycle, refrigerator, armchair, bronze lamp, pressure cooker, gold and silver coins.

In a novel initiative, former Trichy MP and AIADMK Trichy urban district secretary P Kumar gave away native breed male calves to the owners of untamed bulls and successful bull tamers. While he distributed three such calves to the winners, he said that the move was to encourage people to rear native breeds. Thiruverumbur DMK MLA Anbil Mahesh Poyyamozhi, who witnessed the event, gave away gold coins to the winners.

Jothilakshmi, 40, from Woraiyur in Trichy who came along with family sustained injuries when a bull coming out of the jallikattu arena accidentally hit her. She sustained injuries on her thigh and hip and was rushed to the government hospital for treatment. Doctors said that her condition is stable.

A total of 29 people suffered injuries during the event, a sizable number of them were injured outside the jallikattu arena after being charged by bulls coming out of the arena.

A sizable number of bulls were waiting event after 3 pm, the scheduled time for the event to get over. This prompted the organisers to extend the event for another hour to allow some more bulls to enter the arena.

The event by and large went peacefully, and police claimed that it could be achieved only due to strict vigil.

By checking entry of unauthorised people and minor violations by bull tamers in the arena police could ensure discipline, said Zia Ul Haq, Trichy district superintendent of police. Trichy zone Deputy Inspector General (DIG) of police V Balakrishnan asked visitors coming on motorcycle to compulsorily wear helmet.

Trichy district police has announced a cash prize of Rs 5,000 each to a bull owner and a bull tamer for the overall performance in all the five jallikattu events in Trichy district. “Almost every policeman will be part of Jallikattu arrangement at the end of this season. Being an integral part of the cultural event, we chose to recognise and reward best practice among bull owners and bull tamers,” said Zia Ul Haq.

Title: Ten arrested for flouting norms in rooster duel in village in Karur district
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: Ten people were arrested by the Aravakurichi police for flouting norms on the second day of the rooster duel held in Poolamvalasu village of Karur district on Thursday.

People gathered in large numbers at Poolamvalasu village to witness the duels in which more than 1,000 roosters were brought to the venue. During that time, some of them were found betting on the birds and engaged in gambling. Police personnel present there arrested Balakrishnan, 39, Kalimuthu, 40, Karthikeyan, 33 and Mariappan, 45 for betting on roosters and gambling, Rajendran, 42, Ramesh, 39, Vadivel, 39, and Murugesan, 40, Murthy, 30, Senthil Kumar, 34 for tying knives on the claws of the roosters.

Police have registered cases under four sections against the 10 arrested and seized four knives, eight roosters and Rs 1,150 cash used for betting.

Among the popular venues for rooster duel in Karur, a ban was imposed by the district administration in 2014 following the death of two people after they sustained injuries from the knives tied on the claws of the fighter roosters. Organisers of the event however managed to get permission from the high court last year.

This year, the district administration laid down a 21-point regulation to be strictly followed by the organizers. The roosters were allowed to take part in the event only after undergoing medical examination by a team from the animal husbandry. “Roosters were subjected to doping test to check if they were given alcohol. Only healthy roosters without any injuries could take part in the event,” said a veterinarian.

Title: 32 deaths in 4 terms, MLAs call for Vaastu check of MP assembly building
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Bhopal: ‘Vaastu dosh’ of the MP Vidhan Sabha is again a talking point after leader of opposition Gopal Bhargava voiced the concern at the opening day of the two-day special session of assembly on Thursday. While paying homage to Joura MLA Banwarilal Sharma, who died on December 21 last year, Bhargava said there could be supernatural element responsible for the high number of deaths among sitting MLAs in Madhya Pradesh.

The MP assembly opened its gates in 1996, and rumours of it being jinxed began swirling in a couple of years. At least 32 sitting MLAs have died since 1998, triggering fears that it has a Vaastu dosh.

“We are a House of only 230 members. Yet, in every term since we shifted to the new assembly, eight to 10 sitting MLAs die. Is it the Vaastu or the constant mental and physical pressures that an MLA has to put-up with?” he wondered in the assembly on Thursday.

The Madhya Pradesh assembly building, designed by famous architect Charles Correa, was constructed between 1983 and 1993. It resembles the Sanchi Stupa, which many MLAs believe is inauspicious. Living beings should not be placed in a structure essentially built for the dead, they argue.

Vaastu of the building has been checked more than once. When the Digvijaya Singh government was in power, former Speaker Shrinivas Tiwari held a special puja to “purify the building”. He also called priests from his constituency in Rewa and held a havan for four days. Ten MLAs died during that term, including minister Likhiram Kavre who was beheaded by Maoists.

“Some believe in Vaastu, many don’t,” the LOP said. “Some even make fun that we are talking of it. But we need to consider that the number of deaths of sitting MLAs is unusually high,” he later told reporters outside the House. “There are two aspects — one, the Vaastu of the building, and second, the work hours and stress of MLAs who have no fixed time to eat or sleep. Sometimes, an MLA works till 2am in the night, listening patiently to every person who approaches him,” Bhargava said.

Former Speaker Sitasharan Sharma, BJP MLA from Hoshangabad, said, “During my tenure as Speaker, there were complaints from MLAs. We got a Vaastu expert from Itarsi, who recommended a small change.” A water tank outside the Speaker’s room was filled with soil and converted into a garden and a wall was broken to install a small gate. Changes were also made after Speaker Ishwardas Rohani, deputy Speaker Harvansh Singh and LOP Jamuna Devi died in the 13th assembly’s tenure.

It is not just BJP that is asking for a Vaastu review or a close look at \mental and physical stress of MLAs. Congress minister for revenue Govind Singh Rajput said, “We believe in Vaastu and since the assembly has been shifted to this building, there have been many accidental deaths. The Vaastu needs to be checked.”

Sitting MLAs death in each term

11th assembly 1998-2003, 10 deaths: Omkar Tiwari, Krishnapal Singh, Dariyav Singh Solanki, Magan Singh Patel, Randheer Singh, Likhiram Kavre, Shiv Pratap Singh, Saiyogeeta Singh Devi Deshmukh, Vesta Patel, Lal Singh Patel

12th assembly 2003-2008, 7 deaths: Kishorilal Verma, Dilip Bhatere, Prakash Sonkar, Amar Singh Kothar, Lavkesh Singh, Lakshman Singh Gaud, Sunil Naik

13th assembly 2008- 13, 6 deaths: Makhanlal Jatav, Jamuna Devi (LOP), Ratnesh Soloman, Khuman Singh Shivaji, Harvansh Singh (deputy Speaker), Ishwardas Rohani (Speaker)

14th assembly 2013-18, 9 deaths: Prabhat Pandey, Rajesh Yadav, Tukoji Rao Puwar, Sajjan Singh Uike, Rajendra Dadu, Satyadev Katare (LOP), Prem Singh, Mahendra Singh Kalukhera, Ram Singh Yadav

Title: It is all talk and show at the governor’s address
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Chennai: The customary governor’s address to the state legislative assembly at the beginning of new year session has turned out to be an exercise in futility and reduced to a farce. A colonial legacy, it could as well be converted into a chief minister’s address, since it is prepared by the cabinet and not the governor .

It is only the media, political circles, and a section of the intelligentsia, which is aware that the governor is merely reading out the text prepared by the state government , and the views expressed are not his at all.

The public image is of the governor having supported the policies and projects of the state, though the governor and the chief minister belong to different parties, wedded to different ideologies.

All ruling parties, even those like the DMK which in the past were opposed to the very institution of governor, have tended to use the motion of thanks to the governor for his address as an endorsement of its own policies and schemes. The AIADMK MLAs led by the ministers thump the benches whenever the governor reads out portions, hailing the government’s achievements or the party’s leaders like M G Ramachandran and J Jayalalithaa, especially when the governor describes her as Puratchi Thalaivi (revolutionary leader). During the DMK rule, MLAs thumped the desks and rejoiced when the governor referred to M Karunanidhi as ‘Doctor Kalaignar’. The ruling parties derived a sense of vicarious pleasure when they got the governors (from adversarial parties) to hail their leaders.

Tamil Nadu has had a history of governors and chief ministers getting along well, barring the brief tenure of Channa Reddy, who accorded sanction to prosecute the then CM J Jayalalithaa in a corruption case. She even accused him of misbehaviour.

In fact, other governors had such a good relationship with their CMs, that there were charges of gifts being exchanged. Those that shared a bonhomie included, S L Khurana, who went out of his way to carry out the Centre’s move to bring back MGR as CM though he underwent a major surgery in the US. But the good times lasted only till it made sense to the Centre’s political calculation. For instance, Fathima Beevi was allowed by the NDA-government at the Centre to invite Jayalalithaa to form the government after the 2001 elections (though she was disqualified as an MLA). Fathima was later removed, apparently under pressure from the BJP’s Delhi ally, the DMK. K K Shah, too, was on good terms with the then chief minister, M Karunanidhi, even during the Emergency. He had praised the Karunanidhi government one day, but the next day was asked to give a report seeking dismissal of the DMK government. He did so to oblige his bosses at the Centre.

Some governors, like Surjit Singh Barnala, had more problems with the ruling parties at the Centre than in the state. When the Chandra Shekhar government at the Centre directed him to send a report recommending dismissal of the DMK government in 1991 for supporting the LTTE, Barnala refused to comply. He chose to resign rather than bow to Delhi’s orders.

The stand of the DMK in the 1950s and the 1960s was in favour of abolition of the posts of governors. "Where is the need for goats to have beards and for states to have governors" was the refrain. There is even less need now for governors to make addresses to the legislature when the text is prepared by the state cabinet. It makes even less sense now when the presentation of the budget has been advanced in many states to early February, when the ruling party can spell out its policies and schemes.

The voting on the motion of thanks to the governor for his address to the assembly is a mere formality almost throughout the country. Governors can seek changes of some words or a phrase, but it is up to the ministers to make them. In the long run, it would be less hypocritical to change the format from governor’s address to chief minister’s address.

(The writer is a veteran journalist)

Title: 1,500 attend Murugan rath yatra, held amid tight security
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Trichy: More than 1 ,500 people took part in Gnanavel Murugan Rath Yatra near Puthanatham on the outskirts of Trichy on Thursday. During the procession, members of Vishva Hindu Parishad (VHP), one of the organizers of the festival, appealed to the people not to spread false propaganda against the citizenship amendment Act (CAA).

The organizers including the residents of 18 villages and VHP members pulled a chariot carrying the deity of Murugan through the streets of the villages from Paraipatti to North Idaiyattupatti.

The annual festival commenced with the procession of around 1,500 people including around 200 women at Paraipatti village and passed through Malaikattupatti and Karuncholaipatti before reaching Puthanatham area.

A special pooja was performed for the deity on the ratha in front of Kaliamman temple in South Street in Puthanatham before resuming the procession towards Gnanavel hill.

Considering the religious sensitiveness in the area, Trichy rural police headed by superintendent of police Zia Ul Haq camped in the area to ensure the peaceful conduct of the festival.

The police said that they deployed 650 police personnel along the four kilometre stretch of the procession route.

The Puthanatham police team led by inspector Shanmugasundaram deployed drones to monitor the procession to avert any untoward incidents. As a part of the festival, some of the leaders of the VHP also addressed the gathering and registered their concern over the propaganda against CAA.

Title: MDL lists 300 items it hopes to buy from UP
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Lucknow: A chemical manufacturer in Kanpur who has developed a water repellent, a man in Shahjahanpur who has created fire- resistant marine plywood, a valve supplier in Kanpur and startups from IIT Kanpur are some of the reasons why Mazagon Dock Shipbuilders Ltd (MDL), a GOI undertaking, has come to UP to scout for possible suppliers and manufacturers.

In a meeting with more than 50 interested industrialists on Thursday ahead of the Defence Expo, MDL put forward a list of 300 items which it hopes it can source from UP. It has been mandated to procure goods worth at least Rs 10,000 crore from MSMEs in the next 8-10 years, which is a massive opportunity for companies in UP, said Rear Admiral AK Saxena, director of ship building at MDL.

The company’s foray into UP has been facilitated by Indian Industries Association, the umbrella body of MSMEs in the state.

MDL has said that if MSMEs cannot export bulk orders of products and equipment to far off places like Mumbai, MDL can help with that too. It is also ready to handhold startups and even assist with funding if the product is of superior quality. General secretary of IIA Manmohan Agarwal said after Defence Expo, IIA would arrange for a visit of industrialists to MDL in Mumbai.

Title: At Chennai book fair on the footpath, old books find new readers
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Vendors sell used books outside the book fair

CHENNAI: If you are visiting the book fair at YMCA in Nandanam , then don’t miss this ‘alternate’ fair. The pavement leading to the YMCA premises on Anna Salai is dotted with vendors selling old books .

Around 10 stalls have put on sale 10,000 books of which most are English titles with prices ranging from Rs 10 to Rs 150. Most of the vendors ply their trade on pavements near LIC and on Bharathi Salai in Triplicane, and move to venues near book fairs every year.

A M Hyder, a stall owner, said rare books sold at reasonable rates were their USP. “We have books on furniture, antiques and numismatics that may not be available at the book fair. Some books on writings of Mahatma Gandhi are also rare,” he said.

Vendors source used books from different parts of the city. Books on academics, English grammar and novels are in high demand. Titles of international authors are available in plenty.

Villivakkam-based C N Vathilingam, a vendor for more than 50 years, said he had always set up a stall near the fair. “Some of my friends give away books stocked in their homes or we buy them cheap. We sell them,” he said. Vaithilingam once owned a book shop at Moore Market.

Vendors said people looked for specific titles and previous editions of titles no more available. While some vendors said there was brisk sale this year, a few reported poor business. S Nandhakumar, who is selling hard copies of articles published on an online portal, said his objective was to promote the portal. “But I will hardly earn Rs 300 during the book fair,” he said.

The stalls though have attracted book lovers and onlookers. S Sathya, who works for a private firm and bought a book on Gandhi, said, “I regularly purchase a couple of books from these stalls when I visit the book fair.”

Title: Nagpur: Sahebrao rejects artificial limb, doctors disappointed
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

The artificial limb was designed and made by Dr Sadanand Thote and Ameya Kathale of Saket Orthopaedic Applianc... Read More

NAGPUR: The world’s first attempt to fit a prosthetic limb to Sahebrao, a male tiger, ended in a disappointment after the big cat rejected it by thumping and shaking it loose. Wildlife veterinarians and orthopaedicians, who initiated the process to fit an artificial limb to Sahebrao on Saturday morning, immediately removed the prosthetic even before it could stand and attempt to walk.

Ever since losing its left paw in a trap in 2012, Sahebrao has been housed in the Gorewada Rescue Centre in city, where the operation to give the nine-year-old a chance to walk comfortably was conducted.

“After the anaesthesia wore off, Sahebrao seemed anxious on the object screwed to his paw. Feeling uncomfortable, it started banging its foot continuously. We suspect it contracted its muscles resulting in the prosthetic coming off easily even though it was fitted well with screws,” said city orthopaedician Dr Sushrut Babhulkar and wildlife surgeon Dr Shirish Upadhye.

Maintaining that it was a difficult operation, Dr Peter Giannoudis said the doctors “have learnt from the experiment and we will have to restore the missing links”. A professor of orthopaedics in University of Leeds, he had visited Gorewada twice to take a look at Sahebrao.

Dr Babhulkar said the failure had nothing to do with the measurement or design of the prosthetic. “We never imagined that the tiger would contract its muscles. The cat species can shrink their size by contracting skeleton muscles,” he added.

The artificial limb was designed and made by Dr Sadanand Thote and Ameya Kathale of Saket Orthopaedic Appliances & Artificial Limb Centre, in city. Kathale said, “This was the first such prosthetic for a tiger. Earlier, I have done it successfully for cats and dogs. It is easier to do it for domestic animals but difficult in carnivores,” he added.

Sahebrao’s limb weighed 1.8kg. “After a lot of research it was brought down to that weight so that the tiger could sustain its weight. Anything lighter in weight would have compromised on quality,” said Kathale.

Next, Dr Babhulkar said they plan to do ‘osseointegration’ where a new bone is laid down directly on the implant surface and the implant exhibits mechanical stability. “However, we will rework on the plan at a later stage after getting in touch with experts worldwide. For now, we are just dumbfounded over the unsuccessful attempt,” he added.

Dr Babhulkar came to know about Sahebrao’s plight through forest staff who visited him for treatment. The orthopaedician then adopted him on February 2018 and promised to get an artificial limb after expert advice.

The experts first suggested removing neuroma in the tiger’s limb. As a first step, Sahebrao underwent clinical and radiological tests in August 2018. During the same time, it was measured for the prosthetic.

In October last year, the tiger was operated upon by Dr Upadhye, Dr Gautam Bhojne, Dr Vinod Dhoot and others for neuroma and arthritis. It is only after relieving it from pain that the operation to fit the artificial limb was attempted.

“The Maharashtra Animal and Fishery Science University (Mafsu) and Forest Development Corporation of Maharashtra have signed an MoU to promote research. We are not averse to further modifications and efforts to give an artificial limb to Sahebrao,” said FDCM MD Dr N Rambabu & Dr Ashish Paturkar, vice-chancellor of MAFSU.

Title: 10 years on, transport hub proposed at Karodi still on the back-burner
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Aurangabad: The proposed transport hub at Karodi on the outskirts of Aurangabad city is still a distant dream, drawing sharp reactions from stakeholders.

The project was first mooted around a decade ago when the ‘Vision 2020’ document for Aurangabad city was prepared. The initiative of the then guardian minister Radhakrishna Vikhe Patil, the document had proposed solutions to some of the pressing issues faced by the city on different fronts.

The proposed transport hub at Karodi was expected to minimize traffic of heavy vehicles in the city besides serving as a one-stop solution for different needs of transporters.

Civic activist Sayyed Mushtaq Sayyed Isaak said that it was ironic that the project which was envisaged in the ‘Vision 2020’ document around a decade ago is still on paper.

“States such as Madhya Pradesh, Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh have set up transport hubs which offer multiple benefits. Taking a cue from some of these projects, we had proposed a similar facility in Aurangabad. The project had found a place in the ‘Vision 2020’ document also, but no progress could has been made,” he said.

According to stakeholders, the revenue department authorities had also proposed land of around 65-acre for the project at Karodi.

“Despite repeated follow-ups with the government authorities and public representatives, the transport hub has witnessed no progress. The facility could have been vital for the growing city like Aurangabad, which witnesses huge movement of the commercial vehicles,” Sayyed said.

Aurangabad district collector Uday Chaudhari could not be reached for his comments.

Meanwhile, no progress has been witnessed either on the demand for shifting the freight loading and unloading point at Aurangabad railway station. The place is located in the immediate vicinity of the station and witnesses huge traffic of heavy vehicles.

Title: Man held at Madurai International Airport for using fake passport
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: A 61-year-old man was arrested at the Madurai International Airport for forging and using a fake passport to travel.

The accused, Paramasivam S from Thamarakki Vadaku in Sivagangai district, was arrested when he was trying to use the fake passport to travel to Dubai from the international terminal at Madurai airport on Wednesday. He procured the passport by providing false information, police said. The false passport contravened the provisions of the passport document.

A case has been registered at Perungudi police station under various sections for forgery by furnishing false information, forgery with the intention of cheating and using the forged document, all read with the Indian Passport Act. Investigation is underway.tnn

Title: Nashik shivers as mercury hits season’s lowest of 9.8 degree Celsius
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

This was the minimum temperature recorded in the state, followed by Mahabaleshwar which had 10.8 degrees celsi... Read More

NASHIK: Nashik city experienced the coldest day of the season so far on Thursday when the minimum temperature dropped to 9.8 degrees celsius.

This was the minimum temperature recorded in the state, followed by Mahabaleshwar which had 10.8 degrees celsius.

The previous lowest temperature of the season was recorded on January 9 at 10.2 degree celsius. The city recorded a drop of 3.5 degrees celsius in minimum temperature on Thursday. The maximum temperature was 22.2 degrees celsius.

The Met officials said on Thursday that the chill in Nashik and adjoining areas would prevail for the next 24 hours.

After the minimum temperature dropped to 10.2 degrees celsius on January 9, it had risen by 5.3 degrees celsius in the next five days to settle at 15.5 degrees celsius on January 13. Since then, however, there has been a drop of almost by 5.7 degrees celsius in the past four days.

“We had been feeling cold over the past week though there have been fluctuations in the minimum temperature. It was a bit warm around three days ago, but suddenly, we started feeling cold again. As winter is the right time to burn calories, I have started running in the mornings,” said Akshay Patil, a student.

The district’s Niphad taluka, which is the grape-growing region, recorded the season’s lowest temperature at 9.4 degrees celsius on Thursday. According to the Mahatma Phule Krishi Vidyapeeth, Rahuri, this is the lowest temperature recorded in Niphad this season as against the previous lowest temperature of 8.8 degrees celsius on January 11.

Meanwhile, Malegaon recorded minimum and maximum temperatures of 13.2 and 24.4 degrees celsius, respectively. Jalgaon city recorded minimum and maximum temperatures of 16 and 24.8 degrees celsius, respectively.

Ahmednagar city recorded a minimum temperature of 13.6 degrees celsius and a maximum of 31.1 degrees celsius.

Title: Nagpur: Ex-VIA president’s company under I-T scanner
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

NAGPUR: Former president of Vidarbha Industries Association (VIA) Pravin Tapadia has come under the income tax department’s scanner. Tax sleuths have conducted a raid on one of the companies in which he is a director. The department on Thursday conducted search and survey operations on Tapadia Polyesters Private Limited, run by Tapadia, as well M/s Mira Zarda, a betel-nut and tobacco trading firm located in Itwari area. The firm is headed by local businessman Ajay Kamnani.

It is learnt that the taxmen had been keeping tabs on the affairs in Tapadia Polyesters on a regular basis after which finally a raid was planned. The action covers seven premises. A search or raid as it is known in common parlance was conducted in four out of these. A survey was conducted in three. In a survey no cash or other assets can be seized from the premises, but it can be done so if it’s a search operation.

Sources said the company was apparently suppressing income by not recording part of it’s sales and purchases. There are chances that proceeds of such transactions may have been parked in real estate.

In Mira Zarda, sleuths have found that the firm was dealing in banned tobacco products like gutkha and certain low grade cigarettes, which too are banned. The entire deals in the banned items took place in cash, totally evading the tax. Here a search has been conducted in five premises and a survey in four. So far no seizure of cash or other items has been made in both cases, said sources.

Earlier, the income tax department’s directorate of investigation here had detected an alleged refund scam in Nashik. Jurisdiction of the directorate at Nagpur extends up to Nashik. It was found that a number of salaried taxpayers had secured refunds through an agent on the basis of fake documents. So far the department has recovered Rs16 crore such refunds granted to them, said sources.

Title: No meat for Kanpur Road residents for 20 days
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

LUCKNOW: At least 35,000 people living along the 10.9km stretch between Chaudhary Charan Singh Airport and Vrindavan Colony on Kanpur Road will be deprived of meat and fish from retailers and local markets from January 20 to February 9.

As part of the security arrangements for the 11th Defence Expo slated to take place from February 5-8, the district administration has ordered temporary closure of all meat shops in the area for the period. Even roadside vendors selling eggs or meat items and food vans will be removed from the route for at least 20 days .

“The area has been declared a low-fly zone and the protocol involves closure of all meat shops in a 7km radius of the airport to make it a meat-free zone,” said nodal officer for the expo at Lucknow Municipal Corporation Arvind Rao. Officials said that fighter planes participating in the show will take off from and land at CCS Airport. They will fly low until they reach an open ground in Vrindavan Colony, above which the air show will be performed.

“Meat shops often dispose leftovers in the open which attract carnivores including birds. Closing meat shops is essential to deter birds from the area to avoid accidents with planes,” explained Rao.

LMC has also constituted 10 teams to conduct drives for closure of meat shops from January 20.

Title: Employees taking leave for KAS exam leaves dept in quandary
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: General administration department has sought the intervention of chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan to cancel the leave of more than 50 secretariat employees who availed it to prepare for the first Kerala Administrative Service ( KAS ) examination to be held on February 22.

A note by principal secretary (GAD) K R Jyothilal said that several employees going on leave to prepare for the examination has affected the functioning of the secretariat, especially when the budget session of the assembly is all set to begin from January 31. The note also said that if those employees who are on leave are appearing for the examination, they should be disqualified.

The note also said that ignoring the duties while on service and preparing for another examination shows their lack of social commitment. “The trend of bettering their own career by ignoring the services to be offered to the public should be discouraged,” the note said. More than 50 employees have availed various types of leave including earned leave and leave without pay, citing multiple reasons. Secretariat sources said that though the leave does not mention anything about the examination, many of them have availed the leave for preparation.

More than four lakh applicants are appearing for the KAS preliminary examination, including several employees from the secretariat. KAS has reservation for those in the government service as well, in addition to general category. Meanwhile, the note by the general administration department secretary has not gone well with the employees’ organizations. “The matters mentioned in the note itself is unwarranted. In KAS, two streams are reserved for government employees. So, how can they be disqualified if they appear for the examination conducted by the public service commission, just because they availed leave? Also, it cannot be said that all those who have availed leave have availed it for exam preparation. The leaves for which they are eligible have been sanctioned by their superior authorities,” general secretary of pro-left Kerala secretariat employees’ association K N Ashok Kumar said.

It is learnt that the chief minister’s office have declined the demand.

Title: Non-functional escalators frustrate passengers at railway station
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Aurangabad: Several passengers have complained that the escalators installed at the Aurangabad railway station remain non-operational at most times, especially during the arrival of key trains, posing huge difficulties.

Elderly passengers, expected mothers as well as those travelling with children have been at the receiving end of the lapse.

Narrating his experience, former corporator Mohsin Ahmed said that the escalators at the railway station were not working when he arrived by Nandigram Express on Wednesday morning.

“It was hardship for senior citizens to reach either at the desired platform or exit gate of the station using the foot overbridges (FOB). Moreover, non-functional escalators led to rush at the foot overbridges. It can lead to stampede like situation during rush hours,” he said.

Echoing similar experience, Sanjay Gaikwad, a private professional, said that the passengers carrying heavy luggage often face difficulties due to non-operational escalators.

“I had to carry my huge baggage and handle my children at the same time while making way out of crowded foot overbridge. It was shocking to see such poor management at the railway station,” Gaikwad said.

Aurangabad railway station is equipped with escalators at platforms 2 and 3. The station witnesses footfall of nearly 15,000 passengers per day, including large number of foreign tourists.

Railway activist Omprakash Varma said that the “defunct” escalators not only cause inconvenience to passengers but also leaves a bad impression about the region in the minds of tourists.

“The historic city of Aurangabad and world heritage sites of Ajanta-Ellora are visited by a large number of foreign tourists. The defunct escalators definitely leaves a bad impression in the minds of foreign nationals,” he said.

When contacted, Aurangabad railway station manager L K Jakde said the private contractor assigned with the responsibility of manning the escalators has been reprimanded. “The contractor is based at Nanded and we have informed the divisional authorities about the lapse on his part. We have also proposed a fine to the contractor upon our part,” he said.

Title: Accused in SSI Wilson murder remanded
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Abdul Shameem (left) and Taufeeq, accused in the SSI Wilson murder case, being escorted by police from Thuckal... Read More

COIMBATORE/MADURAI: A file pertaining to sanction granted by the ministry of home affairs (MHA) for setting up a unit of the National Investigation Agency in Chennai is pending with the ministry of finance. Once the finance ministry gives its nod, the unit of the NIA, the primary agency to combat terror, will be set up in Chennai and an officer in the rank of Superintendent of Police will head the unit.

The NIA is also expected to take over the case relating to the killing of special sub-Inspector of police Y Wilson, who was shot dead by two IS suspects at Kaliyakkavilai in Kanyakumari district on January 8. “The district police registered a case under IPC section 302 (for murder ) and the Arms Act. If the case is also registered under the Unlawful Activities Prevention Act (UAPA), then can we take it over for further investigation. We are, however, closely monitoring the case,” said the source.

“The MHA had given its nod to set up the NIA unit in Chennai last month. An SP and more than 20 officials will be appointed as part of the Chennai team. An office building for the NIA will be established in the city. The file is pending before the Ministry of Finance for approval,” said an NIA source. Currently, NIA officials from Kochi are handling the cases reported from TN.

Meanwhile, the two terror suspects Abdul Shameem and Taufeeq, who were picked up at the Udupi Railway Station in Karnataka on Tuesday for their suspected role in Wilson’s murder, were produced before a court in Kanyakumari district late Thursday evening and remanded in judicial custody. They have been lodged at the Palayamkottai Central Prison.

Kanyakumari SP N Sreenath told reporters, “The two accused were upset over the arrest of their accomplices and killed Wilson in an act of revenge and to teach the police and administration a lesson.” They killed the officer at Kaliyakkavilai as they were familiar with the place, he said.

Police say the two men had also confessed to having planned coordinated attacks using suicide bombers on Republic Day on January 26.

The SP added that the duo would be taken into police custody soon as they needed to be questioned about their extremist links. “We had very limited time, just 24 hours, to produce them before the court (from the time of arrest). So, we could not question them much,” he said, adding that the gun used for the murder was yet to be recovered.

Medical examination of the two men was conducted by a team of doctors in the Thuckalay police station before they were taken to the Kuzhithurai court. Sreenath said security had been stepped up at all the major as well as minor border check posts connecting Kanyakumari with Kerala. He said the small check posts, like the one where Wilson held post, were primarily established to check movement of medical and poultry wastes from Kerala to Tamil Nadu. “We have now posted armed men and officers and asked them to be on high alert round-the-clock,” he added.
