Title: Tamil Nadu: Two hacked to death in brawl
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

THANJAVUR: In a drunken brawl, two men were hacked to death and one seriously injured at a Tasmac bar by a gang in Thanjavur late on Wednesday.

An altercation owing to previous enmity between the groups led to this incident, police said. “Their friend who was grievously injured during the incident has been admitted in hospital for treatment,” police said. According to the police, the deceased have been identified as K Sakthivel, 36, a resident of North Street, and B Sebastian, 26, a resident of Irattai Pillaiyar Koil street in Thanjavur town.

Both the victims had gone to a tasmac bar on North Street along with their friend Sathishkumar, 26, a native of Thillai Nagar in the town, to have liquor. Selvam alias Selvakumar, Pachaikili alias Surya and Sundhar alias Sundharamoorthy of the same area also arrived at the same tasmak bar to consume liquor.

Both the gang picked up a quarrel over previous enmity. At one point, Selvakumar and his accomplices started to attack Sebastian with sharp weapons. Although Sakthivel tried to pacify the attackers, the gang attacked Sakthivel and Sathishkumar too and fled the scene, police said.

Police have secured three people including Selvakumar and Surya.

Title: Tamil Nadu Tourism Development Corporation to run two special Trichy-tour buses today
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

TRICHY: The Tamil Nadu Tourism Development Corporation ( TTDC ) will operate two buses instead of one for the ‘Special Trichy City Tour’ on Friday starting from Hotel Tamil Nadu near central bus stand at 9am and return at 6pm.

As Friday happens to be Kaanum Pongal, when most families spend time going for outing, TTDC has decided to connect some of the places of tourist attraction like Vekkaliamman temple, Malai Kottai, Srirangam, butterfly park, Thiruvanaikoil, Samayapuram and Anna science centre with their ‘hop-on hop-off’ bus tour.

This is the first time TTDC will be operating buses to seven destinations within the city, most of them tourist attractions. Those intersted in the service will have to pay Rs 10 per head.

The bus will follow a circular route with fixed stops (eight stops) and allow passengers unlimited travel for a day with the freedom to disembark at any stop and re-board bus to continue their journey till 6pm.

“Earlier it was decided to operate one bus with seating capacity of 36. As we we have been receiving more inquiries, we have decided to add one more bus with a seating capacity of 18,” said TTDC regional manager G Sabesan.

“There are two advantages, one is people can travel for a cheap rate and there is no bus service within the city connecting all the 7 destinations,” he said.

On being asked if more number of passengers want to avail the service, he said they will consider adding more buses based on the response.

TTDC had introduced ‘hop-on hop-off’ tour for the first time in Chennai on pilot basis and had to operate five buses till Mahabalipuram after receiving overwhelming response, said a TTDC official.

Title: Telangana: No discount on roundtrips at toll plazas on cash payment
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: While toll plazas across the state were supposed to migrate to FASTag lanes with only two lanes on either side accepting cash, some plazas have been exempted. Two plazas – at Pantagi on NH 65 and Raikal on NH 44 — will be exempted.

“At these plazas, cash will be accepted on 25% of the lanes for next 30 days,” said NHAI regional officer, A Krishna Prasad. This means three to four lanes will accept cash.

The reason for this was heavy traffic pile and high number of cash transactions. “Commuters are being given more time to migrate to the new system,” Prasad said.

Meanwhile, the regional officer informed that commuters will not be given discount on roundtrips on cash payments. “No return journey discount shall be provided to toll payments paid in cash or any other modes with effect from January 15,” an NHAI circular read.

Title: Only dinner, no diplomacy, says minister Govind Rajput
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Minister PC Sharma with Jyotiraditya Scindia in Bhopal on Thursday

Bhopal: State minister for transport Govind Singh Rajput, who will host a dinner for members of the cabinet and all MLAs supporting Congress, during the visit of his political mentor Jyotiraditya Scindia on Friday, has said that the dinner is being held to mark the New Year and has nothing to do with ‘dinner diplomacy’, as it is being stated in a section of the state media.

Talking to reporters at the state assembly building on Thursday, Rajput said that they are happy that Jyotiraditya Scindia will participate in the dinner, where all ministers, CM and MLAs supporting the government will be present. “There is no politics involved in the dinner”, he said.

During his visit, Scindia will visit Pradesh Congress Committee (PCC) headquarters and attend dinner at Rajput’s official bungalow, besides attending to some personal engagements. He had similar itinerary when he visited the city on July 10-11 last year. Then, health minister Tulsi Silawat had hosted the dinner in which chief minister, ministers and MLAs supporting the government, including two SP MLAs and a BSP MLA took part. During that time, some ministers from Scindia camp had openly complained of being “neglected”. The dinner hosted by a minister from Scindia faction in such a situation was touted as Scindia’s “dinner diplomacy” by a section of media.

Silawat had said then that the dinner was to show unity in Congress and dispel the notion propagated by BJP that this government won’t survive. The political situation remains more or less the same, except for the fact that Kamal Nath government seems far more stable and confident now, but issues like PCC chief and Scindia’s nomination to the Upper House in the election slated in April are still on top of the agenda for the state party leadership.

Title: Hyderabad: Bone-jarring ride, rue Kompally residents
Content:
The road to Kompally municipal office is one filled with potholes and bumps

HYDERABAD: The road to Kompally municipal office is one filled with potholes and bumps . The main road, which is a two minute ride from National Highway-44, is surrounded by commercial properties on either sides.The stretch is not an anomaly but a regular feature in Kompally, one of the fastest growing municipalities that houses several commercial and residential buildingsThe reason behind the poor condition of the roads has been attributed to work being taken up by the Hyderabad Metropolitan Water Supply and Sewerage Board (HMWS&SB).The water board had dug the road to lay a 35-kilometre-long pipeline network under Telangana government’s ‘Mission Bhagiratha’ scheme, to provide potable water to every household.Another resident, S Jagannatha Reddy, said, “It is the responsibility of authorities to restore the roads . Several pleas have been sent to the engineering wing, but they have been ignored.”When TOI contacted Subramanyam, deputy general manager, HMWS&SB project division-V said, “The water board will not take up road restoration works at Kompally municipality as it is comes under GHMC. Our job is to lay the pipeline network. It is the civic body that has to attend the road restoration works.”MNR Jyoti, municipal commissioner, Kompally said, “Road restoration work will be taken up after the civic polls.”Residents also expressed dissatisfaction over the condition of drainage system and water supply in the area. The area records frequent instances of sewage inundation as the existing sewerage that was laid a decade ago cannot handle the present load.Kompally municipality deputy engineer, Srilatha, said, “There is a proposal to revamp the existing drainage system in Kompally. A consultancy will be appointed to prepare a ‘detailed project report’ on drainage systems. We are facing financial crunch too.”Residents have also brought the water problem in the area to the notice of the 81 candidates who will be contesting the upcoming polls. “Despite the government introducing a network to provide potable water, we hardly get water for half-an-hour and the pressure is abysmal,” P Ajad, a shopkeeper said.

Title: Madurai: Class V, VIII students under pressure to perform despite board exam puzzle
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: With half-yearly exams done and dusted, board exams loom ahead for students of classes V and VIII for the first time. As uncertainty still surrounds the exams, right from the syllabus to question paper pattern, many schools in the city and parents are pressurising students to study harder.

During the middle of this academic year, the school education department had announced public exams for students of Class V and VIII from this year. Later, it said that students writing for the first three years would not be failed. “Even if students don’t fail, making it a public exam creates pressure for students because schools tend to focus on results. If the students’ performance is not good enough, then the schools’ reputation will be affected. If the top score of a school is low, it can greatly affect admissions for the new year. So, there is pressure to make students work harder at even their young age,” said a government school teacher who spoke on condition of anonymity.

Several government school teachers said that so far no official instruction has been given to conduct special classes after school hours. However, many of them are voluntarily conducting them particularly for late bloomers in a bid to get them to perform better in exams. Many private schools are also holding special classes to help students score better. The classes are mainly in response to the fact that there is still no clarity on the question paper pattern or blueprint so students as a precaution need to cover all portion from all three terms.

Sruthi A, a class VIII student who studies in a private school, said that even if students try to take it easy, parents and teachers are making them feel the pressure. “My parents told me that it is similar to the usual annual exam but that the test papers will be corrected by teachers of another school. That eases my fears but it was pressure enough to be expected to be class topper. Now, teachers and parents expect us to become toppers at state level,” she said.

On the other hand, some feel the move to hold board exams for students at a young age can benefit students, especially from government schools where teachers may not be under pressure to teach lower classes well. “Many government school students are unaware of basic concepts and can barely read or write in class X. These exams can ensure that the quality of teaching in government schools goes up,” said Pandiselvi N, a parent.

Title: Nagpur: 30th sociology meet at Amravati from January 23
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

NAGPUR: The 30th convention of professors and students having sociology background will be held on January 23 and 24 at Takshashila Mahavidyalaya, Amravati .

The meet has been organized by Marathi Samajshastra Parishad and will be based on the theme of the study of sociology completing 100 years in India. The study of sociology in the country was facilitated at Mumbai University in 1919.

The conference will be inaugurated by vice-chancellor of Amravati University Muralidhar Chandekar in the presence of former president of Indian Sociological Society, Anand Kumar, from Delhi. Kirti Arjun will preside. Avinash Moharil, parishad president Saroj Aaglave and sociology department head at Amravati University KB Nayak will attend the inauguration ceremony.

The inaugural function will be followed by a lecture on ‘Progress in the study of sociology in India’ by Shankar Gaikwad. The session will be chaired by PG Jogdand from Mumbai.

This will be followed by Iravati Karve memorial lecture which will be delivered by Shaunak Kulkarni, head of the department of anthropology at Pune University. He will speak on ‘Anthropological research in Maharashtra’. D Shrikant from Kolhapur will chair the session.

On the concluding day of the conference, over a lecture on ‘Contemporary context of sociology’ will be delivered by professor Ramesh Kamble from Mumbai. Narayan Chaudhary from Nashik will preside. There will be two sessions for the professors to present their dissertations. Principal Mallu Padwal will preside.

The valedictory function and awards ceremony will be chaired by Kamal Gavai, founder president of Shri Dadasaheb Gavai Charitable Trust, Amravati.

Title: Budget to fix many eco issues: Thakur
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Kolkata: The Centre is keeping its fingers crossed for revival of India’s economy by shifting its focus from ‘Look East’ to ‘Act East’ policy.

The Union Budget 2020-21 slated to be presented on February 1 is likely to resolve several issues being faced by traders in the country and give thrust on agriculture, job creation and boosting investment on infrastructure development, said Anurag Singh Thakur , Union minister of state, finance and corporate affairs.

Thakur met the representatives of various merchants and traders’ associations at a special session in the city on Thursday and took down their suggestions to resuscitate the economy. “This time, I am in the city to listen to the problems being faced by the traders and know about their expectations in the budget,” said Thakur.

However, the minister of the state sounded confident that the present financial capacity of the country would take a leap in the next five years when “Prime Minister’s targeted 5 trillion economy” can be achieved. “Till now, the Central government has achieved $1 trillion of the target,” he added.

Divestment in share markets, generation of employment, tweak in the policy of environmental clearance for industrial sectors, abolition of GST from real estate sector, boost for housing sector, governmental support to create an appropriate roadmap for the NRIs who are keen to open startups in the country were among the suggestions given to the minister by the representatives of Merchants’ Chamber of Commerce, Bharat Chamber of Commerce, Calcutta Chamber of Commerce, Direct Taxes Professionals’ Association and Association of Corporate Advisors and Executives.

Vivek Gupta, president of MCCI told the minister, “The landmark legislation on insolvency and bankruptcy may step up the industrial sector of the country but its implementation is still very slow.” Narendra Kumar Goyal, president of DTPA urged through Thakur that the Centre take a call on the settlement of the cases pending with National Company Law Tribunal. Total 19,771 cases have been pending with the NCLT benches and 10,860 of these cases come under the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code 2016.

“The central bank’s five interest rate cuts last year and billions of dollars of liquidity pumped into financial markets have done little to spur lending. The NPA norms need to be aligned to global norms so that the banks will no longer remain saddled with stressed asset ratios,” said Gupta.

Ramesh Kumar Saraogi, president of BCC, suggested the minister that the Centre make the power sector competitive through PPP model. He also rued that banks only favour big borrowers and are indifferent to MSME units that are “engine of economic growth in the country and have high employment potential.”

The minister said, “I shall take up these issues with the finance ministry and if needed, the government will change policies and amend laws for the country’s economic growth.”

Title: Nanded no more needs kerosene
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Aurangabad: The ‘Pradhan Mantri Ujjwala Yojana’ (PMUY) launched by Prime Minister Narendra Modi has highly benefited Nanded, which has achieved the distinction of becoming a ‘kerosene-free’ district in the Marathwada region

With 16 talukas, Nanded is the largest district in the region which has opted for no demand for kerosene through the public distribution system (PDS).

District supply officer, Nanded, Latif Pathan said on Thursday that off late, there has been a rapid decline in the demand for kerosene through PDS in the district.

“As the number of PMUY beneficiaries started swelling, there were lesser takers of kerosene. Of the 16 talukas in Nanded district, 15 of them had registered zero demand for kerosene through PDS by June last year. There was a certain demand for kerosene only in Umari taluka. Now, even that taluka does not require kerosene,” said Pathan.

Before the launch of the central scheme, Nanded district had a requirement of around 14.68 lakh litre of kerosene through PDS. The district administration has over 5.7 lakh families benefiting from PDS, including over 2.65 lakh target beneficiaries of PMUY. As per official record, LPG connections were given to 1,82,868 PMUY beneficiary families in the first phase and another 25,528 families in the next phase.

“Around 15,821 families are yet to avail the central scheme. This implies that these families are still stuck to the traditional ways of cooking using firewood. Attempts are on to reach out to the remaining beneficiaries,” said Pathan.

Launched on May 1, 2016, PMUY aims to provide Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) connections to households falling below poverty line (BPL) in the country. The scheme, which aims at replacing unclean cooking fuels, mostly used in rural India, achieved the target of giving 8 crore LPG connections seven months ahead of its stipulated deadline set in September last year.

Incidentally, Prime Minister Narendra Modi will be handing over the LPG connection to the 8th crore beneficiary at an event, which will be organised in Sendra, Aurangabad on September 7.

District collector Arun Dongre said Nanded might be among the first few districts in the country to have registered zero demand for kerosene through PDS. “The Pradhan Mantri Ujjwala Yojana has a broad objective of bringing a positive change in the lives of women, especially those from rural areas. The zero demand for kerosene implies successful implementation of the central scheme in the district,” he said.

Title: Hisar peddler arrested with heroin in Chandigarh
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

CHANDIGARH: The UT police arrested a drug peddler after heroin was found on him in Sector 31 on Wednesday.

A police team was patrolling near Sector 31 and Industrial Area, Phase-II, light-point. On seeing the cops, a man tried to flee. But he was chased and nabbed. He identified himself as Harish Kumar, alias Happy, 32, a resident of Hisar. During checking, 20gram heroin was recovered from him. Following the seizure, Harish was arrested under the NDPS Act. On Thursday, he was produced before a local court that sent him to 14-day judicial custody.

On January 14, police had arrested two people, including a woman, after 20 banned injectable vials and 20gram heroin were recovered from them. The two are lodged in Burail jail.

Title: Local girl bags PM Bal Puraskar
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Mangaluru: Moorje Sunitha Prabhu from Belthangady has been selected for the Pradhan Mantri Bal Puraskar announced by the Union ministry of women and child welfare .

The award consists of Rs 1 lakh and a citation. An alumnus of Sri Manjunateshwara CBSE School, Ujire, Sunitha, now a PU student at CFAL, Mangaluru, had represented India in the 80thScience and Technology Fair held at Phoenix, USA, in 2019.

The ministry has selected Sunitha, the daughter of Belthangady-based entrepreneur Vivekanand Prabhu and Shanthala Prabhu, for the award in recognition of her Phoenix achievement. She will receive the award from President Ram Nath Kovind at the Rashtrapati Bhavan on January 22.

Will meet Modi on R-Day

She will have the opportunity, along with her parents, to meet Prime Minister Narendra Modi and other dignitaries at the Republic Day function on January 26.

Title: Cong poll sop: No tax for small houses
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Hyderabad: TPCC on Thursday released a 24-point manifesto for the municipal elections. The highlight of the manifesto is cancellation of municipal tax for all houses under 500 square feet.

A new building regularisation scheme (BRS) will be introduced, and all constructions that contain extra rooms will be regularised, said the document.

The Congress manifesto also said that each municipality will have a modern dumping yard and waste management unit. The party will pressure the government to give each eligible poor 100 sft land and Rs 6 lakh financial support to build houses. Each municipality, will have a modern 100-bedded hospital, a degree college, ITI and polytechnic colleges. Each ward will have two urban health centres and free ambulances, the manifesto said.

Title: Drunk man rams sedan with family of six in Mohanlalganj
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Police at the accident site in Mohanlalganj

LUCKNOW: The driver of a speeding hatchback was on Thursday booked for drunk driving after he rammed his car into a sedan carrying a family of six.

Anshu Verma, the accused, had undergone a breathalyser test in Mohanlalganj police station after the incident on Wednesday around 4pm in Kankaha, Mohanlalganj. He had hit the sedan carrying the family of Allahabad resident Sahid Umar (38). He and his wife Afroz (34), brother-in-law Abdul and three children aged 11, nine and five were injured in the accident.

The impact was such that both cars had overturned multiple times and landed in the undergrowths along the road. Locals had rescued the occupants and sent them for treatment to a community health centre in Mohanlalganj. Anshu Verma, also injured, was detained by police and sent for treatment and medical examination.

Mohanlalganj SHO Gaudeen Shukla said, “We found the accused heavily drunk and confirmed it with a breathalyzer test. The complainant had lodged an FIR of drunk driving.”

Umar’s family was returning from Dubagga and headed to Allahabad.

“After the accident, I lost conscious for a few minutes. When I regained consciousness, I saw my wife bleeding from the head. With the help of locals, I rescued her and my kids and rushed to a hospital. They are out of danger now but still very traumatised,” said Umar.

“There were four people in the hatchback that hit us. Two escaped while the driver and another man were detained. They were heavily drunk and I saw empty liquor bottles inside their hatchback,” Umar further added.

“We were fortunate that no one died. However, men like Anshu must not be allowed to drive vehicles, as they are a threat to people travelling on road,” he said.

Title: Hisar peddler arrested with heroin in Chandigarh
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

On January 14, police had arrested two people, including a woman, after 20 banned injectable vials and 20gram heroin were recovered from them. The two are lodged in Burail jail.

Title: Delhi: Killer stretch to be zero-fatality corridor
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: The three-kilometre stretch on Outer Ring Road between Burari Chowk and Bhalswa Chowk is arguably the ‘deadliest’ in the city claiming several lives every year. This “killer stretch” was chosen by Delhi government for a proposed “zero fatality corridor” last year. The government, in collaboration with SaveLIFE Foundation , was to scientifically assess the cause of accidents.

The average national figure of fatalities per kilometre is 0.5 annually, while the average for this particular stretch is 11 deaths per km per year. The objective behind adopting the stretch was to turn it from the “deadliest” to the “safest”, and replicate its success on other similar traffic ‘black spots’ in Delhi.

On Thursday, SaveLIFE Foundation, transport department and Delhi Traffic Police initiated “tactical urbanism” trials to mark the 31st National Road Safety Week. “The trials are temporary, quick and relatively low-cost interventions,” a statement from the foundation said.

“The objective of these trials is to insert safety elements for all road users. Since 2016, Bhalswa Chowk has featured among the top black spots in Delhi,” said Piyush Tewari, CEO, SaveLIFE Foundation, adding that in the past three years, at least 25 people have on this stretch.

As part of the trial, temporary urban design interventions will be tested to improve the safety for pedestrians, cyclists and other users. The trials started on Thursday at Bhalswa Chowk to test road space redistribution, road geometries and traffic channelisation among other things, the foundation said.

Title: Telangana municipal elections: AIMIM set to contest in 276 civic wards
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

File photo of AIMIM chief Asaduddun Owaisi

HYDERABAD: All India Majlis-e-Ittehadul Muslimeen ( AIMIM ) will be contesting in 276 wards in the ensuing municipal polls.

While campaigning for the polls in Kagaznagar, AIMIM chief Asaduddin Owaisi urged chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao to put a stay on the National Population Register (NPR).

“I request KCR to put a stop on all activities pertaining to NPR. It is against Telangana’s Adivaasi’s, Dalits, Muslims, farmers and poor. This exercise will be an injustice to poor. This country does not belong to a particular religion,” he said while addressing a public rally in Kagaznagar.

Title: Copies replace Chola idols at Ariyalur temple
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

The old and the new versions of the Kala Samhara and the Nataraja at the Alandurayar temple in Keezhpazhvur in... Read More

CHENNAI: The 9th century Alandurayar temple in Keezhpazhvur in Ariyalur was once known for its rare and ancient sculptures. A couple of weeks ago when a team headed by heritage activists S Vijay Kumar and Aravind Venkatraman visited the Chola temple an administrative staff of the temple asked them not to take photographs. This raised doubts and the team after a detailed investigation found that many of the ruined sculptures have been replaced by substandard ones, supposed to have been made by local artisans.

What happened to the old sculptures? No staff at the temple, which is maintained by the Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments (HR&CE) department, could answer to it. When Aravind documented the Alandurayar temple in 2012, the situation was different. The staff were cooperative, and they took him around the temple to try photos of the temple and its sculptures in various angles.

"I was shocked when they told me not to take photographs. But it helped in a way. We wanted to know why they stopped us. We found three ancient sculptures, including the one of Brahma, were replaced with substandard ones in the name of renovation," said Aravind. Worse, the staff were clueless about what happened to the old sculptures.

The Ariyalur-Perambalur belt has some great Chola temples and sadly they have been the target of the Sanjeevi Asokan-Subhash Kapoor gang, according to Vijay Kumar, author of ‘The Idol Thief: The True story of the looting of India’s temples’.

"Due to the publicity around this gang we expected greater awareness and better upkeep, security and maintenance of the temple sites. Sadly, that’s not happening," he said.

"There is a blanket ban by the court on such renovations yet it continues. Neither the ASI nor the HR&CE has come up with a clear conservation manual. But renovation without vision like this goes against the very tenets of conservation," said Vijay Kumar.

There are advanced techniques available today when it comes to restoration of ancient sculptures.

"These ruined sculptures needed special treatment. There are advanced methods and experts are available to do that job. I don’t know why the temple authority removed the ancient ones without following the basic procedures," said Aravind.

The temple is significant as it underwent renovations quite a few times. The ancient brick structure of the temple, historians believe, was renovated with stones during the time of Parantaka Chola I (907-955). The team even found an early Chola sculpture of goddess Jesta discarded outside the temple compound.

"There was no response to our questions on the whereabouts of the rest of the sculptures," said Vijay Kumar.

Title: Nagpur: Help students develop scientific temperament, says MECL CMD
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

The five-day 9th Science Expo was inaugurated at Raman Science Centre & Planetarium, Gandhisagar, on Thursday

NAGPUR: Children should be encouraged to choose the field they are interested in so that they could make rapid progress in life for which the role of teachers and parents is important, said Ranjit Rath, chairman-cum-managing director of Mineral Exploration Corporation Limited, on Thursday.

He was speaking at the inauguration of a five-day ninth ‘Science Expo 2020’ organized by Raman Science Centre (RSC) at its facility near Gandhisagar. Rakesh Kumar, director of National Environmental Engineering Research Institute (Neeri) and Shrikant Pathak, former director of Central Research and Training Laboratory, National Council of Science Museum, Kolkata, were present.

Shedding light on the works of scientists in various fields, Rath said it is important for students to learn how to develop a scientific temper and not to fear science as a subject as it opens a plethora of opportunities to excel. Teachers and parents should guide children in pursuit of knowledge and ensure that questions they pose are answered to develop scientific approach, he added.

Kumar spoke about various scientific inventions and said, “The exhibition gives students a chance to gain knowledge and start thinking out of the box. Experiments students conduct have proved to be beneficial in the long run.”

SK Jena, senior manager at Nuclear Power Corporation of India spoke on ‘Nuclear power: Clean, green and safe’ as part of popular lecture series.

Students visiting the exhibition showed keen interest in the models put up by thirteen institutions like Anthropological Survey of India, Atomic Minerals Directorate for Exploration and Research, Central Citrus Research Institute, Central Institute for Cotton Research, Geological Survey of India, Government Medical College, Manganese Ore Limited, Mineral Exploration Corporation Limited, National Environmental Engineering Research Institute, Raman Science Centre, Regional Remote Sensing Centre and Western Coalfields Limited (from Nagpur) and Nuclear Power Corporation India Limited, Mumbai.

These institutions have showcased research-based models at the exhibition which will be open between 11am and 5.30pm till Monday.

Education officer Abhimanyu Bhalave conducted the inaugural function. Education officer Vilas Chaudhary proposed a vote of thanks.

Title: 11 years on, Rs 73 crore not sought for Sukhna, high court asks why
Content:
Sukhna lake

Administration does not want to work: High court

CHANDIGARH: After 11 years and 120 hearings by 30 different benches, the Punjab and Haryana high court has reserved its judgment on the conservation of the Sukhna Lake catchment area. But the UT must explain why it waited so long to ask the Centre for help.Passing the interim order on Thursday, the high court divison bench of Justice Rajiv Sharma and Justice H S Sidhu not only rapped the UT administration for its “lethargic attitude” that has delayed the sanctioning of Rs 73.51 crore but also gave it two weeks to reopen talks with the environment ministry for this de-siltation and catchment area treatment project.The bench told the ministry to look into matter and consider sanctioning the money.The bench also opined that the Chandigarh authorities must consider the method of dredging and take it to ground, where de-silting of the lake is an urgent requirement. It told the officials to divide the lake into blocks for the preservation effort of dredging.During the resumed hearing, the high court asked the UT administration why it had never tried dredging of the lakebed, to which the UT senior standing counsel replied that experts from the National Institute of Hydrology had stated in report that its was unviable.The court said if the method was good for Pong dam, river Ganga, and the lakes of Nainital, why was it unviable for the Sukhna. The bench observed: “Experts could have their views but we have also seen expert views that defy logic.”The delayed Rs 73.51 crore was for de-silting and deepening the lake. Taking a strong note of the delay, the court observed that: “The Chandigarh administration does not want to work. If the Centre was ready to give the money, why you (the administration) never showed interest? If the UT can’t do this work on its own, it should hand over the job to some other agency. Why is the UT not taking money from the central government when the latter is willing?The high court also observed that its various order had failed to prompt the administration to bring about any tangible change to the state of the Sukhna catchment. It stressed that if the Sukhna was to be conserved and preserved, the problem of desilting must be solved. The Chandigarh administration cannot allow the situation to deretiorate.The UT wants a 2-kilometre eco-sensitive zone in the Sukhna’s catchments, while the Punjab government is trying to keep it to just 100 metres.

Title: Arvind Kejriwal: Don’t put off budget, Delhi’s work shouldn’t suffer
Content:
Arvind Kejriwal

NEW DELHI: Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Thursday urged the Centre not to postpone the Union budget due to the model code of conduct that is in place for Delhi polls.The CM said public welfare was above political benefits for him and the development of the capital should not suffer. He demanded ample funds for Delhi to augment the transport infrastructure, fight pollution, clean the Yamuna, improve sanitation and expand the metro network. The CM, who will soon write to the Centre, also sought funds for the municipal corporations.The Union budget is due just seven days before the assembly elections on February 8. “I have been under pressure from party functionaries to write to the Election Commission objecting to the budget being presented on February 1. But I am not in favour of stalling the budget merely for the elections. In fact, I will like to appeal to the Centre to make new announcements for solving the problems the people of Delhi face,” he said.Citing the funds crunch faced by the municipal bodies, Kejriwal said: “We also want the corporations to get adequate funds from the Centre. The allocations to the corporations will pass through Delhi government, but we have time and again requested funds for them and assured the Centre that the funds will be transferred on the same day.”The civic bodies claim that lack of funds has taken a toll on their efficiency and even the timely disbursal of salaries has been hit by it.The CM demanded that the budget should provide adequate funds to Punjab and Haryana governments to take preventive measures against the pollution caused by stubble burning in these states.Seeking funds for providing sewer connections to each household, Kejriwal said the party that would form the government in Delhi could utilise it efficiently.However, even if Delhi government didn’t receive adequate support from the Centre, his party, if returned to power, would not let the development of Delhi stop, the CM said.

Title: Nagpur: Allen Career Institute to have residential coaching facility
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

NAGPUR: It hasn’t been long since Nagpur has witnessed a linear growth in highly organized coaching centres. In the recent past, the coaching institutes have flourished, competing neck and neck with each other and promising hopeful parents a bright future for their children.

Coaching isn’t what it used to be earlier where students would all cram into the ‘masterji’s’ living room and study together.

Coaching institutes are now known for uniquely designed uniforms, excellent infrastructure, latest ‘modules’ on all subjects, online and offline tests, and expert and technologically advanced counselling.

These coaching centres have streamlined their functioning to the extent that students are denied entry if they do not show ID cards.

However, these facilities come at a price. Students have to shell out hefty fees every year to avail quality education. The demand for coaching centres has increased considerably with more number of students opting for competitive examinations for admission to medical and engineering colleges.

Not surprisingly, coaching giants mainly based at places known as education hubs of the country, have now found in Nagpur a potential destination to attract students with state-of-the-art facilities. Such coaching classes have established themselves in the city and are earning handsomely for innovative ways to help students crack the toughest examinations of the country.

Allen Career Institute is setting up Central India’s first residential coaching facility a few kilometres from Nagpur airport that boasts of a community hall, recreation room, open gym, sports areas, security, CCTV surveillance and shopping complex. There will be separate buildings for boys and girls who can get coaching and live comfortably at the same place.

The venture looks promising for those who move to Nagpur from other places for education. Officials of Allen Career Institute announced this facility at a press conference on Thursday. The expected fees, that includes stay and meals, is about Rs8,500 per month. In the first year, this facility will be open to Std XII pass students aspiring to clear NEET.

The facility has been designed to house over 300 students. The institute will later expand to admit students aspiring to appear for other competitive examinations, and also introduce more courses.

Title: Centre gave Rs 1,000 cr for municipalities: BJP
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Hyderabad: State unit of Bharatiya Janata Party said that all promises made by TRS for municipalities were completely forgotten, including the one regarding double-bed room houses at a minimum cost of Rs 5 lakh.

In a document, which BJP termed ‘chargesheet’, the saffron party said: “In the first phase it was announced that there will be 500-1,000 houses, but nothing really happened.”

BJP said that TRS regime did not send 2.42 lakh applications received under the Pradhan Mantri Avas Yojana to the central government. The document also alleged that though the Centre is releasing Rs 1,000 crore for municipalities, the state government is not releasing a matching sum as part of its share.

Title: Soon, CBCS to offer more options to PG, PhD students of LU
Content:
This story is from January 17, 2020

Lucknow: From new academic session, Lucknow University will implement choice-based credit system (CBCS) at all its post graduation and PhD courses.

The CBCS will offer more learning options to students.

The system was earlier in place only in science courses at PG level.

“The introduction of CBCS will be a major boost to the quality of education imparted at the university level. It will offer more learning options to students with greater flexibility. They will get an opportunity to learn extra subject apart from their core courses,” said spokesperson Durgesh Srivastava.

In a meeting of all heads and deans held on Thursday, it was decided that massive open online courses — which is an online learning and knowledge testing system made available by the ministry of human resource development will be a part of CBCS.

“It will also give students interdisciplinary and intra-disciplinary options, for example, in the inter-disciplinary choice option, a student of science can learn a subject from humanities while in case of intra-disciplinary, a science student of zoology at PG level will also have an option to study botany as one of the subjects,” Srivastava said.

He further added students will also get an option to learn a subject without appearing in any examination of the same,” he added.

The move will give a student of arts the option of studying a course on arts or a language or course of other streams like commerce and science. Similarly, students of other streams will have various option to enhance their the knowledge that will help them in competitive examination and inter-disciplinary research.
